reviewText:
Have you ever noticed how, in a typical RPG (and, now that I think about it, most games in general) battles don’t really mean anything? How many times have you defeated a miniboss, only to have it stand back up and laugh at you, saying “I have underestimated you! You are a worthy opponent! This is not the end! We shall meet again!” and make a getaway? Think about it. How many times do you beat up Balrog in Cave Story only to have him fly away without a scratch? How is Black Knight able to keep running away after Shovel Knight stabs the hell out of him? How come you black out if you lose a Pokémon battle, but none of the other trainers do? And how does the big bad villain always seem to get away, even if their HP hits zero, so they can reappear in the sequel?

Undertale asks the question, “What if defeating an enemy in battle always means that they die?”

This might seem quite inconsequential in random encounters, but Undertale will also pit you against several main characters. If you defeat a main character in battle, they’re dead for good, and the whole story changes to reflect it. Heavy stuff.

But thankfully, as the game advertises, you don’t actually have to kill anyone! The game offers a second option to get out of battles: talking the enemy out of fighting. This involves solving a simple puzzle, almost always involving the “Act” menu in battle. The puzzle changes depending on what kind of enemy you’re fighting; sometimes you’ll just need to give them a compliment, other times you’ll need to survive several of their attacks, and so on. Once they’re not emotionally invested in the battle anymore, you can “spare” them, and the battle ends. You won’t get any EXP for it, but you’ll still get gold. It’s a very unique fighting mechanic!

I admit, after my first playthrough of the game, I was disappointed in the story’s presentation. I thought that both the very beginning and the final area of the game were fantastic, dripping with shocking emotional dilemmas, but the middle 80% of the game’s content seemed like it relied too much on oddball humor and not much else. The game hilariously plays with expectations and has no shortage of genuinely witty satire of its genre, and I found myself amused by nearly all of it, but after the first two hours as I was walking across long linear worlds and listening to dozens of characters try to tell me jokes, I started to wonder where the emotional gravity had gone. “Why is this game making me laugh, when I thought it was supposed to make me cry?” I asked myself. “Where are the feelings? After such an excellent and powerful prologue, why is the game taking so long to show me more?”

Later that night, as I was lying awake in bed, the answer hit me: the game was quirky and lighthearted because I was sparing everyone’s life. I wasn’t playing as a murderer. If you want this game to have drama, you have to cause it. And I think that’s where all the hype is coming from, all the talk about player choice. This is a game about being a tree-hugging pacifist, or a murderous psychopath who kills anyone who gets in the way, or anything in between. You only need to live with whomever you decide to be, because the game won’t let you ignore what you have done.

Though it isn’t the most visually impressive game, and the stage design isn’t always the best, Undertale has left me feeling that I have just witnessed a work of art. It tried some new and ambitious things and isn’t ashamed of what it wanted to be. It's about 6 hours long; I’d recommend anyone to play it at least twice, just to be able to say that they've made their own choices and seen what the game has to offer. It’s hard to imagine that anyone would regret the experience.

reviewText:
Ten dollars. Only a few hours of gameplay. 16-bit graphics compared to the flashy 1080p stuff in standard games.

But... wow. Undertale blew me away. It doesn't need flashy graphics or even fanservice to falsify its enjoyment. It just does things right, and boy that was one immensely enjoyable experience.

I think most of the magic of this game comes from knowing absolutely nothing about it. I got this game from a friend and just decided to play it since it looked very interesting and it was getting good responses. So I went in completely blind, knowing nothing but the game's name. And I'm glad I did, because everything the game presented to me was unexpected, notably dark in places, and very emotional, which would have been lost entirely if i watched someone else play it. So, if you happened to have been flooded by everything Undertale on tumblr (god help us) and the entire story's already laid out for you, the magic has been lost and the game won't be as incredible of an experience. I'm sorry.

Of course, I call Undertale an experience"

reviewText:
Undertale is a game where you, a fusion between Dora the Explorer and the -_- emoticon, fall into a vast cavern that a race of monsters have been trapped in since long ago, and can choose to do tasks, a few of which follow:

-Petting dogs
-Flirting with skeletons/airplanes/your own mom
-Lying on the floor and feeling like utter garbage after a meal
-Striking poses on TV
-Bullying Mike Wazowski
-Accidentally going on a date with a bisexual lizard scientist who is a weaboo
-Hugging goats
-Hugging a volcano
-Petting dogs
-Decaminating the underground area in a bloody massacre
-Getting possessed by a demon
-Petting dogs
-Eating food literally made of spiders
-Determining the realism of anime
-Petting dogs

And that's just a few of the heavy morally weighted you'll have to make in Undertale.
In this world, it's kill or be killed. 10/10

reviewText:
(Mostly spoiler-free review)
I hate turn-based RPGs. This is my Game of the Year. What.

After becoming ULTRA-JADED about gaming with the cancellation of Silent Hills, this game re-established that games can be really, really frickin good.

This thing was made with an incredible amount of love, and it shows in every nook and cranny, every joke, every secret conversation you never thought a game dev would have thought to include. Tobyfox is the most thorough dev ever. I'm continuously impressed with how many things he thought to include in this game, and how he managed to make it all extremely fun the entire way through. You'd think you've seen everything in this game, but you haven't. There's always another amazing thing, another way to turn the genre on its head, another great joke you didn't see coming. And it stays engaging the entire time, supported by a cast of fantastic, endearing, hilarious characters. Great puzzles too, imo!

It avoids all the things about (turn-based and non) RPGs that I despise:
-There's no grinding (unless you want to)
-Battles are a great length and never overstayed their welcome for me
-There's no boring menu-navigation-only-based combat (bullet dodging/timing-based stuff really spices it up, as well as bossfights always having a new, really fun gameplay twist on them!)
-There's no unlikable/unrelatable characters that go on and on about you being the Chosen One" or whatever
-No plot where you gotta go to the 7 temples and find the 7 sacred whatevers and then oh wait now that you've gotten those 7 sacred whatevers
date: you gotta go to 4 extra places and get 4 SUPER sacred whatevers...\n-No backtracking (unless you want to! Backtracking is actually usually rewarded with more fun conversations and such.)\n-No constant equipping and unequipping items because
hoursPlayed: this one is +2 Def but -3 Speed but THIS one is +3 Speed and -2 Def but THIS one is immune to fire and this one is...\n-It actually has a way more complex
voteText: useful moral than "Evil is Bad
helpfulPercent: Good is Good." Everyone has relateable motivations.\n-The writing doesn't suck like 90% of RPGs. It has a wonderful sense of humor and a simple plot that is underlaid with complex emotions.\n-Has jokes about anime
votesHelpful: doesn't take itself seriously.\n\nI could gush about it forever. Undertale's not only made me less jaded about gaming
votesTotal: but also less jaded about real life. It has a strong message about empathy that stays everpresent
votesFunny: while somehow not being cloying about it
commentsCount: or shoving the message down your throat. It's simply a wonderful experience

reviewText:
I was skeptical when I bought it. Oh boy, another game with a moral choice system. I was wrong. So terribly wrong.

Oh man, do your choices matter. Every. Single. One.

And don't think you can pull your usual tricks, either.  Flowey knows what you've done.  Flowey sees all. Flowey knows where you sleep at night. And Flowey... is your best friend. =)

So, are you going to be good? Are you going to have a bad time? What fills you with... determination?

EDIT:
When I wrote this I hadn't fully completed the route, though I thought I had. I'm going to be a little more serious.

This is the only game I've ever played that made me fall out of my chair laughing, jump out of my chair in shock, and slump out of my chair in the least manly of tears. I need a new chair is partially what I'm saying. The other thing I'm saying is... just... holy crap. This game.

Go in blind, but remember this -- you are NOT above consequences.

reviewText:
Some games are okay.

Some games make you stop and reevaluate who you are at the very core of your person, make you feel a depth of emotion that no work of art ever has before, and then leaves you with a genuine sense of loss when its all finally over and gone, because you know you won't ever be able to experience anything that beautiful for the first time ever again.

You should probably play Undertale and find out which one it is.

reviewText:
♥♥♥♥. This is a tough one to write, not at all like my usual reviews. I'm just sort of rambling and gushing because there's so much to say about Undertale... and I can't SAY anything without spoiling the experience for you!

Yes, you!

Buy this game, don't watch anything on YouTube about it, don't read the Undertale subreddit or any wikis, don't even read this review (though I've avoided spoilers, of course) – just seal yourself into a room with a computer and some kind of makeshift toilet, play it to completion, clean yourself for the love of God, and come back.

...

Hero? Villain? Or something wholly other?

The year isn't out and there are some huge releases yet to come, but that being said...

Undertale is a GOTY contender, indie or otherwise.

It's the best RPG in a year of amazing RPG releases.

It's the funniest, most well-written game in, well, a very long time.

It's the most genuinely heartwarming (and incredibly dark) game in, well, a very long time.

It's challenging but surmountable, given a little skill and a whole lot of determination.

And it's also the most mind-♥♥♥♥y game in, well, a very long time, in an entirely unique way! Sure, you can compare it to Metal Gear's Psycho Mantis or Eternal Darkness' sanity meter effects, though that won't do Undertale's special, thoughtful mechanics justice.

But I digress.

You play as a tiny, gender-neutral child with bad fashion sense who falls down a mountain into a cavernous underworld filled with all sorts of fantastical monsters – all of whom have been banished there after losing a war with humankind. Now you have to get yourself back to the sunny, human-friendly overworld.

Fairly standard so far, complete with the pretty concept art cutscenes and humdrum hero origin tale.

Then five minutes pass and all your expectations just sort of fly out the proverbial window screaming, never to return.

Like, ever.

Thus begins your six, seven, or eight hour (initial) journey into Undertale. You'll encounter all sorts of wacky, zany characters and monsters, puzzles, traditional RPG-type environments... loaded with obstacles standing between you and the finish line. And it's up to you decide how you're going to approach the aforementioned zany characters and monsters. Sure, you can do the traditional “kill indiscriminately” thing, but that's just one solution. See, Undertale is an RPG where you can beat the whole damn thing without killing anyone!

Like, you can hug your way through the entire affair!

Easy enough, right?

And you can always just reload a save if you screw up, right?

…

Anyhoo, combat mechanics are... it's hard to describe. It's like a traditional turn-based RPG combat system only, well, those expectations all went screaming out that window I mentioned earlier. Your heart appears in a window below the enemy you're currently dealing with and you have to dodge bullet-hell-style attacks... most of the time anyway. Even after your old expectations are but a distant memory, newly established expectations go flying out screaming too.

It's a little weird.

If fighting is your style you'll have that option, of course. Presented with a flashing bar, hit the sweet spot and you'll do the most possible damage; rinse and repeat. You can access items, check on the enemy's stats and what have you, pursue a peaceful resolution... lots of options, and every monster is a little different.

Well, not a little different – incredibly different, incredible variety! And figuring out their ticks, traits, fears, and dreams is all part of the fun puzzle that is Undertale.

But there's more!

Undertale's music is fabulous – in that wonderfully synthetic, retro way. Every character has a “voice,” every monster, region, and special event has a theme, and when appropriate, the music is chillingly absent. It's the best part of this game - beside the top-notch writing.

I said every character has a “voice,” referring to the musical tones playing during dialogue. But they also each have their own VOICE, you understand? There's the overly protective mother, the bad jokester, the lacking-any-self-awareness fella... but even then it's just scratching the surface. These ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s emote! These sprites have some Shakespearean depth that becomes more apparent with each hour, each playthrough.

You'll care for them, whether you want to or not.

…


What else is there to say? I laughed out loud two dozen times or so, I lost count; I nearly cried at least five times, I was God damned jumpscared more than once, I had an existential crisis, and I'd do it all over again.

And again.

And again.

There's, like, nothing I can even complain about! Were some of the fights tedious, long-winded? Yeah, but I might be biased because I wanted to just enjoy more dialogue, more strange interactions, more environments. Were some of the references lost on me (particularly Anime stuff)? Sure, but that's what Google is for.

Undertale just is... objectively good.

Objectively great.

It's an experience like Shadow of the Colossus, Zelda: Ocarina of Time, Half-Life, Red Dead Redemption, Dark Souls, EarthBound... a little, unassuming 2D RPG game released in 2015 stands shoulder to shoulder with some of the best games of all time – one I initially judged by its cover and ignored.

I'm glad I deleted that particular corrupted save file and started fresh, because missing out on this game would have left a little heart-shaped void that I might have never filled.

reviewText:
There has been no game that has affected me as deeply as Undertale has.

This is coming from someone, who did not understand what the word 'empathy' meant, until age 11, and is still very much trying hard to be a decent human being; the distinction here is important: Empathy, and caring for people does not come naturally for me.

Yet here's a game that made me care. A person that takes the most pragmatic route in every game. A person who was banned from multiple games for griefing, and toxic behavior. I ended up caring deeply about ALL of the characters in this game, and I simply could not bring myself to lay a finger on most of them. I was filled with DETERMINATION to go against how I usually play, and make damn sure that nobody gets hurt, and everyone gets their happy ending.

Toby, man, I have no idea how you managed to do this, but.. Thank you.

As for you, dear reader, you're probably asking; is it worth the asking price?

You tell me. Buy it. Play it for two hours. Steam can refund you, if you hate it; you have literally nothing to lose. You'll have no regrets, either way.

But be good, won't you?

reviewText:
I love this game so much, I made the trailer for it!  I did so after being super impressed by the demo, and asking Toby if there was some way I could help out.

After experiencing the final game, my high expectations were absolutely blown away.

Undertale is a fantastic, novel, unforgettable RPG experience in so many ways.


It couples thoughtful, reactive NPC interactions with a very engaging bullet hell / varied minigame combat system that, unlike most rpgs, never becomes a bore or a slog. Difficulty was a gentle ramp, though affords opportunties for the player to really challenge themselves. All of the combat defenses are unique to each enemy, serving as both funny and clever expressions of their personalities.  Mechanically the combat is so solid it makes me wonder why I haven't seen it done before.

Undertale ties its combat and the rest of its game systems so intricately into its narrative, into achieving what it sets out to do as an experience, that it's almost magical.

The characters are genuinely likable and relatable. I find this supremely important to stay interested in narrative-focused games and Undertale does not disappoint.  Depending on your interactions with characters, the choices you make will hit you.  Hard.

Audio... Well, Toby Fox is known for doing some tremendous music tracks.  On first listen to many of Undertale's songs I said to myself 'oh yeah, I can tell this is going to become an instant classic.' The melodies and compositions are just excellent, and truly help create memorable in-game experiences. You want the soundtrack, trust me.

I might consider graphics to be the 'weakest' aspect of Undertale, but I'd stress that they are utterly appropriate and support the experience.  Really the one nitpick I have is that I'd liked to have seen more NPC animations in the overworld, to make monsters feel as lively and ~sassy~ as they do in combat.  But it's a small quibble in a very, very intricate game. Ultimately Undertale's simple, cartoony, certainly Mother-esque graphic style suits it perfectly, enhancing and fortifying a very chill, friendly tone.

A single playthrough is in the neighborhood of six hours, but by design Undertale encourages both replay and reeximation of choices made throughout the game.  I went through its content repeatedly, eagerly looking for new insights and interactions I had missed, and I feel like I got way more value than I could ever hope to expect for the price.

Get this game, it's touching.  It's worthwhile.  It's Undertale.


Oh, and Toby?  Thanks for letting me help you.  It means a lot to me.

reviewText:
Undertale, “the friendly RPG where no one has to die.” When a game makes you feel bad for killing monsters and makes you consider not killing any more, then it definitely does something right!

Story
The story goes that both monsters and human once ruled over earth, living together, until war broke out between the two races. The humans defeated the monsters and drove them to the depths of Mt. Ebott, trapped with a magic spell. You appear on a bed of golden flowers, and are greeted by a flower, and taught about friendliness pellets. Afterwards, you can choose to massacre every monster you meet, or choose to show mercy to your opponents. Your actions of killing or mercy will shape the way the game progresses, as well as how others view you. The dialogues, and even the music of the game will become happier or distorted based on your killings or acts of mercy. With that said, there are a few endings that can be achieved within the game, some being more satisfying than others; some feeling like you are cutting onions, and some just for the cold hearted. What makes these outcomes to impactful, and sometimes sad, is the way the monsters react to the player’s actions, and sometimes questioning your actions and making you feel like a monster for the things you do. This is also true when you do immoral things like take more than one candy from a bowl of candy that says “take one please”.

Gameplay
Gameplay is very easy to catch on to, and is like one of those old time rpg games like Earthbound. Your goal is simple, but complex, just get through the game(through any means necessary). Your initial goal, or why you are there are not stated, but you can assume you fell down the mountain (as seen in the opening). Your real goal is to play the game as you like, exploring this unique world of monsters and see what it has to offer.  While you explore the world, you will have numerous random encounters with monsters, in which you are a heart that must avoid monster’s attacks, and will die if you take too much damage (causing you to restart at your last save). Pretty easy to understand and play, but a bit difficult to master, as some of the later encounters will be a lot more difficult to dodge seamlessly, and may prove to require a bit more thought and endurance to overcome, rather than just one lucky turn. The game itself is not too difficult, in that it does not have any difficult puzzles to do, and no grinding is required to win the game, as the game can be beaten without killing a single thing.

Visuals/Audio
The visuals are all a bit old timey, but that does not take away from the experience. As for the audio, there are a wide variety of songs that make the game very fun while in combat scenarios. The beginning music was a bit new to me, as I did not think it would have the old retro type of music, but it surprisingly worked well and was not monotonous, and seemed to match the backdrops, and battles very well.

Characters
Why would I include a characters section in a review? The answer is, because they are such an integral part of the game, otherwise it would be like any other rpg, with the exception of the option to spare your opponents.  The characters are what make this game so memorable. It’s not the fact these characters are super likeable, since you may end up disliking or even hating some of them, but the fact these characters will end up growing on you in the end. Without such a unique and hilarious cast of characters, the player would not feel any real motivation to spare them, or any remorse if the player decides to kill any of them. They are in all respects to this game, the driving force that makes it so popular and why it causes many (if not all) it’s players to shed tears.

Verdict: 9/10

Staying determined really is the only way to beat this game!


If you enjoyed this review, please feel free to follow our curator here.

reviewText:
This game does... strange things to people.

It somehow manages to reawaken emotions one would have never thought a game could. The music is spot-on, the dialogue and personalities of the characters are amazing, puzzles aren't particularly difficult but the occasional japes make them seem less tedious.

This game will amuse you.
This game will annoy you.
This game will make you angry.
This game will make you sad.
This game will make you hate everything.
This game will make you love everything.
This game will make you DETERMINED.

Even if you lack the capacity to feel emotions, this game even thought of that and has something very... special for you.

reviewText: One of the most heartfelt and genuine games I've ever played. Undertale is an RPG where, as advertised, you don't have to kill anyone. You play as a child who has accidentally fallen into an underground society of monsters, long since locked away after an unsuccessful war on humanity.\n\nHowever, despite an immediate declaration that this world is kill or be killed
date:
you are introduced to a motherly monster named Toriel who introduces you to the Ruins you have landed in, and the puzzle-based world they live in. From there, you find your own way, and decide to befriend the monsters, or whether they are deserving of your wrath, as you venture forth and find a way home.

As overly 'quirky' as the screenshots of the game may make it seems (although don't get me wrong, the game is gut-bustingly funny), Undertale's writing is top-notch. No other game has invoked so much emotion in me, in... well, ever. The game runs the gambit from heart-wrenching tragedy, to unstoppable laughter, to genuine unease, aided in part by the way the game handles YOU, as a player, and the way you interact within the world, and what sort of entity you are compared to the denizens of the underground. And on top of that, each character is unique and has a strong personality, from the bosses-turned-friends (on pacifist runs) to each and every monster you encounter.

The music is, most certainly, one of the game's strengths. Most of the game was made by Toby Fox, a musician who has composed for the popular webcomic Homestuck. Each track is crucial in setting the game's tone, and most songs will stay with you, even long after you've left the world of Undertale.

I'm really bad and awkward at writing, so if there's one thing to take away from this review, it's this:

This game has exceeded all of my expectations and made me emotionally unstable. Get it.

reviewText:
Undertale went up against all the AAA titles that have come out this year.
Games like Witcher 3, Phantom Pain, etc. All entertaining in their own right.
But I found Undertale to be better than them all.
A ten dollar indie game beat them out.

Play the demo at http://undertale.com/demo.htm and see if its to your taste.
If you enjoy it, I promise you'll love the rest of the game.
Also, play it blind or with as little information as you can.

reviewText:
I just beat the game and got the true Pacifist ending maybe 20, 30 minutes ago and I haven't even closed it yet. It's just sitting there, the end title displayed and the music playing serenely in the background.

Undertale is something really, really special. I laughed until I cried, I bawled my eyes out (three times), I sat and stared and shouted aloud in genuine horror. This game pulls so many sharp turns on the emotional roller coaster that I could barely keep up. Its characters grabbed hold of my heart and held on tight, and I have a feeling they'll be sticking around for a good while now.

This game is the best I have ever played. I don't think words can properly describe it. It's left me with that gaping void that any good entertainment leaves behind, video game or otherwise. I haven't felt like this in years, easily.

Please, if you are on the fence about buying this game, I urge you. Please, buy it. You're missing out on something extraordinary.

reviewText:
Well. This game honestly took me by surprise.

When I first saw this game, I didn't really think much of it, just another generic 8-bit RPG filled with memes, so I didn't really ever consider playing it. Then, a friend of mine gifted me it, and I didn't want to be rude and put it off, so I thought 'hey why not give it a shot?'

And so I did. Frankly I was surprised at the bullethell aspect of dodging enemy attacks in an RPG game, and I don't really mind bullet hell so I welcomed it. Boss battles are also quite unique as well. They each have their own gimmick that you have to do, IF you want to befriend them. (tip: if you want to, there is always a way to spare absolutely every enemy you encounter in the game, no matter what. You sort of have to do that on your first playthrough if you want to see the True Ending). In terms of attacks, they each put in their own unique twists in an attempt to hinder you. Frankly I really liked how all the bosses mixed it up in terms of attacks and gimmicks. Enemies are pretty interesting too

In terms of story, how should I put this? It takes a while to find its own voice, and the story seemed generic with a mild humourous twist at first. But then I got to the final few parts of the game, and the story REALLY picked up from there. VERY rarely have I ever played a game where I managed to legit feel something for the story and it's characters, and Undertale's finale did exactly just that.

NPC's are also pretty unique. A lot of them I found pretty funny, although some of the attempted humour may not appeal to some people, as they may think it tried too hard. Nevertheless, almost all the NPCs are likeable and have clear distinct personalities.

The soundtrack. The soundtrack is, quite frankly, one of the best aspects of this game. I have not found one track in here that I dislike. Just about every single one I've heard, I've loved. The best ones are the boss themes, a lot of them are a mix between retro and modern. Toby pulled off this combination in an absolutely excellent way, putting this game's soundtrack in my list of the best soundtracks I have ever heard in any videogame

Overall, would I reccomend it? It depends. If you don't mind bullet hell and retro style graphics, then this is definitely the game for you. If you don't like either as much, then I'm not sure if you will enjoy this game, but I still advise to try it out for the story/characters. This is definitely one of the better games I played this year, and I can't wait to see what'll happen if I do different things during different runs.

10/10

reviewText:
It has been a long time since a game actually made me give a damn about any of the characters in it, let alone ALL of the charactes in it. This game, Undertale, did that. It made me rememeber how it felt to actually enjoy video games again instead of just playing them to try and fill the gigantic void in my life and block out the bad-thoughts.

This game had me laughing, worried, nervous and deeply caring for the characters and story.
It also has a fantastic soundtrack, incredible boss fights and is all-around a wonderful game.

I recommend this game strongly.

reviewText:
One of my closest friends and I had just had a falling out, and I felt so alone. I thought I'd pick up this little indie game called Undertale and spend some time taking my mind off things. Turns out it would just make me think harder about things than I ever had before. And through this period of confusion and emotional instability, Undertale was my closest friend.

I suddenly had friends and people looking out for me. It all felt so real. So real that I suddenly didn't feel so alone. These people motivated me to learn how to forgive, and go to great lengths to spare someone important to me. And even people who I didn't know. People who might seem nasty, but just need someone to talk to. Undertale taught me that no matter what someone does, or how you feel about something in the past, that it's a better option to not lash out at people and act out of aggression, but to show mercy.

When my friend came back to say to me that she wanted to talk to me again, I remembered everything that had happened before. How bad I had felt, and how I felt the only way to feel better was to make sure we had nothing to do with each other. The day that happened, I remember my heart shattering. As if I had died. But here I was, standing here now in a situation that seemed all too familiar to me. But how was I going to act this time? In this world, second chances don't appear as often as we'd all like. So this time, I made sure to welcome her with open arms.

My friend and I made up, and I have Undertale to thank for making it clear to me that it was the right thing to do. When people fight, the solution is never to distance yourself more so that you'll hurt less. In fact, doing so will just hurt everyone a lot more. Just try and talk it out. Being a pacifist can go a long way. And who knows, you might even make a friend or two.

To those of you who might feel lonely, or bitter, or just plain unhappy, Undertale is here for you. Here to let you reflect on yourself, and maybe even some other people you might know. If you're lucky, you might even figure something out like I did.

If you need a friend, Undertale will be your friend. But, friendship won't happen unless you give each other a chance. So what will you do? Give it some thought. Wherever you are and however you're doing, I hope things end up working out for you. Until then, stay determined.

reviewText:
Playtime and Time/money The game in total took me 5 hours to complete a path, after that I beat the other 2 paths clocking in at 15.1 hours. the time money value is... slightly off though, because it's far less about how much time you play this game, and far more about the fun you had while playing. But in case you still want to know, my rate for the game was 0.66 an hour, which is fairly cheap for a lot of games anyway.
In other words it is at a value that is worth buying.

Exactly what is this game? Wow, so this game... is best described as a meta game. It knows so much.without giving away any spoilers the game is an RPG with everything you'd come to expect in an RPG, stats items, dialog etc. what sets this apart is the dialog though and the mix in of bullet hell gameplay in the battle system, when you go to fight an enemy you'll be given a bar that you have to time properly to deal full damage, and when an enemy attacks you you have to dodge a unique bullet hell attack for each enemy, not only this but there are several different mechanics in the battle system that also get introduced, you'll know what these are by color eventually. And that's it as far as battles go.

As far as the story, the game has a very well thought out, well executed story, it's unique, it's lovable, it's something that truly stands out to be this is undertale's story". You start out the story as a human who falls into the monster underworld onto a bed of flowers

reviewText:
I have played a great many games in my time,

I survived the suicide mission in Mass Effect 2
I fought the Lord of Cinder in Dark Souls
I schemed my way into power in Crusader Kings II
I commanded great armies in Rome Total War
I built a lasting civilization in Civilization 5
I saved the world of ruin in Final Fantasy 6
I uncovered a conspiracy in Deus Ex
I endured the waste land in Fallout
I escaped Aperture in Portal
I starved in Don’t Starve
I lost a few good men in X-Com
I explored the heavenly bodies of space in Kerbal Space Program
I choose and obeyed in Bioshock
I travelled to faraway times in Chrono Trigger

Undertale kicked my ♥♥♥.

I played Undertale for all that I thought it was worth, but instead it played me for all I was worth.

10/10
They say to beware the man who speaks in hands. No. Beware the Fox that takes the form of a Dog.""

reviewText: It was... I don't remember what day it was. Thadeus had bought me a game he loved. Undertale it was called. For a while, I didn't really want to play it. I mean, the graphics seemed... not that impressive and all I knew about it was that it was influenced by Mother/Earthbound, which granted are some of my favourite RPG's, but for some reason, I held off on playing the game.\n\nI sat down one day, Thadeus eagerly sitting on Steam chat, awaiting my reaction. I fired up the game, commented how I could tell it was made in Game Maker, cause of the collision detection. Commented how I wish the music wouldn't constantly change styles. I kinda half-♥♥♥ played it, not really paying full attention. I met Flowey, he of course was creepy as all hell, letting me know it was kill or be killed". I killed some enemies. That's what you do in RPG's
date: right? I earned some EXP and felt pretty good. This character Toriel took me in
recommended: she seemed very nice. I liked her. In fact... I started to enjoy her company. Then I wanted to leave her place and move on. She blocked my way
hoursPlayed:
said she was going to test if I was ready.

Then I killed her.



Realizing what I'd done
voteText: realizing I had killed a character who was friendly
helpfulPercent: I panicked. What happened? In other games
votesHelpful: friendly NPC's wouldn't die if you fought them. They would stop
votesTotal: not let you kill them
votesFunny: something would keep it from happening. Yet here I sat
commentsCount: watching Toriel vaporize in front of me after the most blood chilling speech I've ever seen from someone friendly.\n\nI cried
column16: I felt rotten. I felt ashamed. I reloaded the game so I could get her back. The next fight the game told me I thought of letting Toriel know I watched her die
column17: and she said she felt like a ghost when I looked at her. Finally figuring out how to spare her I moved on. Then... Flowey appeared again. He let me know he was aware I had reloaded to try and save Toriel. I felt a chill down my spine unlike anything I've ever felt in any game. I knew it was possible for game characters to break the fourth wall but this felt like Flowey was speaking directly to me. Not the sprite on the screen
column18: but the player controlling the sprite. Instantly I felt like I couldn't play anymore. I was scared

reviewText:
Undertale is without a doubt one of the greatest games I have ever played.

It has humor, it has wit, it has references, and it has secrets. I'm also pretty sure it has a genre of its own. This game is the grand sum of a fantastic soundtrack, a unique battle system, and an absolutely incredible amount of attention to detail. Seriously.

Undertale is an experience like no other. If you're determined enough to complete it, I can assure you that it will be worth the price you paid. For the game, of course.

reviewText:
Undertale is a successfully Kickstarted game made mostly by a single person – Toby Fox. To specify the game’s genre, think of something like “creative bullet hell and comedy adventure with focus on decision making and emotional story“.

You might have already read or heard a lot of praise about Undertale, but I’ll rather start at the supposedly weakest point of the game, the graphics. Let’s be honest, they look poor even in compare to other pixelart game graphics. But as you’ll play more, you’ll realise they perfectly do their job, allowing all surprising changes and weirdness, that you’ll meet through the game, to shine.

In many other games, once you get to some sort of new gameplay feature or mini-game (e.g.: hacking in Fallout New Vegas or Deus Ex: Human Revolution, minigames in Bioshock), you’ll get to deal with them (or use them) repeatedly until they make you feel bored, for getting overused. (That also lowers your entertainment, making you more probably to rush through the specific game’s content.) Undertale is absolutely different, showing the developer’s hard work towards constant surprises for the player, with various gameplay features programmed just for specific scenes. Besides that fact, every NPC has a unique way of attacking; at least every type – but until you won’t want to kill everybody, you’ll mostly not meet each regular NPC more than twice.

I’ve seen few people play Undertale and I have to say that it’s not a game for everybody to like. I’ve seen people who just took this as another JRPG, rushing through the content, fighting just with everybody and talking with disappointment like “So, what’s so great about that?” afterwards. The main point is, the game favour people who want to think like “Wait, do I have to kill him/her/it?” with a reward of a lot of entertainment and fun. People who tend to think with more creativity will love this game. Even though the battle options are straightforward, there are more possible outcomes of fights besides killing the enemy. You mostly don’t have to fight, you can find a way to turn your enemies into friends.

To summarize the story without spoilers – Undertale is about monsters that have lost a war against humans on Earth. Monsters that survived ran deep into a cavern, where they got locked by a human magic. They somehow survived thanks to magic and technology, and thanks to their hope for better future; hope to see the Sun again.

Mt. Ebott is a weird place – people who had gone there went missing. And you take role of a kid who falls into the mountain, into the kingdom of monsters. And from this moment, everything else is under your control. It’s up to your decision what will happen with everybody. The game has, besides some small differences, three big endings, each with absolutely different outcome.

I’m not a type of person who would usually replay games ( because of my Steam game backlog) but after finishing Undertale for the first time in about 6 hours, I had to take another try for different ending... and wow. You’ll eventually find a lot more information about the characters and monsters’ history. You’ll also realise many things that together shows you the depth of the story. What may surprise you is also the fact that the game knows pretty well if you are replaying the game for another time, characters have slightly different dialogues... but I’ll not spoil more of it, let’s just say that it’s totally expected from you to play Undertale multiple times for complete experience.

While Undertale really has an emotional story, as many reviews full of tears may tell you, don’t forget that sadness is not the only emotion. The game will also try to stimulate your happiness – not just in a way of making yourself happy for not killing your favourite character, but also by humour. There’s a joke, gag or a pop culture reference (often tailored for “Internet people”) around every corner, probably even in every character. You’ll see.

The final thing that gets the praise is the Toby Fox’s iconic soundtrack. Undertale has a perfect soundtrack, mostly composited from chiptunes. There are so many great melodies that will get stuck into your head and you’ll love them. An interesting fact, most of the game music was made before designing and programming of specific scenes they was made for – Toby Fox said that it helped him to decide how the scene should go. (Source[existentialgamer.com])

Conclusion:Undertale is something so unique and unexpectedly awesome, that it deserves praise without objection. It’ll make you laugh, cry, or just keeps you entertained from 6 to ~25 hours (depends on if you decide to replay the game for different endings; hint: you should).


For more reviews, join Samurai Vader's Point of View group and follow my curator page, I'm always happy to see feedback about my reviews.

reviewText:
I don't like RPGs.
With that in mind, Undertale is one of the best games I've ever played.
If not Metal Gear Solid 5, this is easily my Game Of The Year.

Often, if someone doesn't enjoy a type of game I enjoy, I can shrug it off as a matter of taste, which is completely fine. Except when it isn't. Undertale is something that deserves to be played by as many people as possible.

It's funny and lighthearted, incredibly fun to play (yes, even down to the random enemy encounters which become more of an enjoyable puzzle than a chore as you try to work out how to deal with them without violence), and incredibly heartwarming. Sometimes, certain things make me incredibly sad that I can't wipe" my own memory of something and experience it for the first time again. I wish I could do so with Undertale.

There's minute bits of detail to be found in many places
date: and it seems that there's no possibility that hasn't been thought of. Fail to realise you can spare the first boss and reset to try again out of guilt? It knows.\n\nThe soundtrack is nothing short of exceptional. Just listening to the epilogue theme brings me to tears
recommended:
something no other musical piece in a game has ever accomplished.

You owe it to yourself to play Undertale. You will not be disappointed.

reviewText:
My wording feels off at the time I'm typing this so I'll probably redo this.
After four playthroughs and all three routes done, I can finally review this game.

If you've been on the internet at all the past couple of months you've heard of Undertale and its praise, aswell as its comparions to other RPGs such as Earthbound, which I have yet to play. Now, I can't say anything about the comparisons, but Undertale fully deserves the praise it has gotten. While not the best game I've ever played, it's surely up there.

Pros:
+ The gameplay is unique and never gets boring. despite the fight scenes getting repetitive they manage to be different each time.
+ The soundtrack is AMAZING. Many of the themes are remixed versions of each other, for example: CORE and Death by Glamour. Many songs tell a lot about the situation and character, such as Heartache and ASGORE.
+ The jokes are great. Some would say otherwise, but it really depends on your sense of humor.
+ Everything you do matters. Your choices change the ending and the game remembers everything you do.
+ A well written storyline with multiple paths. The game doesn't try to force you to feel anything, it actually makes you feel. Many other games try way too hard to evoke emotion. PRESS F TO PAY RESPECTS"
+ The characters are amazing. They all have unique personalities and dialogue. The sprites
recommended: are well made. All the main NPCs are extremely memorable
hoursPlayed:
one example being Papyrus.
+ The controls are simple and tight.
+ Really good and rewarding boss fights. The Neutral and No Mercy final bosses are some of my favorites. Do not search them up to avoid spoilers.

Cons:
- The player character's design clashes with the artstyle A LOT. I get that Toby wanted to make them gender ambigious

reviewText:
I think it's a testament to Undertale's excellence that, despite my exposure to the embarassing cosplays, horrible (and at times pandering) fanart, bizarre Rule 63 alternate universe shippings, and an obsessed community that only Tumblr and anonymous image boards could create, it still managed to blow me away and leave me suprised.

Every facet of Undertale is pouring at the seams with tender care; the memorable characters, the wacky encounters, it's unpredictable gameplay and the layered soundtrack that fits perfectly with every situation. Believe it or not, this game never feels like it was made to pander; instead, it feels like it exists as a labor of love, a tribute to what makes video games in general great. Because of this, it's very easy to distance what the game actually is from whatever the heck some parts of the fanbase want it to be.

It does truly upset me that many people are so disgusted by the rabid fanbase that they're turned off from playing Undertale, but this game has a massive following for a very good reason - I myself feel horrible I waited so long to experience it. It's that very rare kind of game that EVERYONE should experience at least once.

reviewText:
This game has made me fall in love with a robot



This game has ruined me more than any other game. Every single character is deep and complex. No matter what route you take in this game, you're a monster. The game never lets you forget that. With the multitude of gameplay paths, secrets and secret bosses, this game keeps you invested both emotionally and mentally as you try to figure out what is happening to you and those around you. This is a game you will love and hate because it shows you who you really are. Everything that can and will happen is your fault.

reviewText:
Love is the strongest emotion of them all"
That was my thoughts throughout playing undertale. Honestly it was a fantastic experience that shows a different side of the regular RPG genre. It is filled with so much emotion and weirdness! Undertale is on the way to becoming my personal GOTY! Undertale is a difficult game to review due to it's very different nature but i'm going to try my best.

To realize why undertale is so great you first have to understand it's combat system. As the game advertises you don't actually have to kill anyone in the game. You have 2 options
date: to fight or to take other action. Other actions are related to the enemy you are up against. Your task is too discover what the enemy likes as too make them surrender to fighting you. It's more difficult then you might think. It takes a certain degree of skill to figure out how best to act to either make the enemy feel sorry for you
hoursPlayed:
want to be your friend or a whole host of different outcomes.

But if you don't want to follow this new tactic then you still have the option of full on combat. Between attacks you will need to defend enemies attacks. This takes part in a kinda bullet hell style way. You control a small heart and have to avoid enemy bullets. Bullets are shot in a huge range of different patterns or styles that are unique to the enemy. I really enjoyed this defensive stystem. It is still integrated even if you opt to not attack enemies so you won't see yourself getting bored.

Seems i'm going off track a bit here. I was explaing the way to attack. Anyway you attack through a kind of rhythm system. The closer to the centre you click the bar the more damage you will do. Throughout the game you will pick up different weapons that alter this combat slightly. They give you different patterns that are more difficult to use. This spices up the combat a bit. Combat isn't particularly intuitive or full of variety but it was good enough to enjoy.

The other thing that makes undertale stand out above other games is the story. It is hard to go into too much details without spoiling it. But the story is full of twists and turns
voteText:
love and hatred. There are so many characters that each have the most unique of personaliltys and feelings towards each of the other characters. Character development builds up amazingly and you really get to know each character. This is where I also get to my point about love. It makes it much easier to show compasion for enemies in combat that you actually who they are.

So I said earlier you have an option of killing enemies or sparing them. But does this really make a difference? The answer is a big yes! Undertale has multiple different endings. They all count on what choices you made in the world. So there is a so called "pacifist" ending for if you don't kill anyone or an opposite ending for killing everyone as well as others. I have currently experienced two of these. They are each so different to each other and it is well worth going back to play again to get each and every ending. The only issue I would state is that you have go through about 4 hours worth of gameplay that is almost identical to get to it which can be a bit boring.

A single playthrough is roughly 6 hours. I would say that is a reasonable length considering that you can replay it so many times!

Restarting even affects the world. The world will be different depending on what choices you made in your last playthrough. Characters will remember some things and parts of the world may be slightly different. It's not a big deal but it does add a little bit to the gameplay.

The graphics is something that probably wouldn't appeal to everyone. I personally love them though. I always fall for pixelated graphics when they are done well. And undertale definitely does it well. There is so much detail in the characters and areas of the world. It really does stand out.

The soundtrack is absoluetly outstanded as well. There is so much emotion in each of the tracks. Immediately after finishing the 2nd playthrough I went onto youtube to listen to the soundtrack again. It's that good!

There are a few other small details that put me off slightly from the game though. Most aren't a big deal but they are worth mentioning.

The first being an issue with the soundtrack. Wheras most areas of the world have a soundtrack playing in the background there are some areas that are missing a soundtrack. This just makes them feel bland and boring to explore.

The game suffers from blackboxing. There are black bars on the left and right so it is never true full screen. On top of this the game has a 30fps lock to it. Since it's a 2D game it's not too big of a deal but some people may care.

That was it for the issues I had with it. Undertale is a fantastic game that adds a lot of variety to the classic RPG games and has a brillant engaging story to go with the unique gameplay. For the amount of replayability you can get out of it £6.99 is an absolute steal for such a good game. I will definitely be going back for another playthrough to get yet another ending out of it. I would recommend it to anyone that loves a good story in a game or just wants to spice up their gameplay a bit.

TheIronicGamers rating system
Don't ever buy this game.
Maybe consider it on a sale.
An average game.
A good game that should definitely be considered.
A must play!
Disclaimer: I was provided a free key by the developer to make this review."

reviewText:
This game is just so beyond powerful in every single way. It doesn't look like much on the surface, but as you get into it, you really become attached to the characters. All of them just feel so real and it really hurts to see them going through any sort of pain.

After taking the pacifist route, there isn't enough money in the world to convince me to go on the genocide route.

This game is amazingly fun with it's unique bullet-hell approach to typical RPG battles. The music is spot on and will bring out more emotions in you than you thought you had. And that ending....I won't spoil it for anyone, but I've never played a game where I had to fight through tears during the last boss battle.

Who would've thought having tears in your eyes makes dodging things harder?

10/10 please get this game.

reviewText:
This has to have been the best game I have, and will ever play on steam.

There is only one thing that I don't like about this game, and that is the main character sprite. Curse you, Toby Fox.


In all seriousness, I can't convey to you how incredibly amazing this game was. It brought me to tears, filled me with happiness, and left me thinking about the way I treat people and life itself. It's not just a game, it's a work of art. I have only just finished my first run, but I have already begun to prepare for my second run, and plan to buy the soundtrack. I am downloading my favorite themes from this game now (of which there are more than 5) and they will go in my music playlist, filled with only the very best music of all time.



I can't put my feelings accurately into words without being incredibly verbose or too lengthy, so I will stop here. Please, buy this game. Please do it.

reviewText:
Undertale is a roleplaying game developed by Toby Fox, releasing on Steam in September 2015.

You play Undertale from a top down perspective, as you control a child. You navigate through “Underground”. Scattered around the Underground, you will encounter plenty of different enemies. The “combat” system in Undertale is where this game will differ from other RPG games of this type. First of all, the regular attacking in combat is done via a QTE sort of mechanic as you have to hit the action button in the right spot to do more damage. This adds a skill level to the combat rather than just relying on stats and equipment. Secondly, the other options when in a fight are much more diverse, such as sparing an enemy, which means letting them live, or you can simply talk to the enemy, whether it be flirting with them, joking, or complimenting them. Each way of interacting with the enemy will result in a different outcome at the end of the fight.  When the enemy attacks you though, you have to again take part in a small mini game, which usually requires you to dodge out of the way of certain objects which are flying at your LV (your love…the game will explain at the beginning). I am not normally a fan of QTEs but Undertale does a good job of masking the mechanic by portraying it in an original way.

Visually, this game is by no means a good looking game. It’s the basic of basics of 8 bit graphics. If you grew up playing games with these sorts of graphics, I can probably see you getting a huge nostalgia hit, but if you missed that era, and then you will probably not fully enjoy the art style. Personally I didn’t like it at all. It is way too basic and minimalistic for me. I need something more pleasing to look at. The sound track of this game is brilliant though, composed by the developer himself, there is some absolutely awesome tracks to be heard throughout the game. If you are the sort of person that really appreciates video game music, I would recommend you pick up the Soundtrack for sure!

Where most people will say Undertale succeeds brilliantly, is the story. I am not going to go into any spoilers at all as I know it is a touchy subject, but you meet some very original characters, some quirky and hilarious as you progress through the game.  The way your story pans out will be determined by your actions throughout the game.  Undertale has three different endings. It’s nice to see a game where your choices really do have a lot of weight behind them, as we have come all too familiar with games giving us the illusion that our choices matter, when in fact we just end up in the same place at the end anyway.

I wouldn’t say Undertale is a hugely difficult game. The puzzles are easy enough once you take a step back and think it through clearly. If you are fighting enemies, the combat is fairly easy too; you just have to be good at QTEs to be able to progress without any real problems.  Completing one of the endings took me just over three hours. I am not sure whether I feel like I want to go into Undertale again to see the other endings, because the game is fairly slow paced and I am really not a fan of the art style and graphics. I think I would be more tempted to way a play through on YouTube of the other endings as I would only be doing it for the story element. Obviously if you are a fan of the gameplay you can probably get about ten hours of content from Undertale.

Sadly, as surprisingly as it sounds, I had technical problems with Undertale – and I wasn’t the only one. The game simply wouldn’t launch. This was fixed using the following Steam community post - https://steamcommunity.com/app/391540/discussions/0/496879865892998743/#p3 The game can be played using either keyboard or controller. I would personally favour the controller though, given the QTEs and simple controls other than those.

To sum up, I’m not going to say Undertale is a must play game like most people. Yes I can see why people see it as being earth shatteringly good, but I really don’t see what all the fuss is about. The game play is slow paced and bland and graphically it is just awful.  What you are getting with Undertale is a fantastic sound track, and hugely original plot. I can quite happily say I could have got the same experience out of Undertale from just watching a play through online. Credit where credit is due though, the story is really good and it is probably Undertale’s biggest selling point. The game has a good price point at £6,99 so even if you are on the fence, it’s not like you are going to break the bank with trying it out.

Tom's Score Card
1) Stay away
2) Not Recommended
3) Only recommended when on sale
4) Recommended
5) Highly recommended
6) This is a must play

If you found this review helpful, please give it a thumbs up. If you would also like to follow my reviews more easily, be sure to join my group by clicking here.

You may also be interested in checking out a PC gaming podcast, be sure to head here.

http://store.steampowered.com/app/391540/

reviewText:
In my opinion, the PC Master Race isn't about the hardware at all.

It isn't about screens having a faster refresh rate than your retina.
It isn't about multicolor keyboards flashing as if they were totally high.
It isn't about super-duper accurate cyborg computer mice.
It isn't about perfectly silent fans and glowing water cooling systems.
It isn't about GPU's and CPU's with numbers beginning with a 9 and ending with an upper-case consomnant.
It isn't about state-of-the-art hardware powering nice games.

It is about top notch devs and games taking advantage of our computers' hardware, of the communities we are part of, of the accessibility of the platform, and of how widespread it is.
But most importantly, it is about us playing these games, especially those which, thanks to the features I've spoken about, succeed into creating new experiences that could not have been crafted elsewhere.

Among these games is Undertale. And if you claim to be worth of owning a pc, you should rather buy it right now.

10/10

reviewText:
A clever iconoclastic romp of a JRGP. The combat in particular (which I find the main roadblock in enjoying this tired genre) is made quite entertaining by the unique way of defeating your opposition and the game is short and varied enough that it doesn't get tedious or repetitive before you reach a nice climactic finish.

GOTY material? Maybe just for the sheer panache of the dev in delivering a surprising and endearing tale of the power of friendship and all that MLP communal hippy crap we love to extol but not practice in practice.

The sweet OST also don't hurt it any.

reviewText:
Let's compare the two biggest game fanbases that are currently blowing up this decade.

Five Nights at Freddy's and Undertale

Toby Fox actually made a game.

**EDIT**
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------

But in all seriousness with jokes aside, I would like to make a legitimate review for Undertale.
In general, this game is damn well amazing and an emotional rollercoaster. Undertale is full of characters you grow to love and keep near and dear to your heart. The people you meet all have a factor to keep the game (or characters) intruiging. The game definitely has replay value, along with full over overwhelming challenges. Now, since my personal opinions are set aside, I have carefully planned out a pros and cons list for this game in particular.

Pros- Amazing soundtrack
- Challenging
- Great gameplay in general
- Killing is not mandatory
- Very active, responsive, and positive community
- Moddable to keep the game interesting
- Cool merchandise!
- Great art

Cons- Short
- The feels can hurt, emotionally

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
The pros category won by a longshot. I highly, HIGHLY recommend you play this game. You're missing out on a lot.

reviewText:
Honestly. Undertale is not a conventional game. And SHOULD NOT be COMPARED with any other.
SO STOP. Don't go for Undertale expecting some light, soft, uncompromising experience.
DON'T EXPECT TO EVEN LIKE IT before you played a lot and are trully open to understand its experience.


OVERALL:
+ Music is phenomenal
+ Combat is addictive (yet simple as f*ck)
+ Characters show a humanity that just seems to be forgotten nowadays
+ The story has so many hidden layers that caught me completely by surprise.
+ The graphics actually help you disconect from the conventional and look more deeply into the story.

- You walk..... kinda..... slow
- To understand the full circle, you might have to google some stuff if you are not into digging every corner for hidden secrets.


PERSONAL THOUGHTS:
It is different, it is unique. And you better have your HEART AND SOUL PREPARED for something that goes beyond conventional, and asks for you to look at things differently.

It takes WAY MORE than 1 simple playthrough for you to scratch the idea that it is beneath Undertale's superficial story.

The whole game is very storytelling centered, even the combat, but yet it is simple and challenging in its own right.

I cannot recommed this game to anyone but at the same time, I want to recommend to EVERYONE.

As a game, has its flaws, but as a different and heartfelt experience, it is unmatched.

If the description made you curious or you feel open enough to try something new, give it a try :)


RANDOM:
By the way, you might just not be playing this game in a time of your life that leaves you very open to try new stuff with fresh eyes. So don't push it. Come back in another time ;)

I only really fell for this game after 2 playthroughts + pacifist + watched genocide with Dodger (nop, I dont have the guts yet lol).

So I don't blame you for not liking it even after playing, Undertale doesn't make the job easy lol

reviewText:
Remember when you were a kid, and you would play RPGs and get this feeling like you actually went on an adventure?

That's what Undertale is.  It encapsulates and maximizes everything that made Earthbound good, that made Chrono Trigger and Final Fantasy 6 good, and it wraps all of that in wonderful, memorable music.  The music is easily above the tier of all the really great SNES RPGs, even matching or exceeding the later Final Fantasy's in how fitting every piece is.

It's hard to describe the game in words, especially without spoiling anything. To get a true idea of what it is, play the demo; the demo is the first part of the game, and will give you the perfect idea of whether or not you want more.

If you finish this game, it's something that's going to stay with you.  It really is an experience.

reviewText: Let's not pretend that this game is not a phenomena. Like it or hate it, there's no disputing that this game is probably one of the biggest indie releases to date, regarding sales and sheer popularity. Basically anyone with a Steam account, or socail media, or anyone that uses the internet in general, has heard of this game. So, with this review, I'm not going to pretend that most people out there have not heard of this game and are completely clueless to it. Everyone talks about this game to a near obnoxious level, so the goal of my review is to try and convince anyone out there that's scepticle, that's completely uninterested because of how annoyed they are about hearing about it, that's completely turned off by the game and turn away from it simply because Tumblr has jumped straight into its trash chute. Because here's the thing. The worst thing about this game is its popularity. So again, my goal with this review is to not recommend, but IMPLORE that you listen and take my words into consideration. Because despite how much flack this game has gotten (when you forget about the immense praise it actually gets), this game is worth it. It deserves to be remembered, and I fully believe it can stand the test of time.\n\nSo with all of that established and out of the way, here's where I answer the main question. 'What is so great about Undertale?'. Well, a lot of things when you look at it all from a technical level. The story is very well thought out, written, and paced, the characters are all memorable (and despite a lot of opinions, very multi-dementional. It's called subtlty, people, these characters are tropey" because that's only their outward appearance.) The music is fantastic

reviewText:
if my playtime seems low, dont be fooled, as someone who helped test the final version of the game ive easily put in over 20 hours in this game so far from due to replaying it so much.

undertale is a game that is truly unique and truly special. to miss it would be a grave error. this is the only game ive ever played where the characters truly feel real and one where ive honestly ruminated on my decisions.

it is easily in the realm of my favorite games of all time, and it is certainly the most special and unique game ive ever played. please consider it, or at the very least trying out the demo.

reviewText:
Undertale; My Game of the Year and maybe even the best game I've ever played!
At the time of writing I've put around fifteen hours into the game. I've completed a full pacifist run and am currently busy with finishing up the genocide run. I'm also listening to the game's soundtrack as I'm writing this (yes the soundtrack is THAT good!)

Introduction
Undertale is a RPG game with a unique combat system. As the game advertises Killing is unnecessary: negotiate out of danger using the unique battle system." this is something that I've never seen before in any RPG I've played. The player is basically allowed to either spare or kill the opponent and choosing what you'll do will greatly change the outcome of the game's story.

When it comes to defending against monster attacks there isn't a simple 'Defend' button or action the player can choose during a turn. To defend against incoming attacks
date: the player has to dodge 'bullets' just like a Touhou game
recommended:
the way you defend against monsters also changes throughout the game. Especially during bossfights you'll encounter different ways to dodge the bullets.

Story
Oh boy are you in for a treat. This game has one of the most unique and compelling stories I've seen in a 'simple' 2D RPG. I won't spoil too much about it since I greatly recommend you go into the game as fresh as you can. Don't look up any spoilers
hoursPlayed: don't follow guides. Enjoy this experience on your own!\n\nWhen it comes down to the story
voteText: you'll cry. You will cry a lot. The game plays with your emotions. It will twist and turn your view on what is right and what is wrong and why you do certain actions in a video game. (Like
helpfulPercent: why do you kill everything in your path while you're playing Final Fantasy?)\n\nIn short
votesHelpful: the story is about a world where humans and monsters used to live together happily. A war broke out and the monsters fled to the underground. One day you
votesTotal: the player
votesFunny:
falls down a hole where you wake up in the underground or 'Home' where the player will encounter different monsters. Everybody despises humans due to the past and your job is to make your way back to the surface!

Characters
This game has a set of incredibly memorable characters. Every character in the game has a different kind of font in the text boxes
commentsCount: putting an emphasis on the variation between characters. There's silly characters
column16: serious characters
column17: incredibly complex characters and a very
column18: very motherly character.\n\nEach of the characters have an interesting background story (if you dig deep into the game's story
column19: that is) that you'll love to find out! Each character has a different appeareance
column20:
there's no copy-pasting as far as I'm aware.

Combat
As I've mentioned before
column21: the game's combat is very unique in a sense that you either have to attack or act. Attacking basically requires you to time your button press right. A line will go from left to right and your job is to hit the center of the screen as precisely as possible. Once you do so your attack will be at full power and you'll land a pretty hard blow.\n\nThe uniqueness of the combat system
column22: however. Is when you act. Acting is basically choosing between different kinds of dialogue. Once you encounter a monster and you act
column23: you'll have different options. The options differ from hugging
column24: to picking on somebody to petting. Depending on what you choose you'll calm your opponent down and you can spare them. This won't give you EXP
column25:
but it will give you gold.

Atmosphere
The game's atmosphere in general is pretty joyful
column26: the music makes the game feel like a good-feel 80's RPG (I'm looking at you
column27: Earthbound.)\n\nHowever
column28: the atmosphere changes drastically when you decide to kill everybody. Towns become deserted
column29: people will be afraid of you
column30: dialogue changes significantly
column31:
etc. It becomes incredibly gritty and the music changes to a pretty horror-esque version of the original happy good-feel soundtrack.

Bossfights
This game has some amazing bossfights
column32: every single one of them has a different kind of attack pattern which will be different every single time a new attack comes up. They don't vary per encounter
column33: however. So if you're stuck at a certain boss
column34:
you'll be able to remember the pattern and repeat the process until you've finally defeated them!

Music
This game has one of the greatest soundtracks ever. Like
column35: you know when you're fighting a final boss in a game. The music just kicks in and it pumps you up so much you just want to end it? You just need to get rid of them and save the world? Yeah
column36:
the game's soundtrack will do this to you. It will make you DETERMINED to win!

In short
This game is one of the most enjoyable games I've ever played. No

column42:
fun atmosphere and in-depth story make this game a unique experience you won't forget. It'll stick with you for a long time and it'll be very memorable.

Pros
Great soundtrack

Unique and lovable characters

Amazing story

Great replay value if you want to find out all of the story behind the game

Very unique combat system and bosses
Cons
Touhou dodging can be a bit clunky due to 8-axis restriction of Game Maker

You will cry

lots.

10/10"

reviewText:
Edited after true eding ***
In a nutshell, Undertale is one of those games I went in, trying my best to be cynical and proffesional about it and ended up devouring me. Incredibly good and enjoyable despite frustrations

+Absolutely creative. The game seems to never run out of ideas.
+Extremely stupid(ly good) writing. Its simple enough for anyone to enjoy but mature when it has to be
+Choices matter! Holy ♥♥♥♥, finally!
+Lore is deep and well crafted.
+Characters have a personality! Havent seen that in a while , I missed games with charisma
+Unique fight system that encourages you to think instead of just attacking. Each fight is a puzzle
+The themes and overall message changes on your actions, making each player feel specialy involved
+Despite bosses are somewhat harsh, you pretty much are deeply invested into winning. That is hard to achive, and Undertale manages to suck you in for that.
+ The unique fight system ( attack or pacify) adds a layer of possibility for those who want a challange of emotion
+The true ending is , by no doubts, one of the best ive seen

+/- Might be that im a guy who studied humor for years as a cartoonist, but the comedy in Undertale is allright, but falls into a childish category. Puns galore, slapstick and some rather weak lines. There so bad they're good - that kind of mediocre. Maybe thats the point. Still made me chuckle in joy, but I can see many disliking it
-/+ THE BOSSES. Holy moly they are a challanging in a bad way. (as stated before, it can be dimished by the investment in the story, but beating them the first time is a grindfest of trial and error)
-/+ The unique fight system ( attack or pacify) is flawed, as it can make you waste time doing an action for no results , spending long periods in unnessesary long encounters.

-The fanbase. No, seriously. Avoid Tumblr like the plauge. It can deeply harm your vision of the game . ♥♥♥♥ing hell, avoid TUMBLR because its Damn Tumblr!

9 outta 10. You have to give this game the chance if story-choice driven game are your thing.
voteText: 33 of 38 people (87%) found this review helpful 6 people found this review funny

reviewText:
For the people out there that think video games cant effect you emotionally...that they cant be art. One word...Undertale...

Ive never had a game get to me like this in a long time. Or...ever really now that I think about it. This game is short yes, but I think people need to experience at least once in there life. I have never seen a story this fleshed out, characters this genuine and endearing. Mechanics that are simple but insanely impactful.

If the games tagline doesn't say it all, the idea of this game is its a RPG where no one has to die. In almost every fight you will have the option to talk your way out of conflict, be it by saying the right things, meeting certain conditions or just enduring until the enemy tires so you can SPARE them. Honestly think of it like a normal RPG, just instead of feeling out elemental weaknesses or resistances your trying to find out if you should laugh at the monsters bad joke or scold him for it. for about 99% of the game you will never EVER need to use the FIGHT command in your battle menu. This goes for bosses too, who are ALL lovable and memorable. They can even become your friends and you can get to know then better. That said...violence is still an option at all times and it will honestly tempt you, because with violence comes power. Letting enemies live will get you no XP or levels, playing a pacifist means you will ALWAYS be Level 1 from the beginning to the end. But playing what people call a Genocide Run results in a DRASTICALLY different experience, its not for the faint of heart.

So in the end the choice is yours will you slay or spare your enemies? Will you make friends or make corpses. The choice is yours, make sure you don't regret it.
voteText: 36 of 43 people (84%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This is one of the best video games I've ever played. If you're a MOTHER / EarthBound fan, play this without hesitation. I hate to make a direct comparison with that series, but UNDERTALE absolutely shares much of its quirkly style.

The writing is great (right down to implementing subtle pauses in text lines... just like MOTHER 3), the comedic timing and story is masterful, the soundtrack is amazing (guess what: it contains sound samples / instruments from EarthBound), and while I do wish the graphics could have a bit of a nicer touch, they are alright and consistent.

I know a lot of people say 11/10" as a joke on the Internet but I deeply mean it from the bottom of my heart and my soul: this is a 11/10 game. You have to play this."

reviewText:
I've finished twice, am watching several friends and my brother play through it, and still can't stop thinking about this game. Apparently, this is a common side effect for players of Undertale. Trust me, for $10 USD, you'll be sentencing yourself to what I daringly consider the best RPG experience I've ever seen. Having been an RPG fanatic my entire life, I don't say this lightly, and it was so important to me that I express my feelings for Toby Fox's masterpiece. So, here we go!



GRAPHICS - Don't judge the game by what you see in the trailer
Let's forget about graphical standards for a moment, because seriously, that shouldn't have been a selling point to any game in the first place. Undertale uses an incredibly simplistic art style to paint a deep and atmospheric world that would perhaps be difficult to digest otherwise. The battle screens feature exclusive monochromatic full body sprites of your enemies". I had to mention these specifically because they just look gorgeous. In fact
date: they become progressively more so. Limbs and smaller features become animated
recommended: and everybody becomes larger and more cleverly designed on this black-and-white canvas. It honestly felt like graphically

GAMEPLAY - There is no RPG experience out there like this one
Fans of the Earthbound/Mother series will feel right at home with Undertale in that its gameplay elements are heavily inspired by the cult classic series. It features a standard
