reviewText: When the credits ended, I stared at the screen for the longest time. I stared so long a dog appeared and just stood under the title. You know, that cute fluffy white one? Then I stared even longer. The dog fell asleep. I managed to keep up my staring for a decent ten minutes after that but nothing else happened. I begrudgingly closed the window. I never played a videogame before that reminded me of how it's better to love and forgive than it is to hate and murder. That's the stuff they teach you kindergarten, but mostly because they don't want all of you arguing over the only box of crayons or the last gummy bear in the jar. This game means so much more. I'm an adult now and I've been struggling with a lot of the themes presented within this work. It was so relevant and so beautifully articulated, I didn't have the heart to do what many of peers are pushing me to do: a Genocide Run. I guess I'm not the hard-hearted person I once thought. I can't even bring myself to kill fictional characters (although I did accidentally kill Toriel on my first try and ended up resetting right away. I felt horrible!), much less hate them. I look at my current life now. There's only one person I truly despise, but this game has shifted my perspective. The anger has turned to pity. This game is the best therapy I've ever had (not that I've been to actual therapy). It's true when they say love when you can. Because we all have such a short time here, whether it's up on the surface or down below. Everyone deserves love and mercy. Sorry for getting so sappy. *cough*

reviewText:
Undertale is a game that has an incredible amount of love and care put into making it.  It's the kind of game that immediately teaches you to approach it in unusual and creative ways, as pretty much every battle and character interaction is, in itself, a sort of puzzle.  There's so much incidental dialogue; if you're the sort of person who enjoys repeatedly talking to every NPC in an RPG to see every last line they say at every point in the story, you'll be delighted with how much of that is in Undertale.  The writing strikes a really good balance of genuine emotion and humor.  I've probably laughed more at this game's jokes than almost any other game I've played.

I've always been a big fan of Toby's music, and this game's soundtrack doesn't disappoint at all.  So many of the tracks are instantly catchy and specific tailored to the mood of the scene, with some tracks feeling very sentimental and nostalgic.  I've been looping the soundtrack for awhile now.

Every single part of this game feels so deliberate and carefully put together.  Not a single part of it feels like a throwaway, like, you can tell that every interactible object had some amount of thought put into its description.  You don't really see It's a door.  It's a trash can.  It's a window.  There's nothing special here." repeated ad nauseum.  Rather
date: checking out every single object in every room is part of the game's character.  Even that cactus in the bedroom feels like it has a personality.\n\nI really like this game.  I think you will too."

reviewText:
Undertale. A game made by the developer of Earthbound Halloween Hack and one of the music writers of the webcomic series of Homestuck. is one of the best RPGs i have ever played. The basic premise is you have control over who lives and dies! You can play through the entire game without killing a single creature or go onto a mass genocide and wipe out anyone that opposes you. The story is too good to ruin with a review and as such i refuse to do so.

This game has multiple endings depending on who is killed, who is saved, and who you befriend however there is three major endings to the game. The Pacifist ending (where you kill nothing and befriend all possible people.) The neutral (where you do anything you wish. saving who you want and killing who you want.) and the Genocide ending which well.. is kinda obvious.

I have only gone through the game twice. (once for my first blind run through pacifist. and the other because someone i care about finds the system a bit too overwhelming as its a bit too bullet helly for them.) and i already have 28 hours on my record. For an $11 CAD game. you really can't go wrong with this.

I recommend that if you do play this game. Expect passionate feelings from this game. I feel that this game definately has the developers heart" and "soul" melded into it and his passion quickly filled me with the passion to enjoy and love this game.

I am however intensely surprised that gamemaker of all programs was used to make this game! I seriously never knew it had the power to do it. But this game shows just how well it can really make games!

I say if you have a few dollars laying around and are looking for an engaging and funny while still heart string plucking RPG then grab this game immediately. You will not be disappointed!"

reviewText:
What can I say about Undertale? Quite a lot, actually, and most of it regarding this game with praise. This JRPG is a wonderful mix of humor and seriousness that is absolutely oozing with story. All of the characters in this game are so loveable, you'll have a hard time even hating the bad guys. The story and lore is a welcome for both the casual and hardcore players alike, each new playthrough having you learn new things each time. Combat on this isn't all that bad either, making a fun combination of bullet-hells and turn-based fighting.

Pros:
+ Various colorful characters that are well written and have their own personality
+ A story that unravels the more you play it and discover new things
+ It has choice and consequences that actually matter, where the endings have major differences depending on how you chose to play
+ You can kill everything if you want to, but you could alternatively win the day by being nice to everything you come across
+ Plenty of hidden mechanics and features that could affect the story in smaller scales
+ Turn-based combat that is still engaging and keeps you on your toes
+ Absolutely amazing soundtrack

Cons:
- Some jokes can be dragged out for too long
- One or two battles seem needlessly tacked on for padding

I will try my best not to reveal any major spoilers, but be prepared in case something slips.

The game opens with an intro cinematic of still images, describing an ancient time when humans and monsters lived together. For unknown reasons, a war breaks between the two races. The monsters are easily defeated by the humans, who prove to be far stronger, and are sealed away in a vast underground cave underneath a mountain. Later, after an unknown lapse of time, a child of ambiguous gender literally stumbles onto the entry. From that point on, you're given the option to choose a name and begin your adventure to find a way out.

The first monster you come across is deceitfully friendly and teaches you the basics of combat and survival. After the brief meeting, you find the second monster who guides you on how to solve some of the puzzles you will come across throughout the game as well as suggesting ways to deal with other monsters without using violence. The guide abandons you afterwards, leaving you to explore your new environment on your own. This whole zone is just a tutorial that teaches you how the game works and lets you explore ways to fight monsters. And despite the brief time you get to spend with the guide, you will feel the most emotional impact from them near the end of it.

And that's what you'll be experiencing with every other major character you come across on your adventure. Each of them have their own traits and personality that makes them stand out from one another, and all of them is sure to make you attached to them in some degree. Even the monsters who are supposed to be your enemy have personalities that make it hard for you to hate them without wanting to know them better, first. And all of these characters can be murdered if you so desire, but remember that their blood is on your hands if you've befriended them in an older playthrough.

And it's here that the game throws its most interesting feature at you: Characters remark that you look familiar, by recollecting events from previous saves. If you murder someone then reload, you might look like you've seen a ghost. If a character murders you, you might be able to tell them they've killed you. And they'll slightly remember you even if you reset the game and start from scratch!

This game focuses on choice and consequences which mostly impacts how the game will end. Will you be a kind and merciful child, becoming a beacon of hope and prove to the monsters that not all humans are bad, or will you be a heartless killer, destroying hopes and lives of all things that cross your path? You can also be both, simply wishing to get yourself back to the surface. For good or bad, the game will remember what you did and will choose what your ending will be.

Prepare to go on a feels trip, because you're going to experience a lot of tear-wrenching plot and character development.

If you're someone who loved the story and want to know more about the important monsters, the first playthrough is going to be nowhere near satisfactory enough for you. A big thing the developers have done was leave a lot of questions unanswered, whether by accident or on purpose to encourage the players to intepret them on their own. For instance, I started the game with a desire to simply escape the underground and go back to my life on the surface. After roughly two to three playthroughs on merciful runs, I'm now writing a hypothesis on who the player character really is. Yes, this game leaves a lot of loose ends for you to tie!

Combat was creatively done. Instead of the typical JRPG turn-based combat of hitting each other until one of you dies, it's instead a mix of timing and bullet-hell dodging. If you're aiming to kill, you're given a colorful bar where you have to try and get 1+ tick(s) to hit the center for maximum damage. Different weapons have different effects on top of that, such as a pair of gloves that let you punch several times at once by mashing the key to cause even more damage. Even if you're not trying to hurt anyone, there's still the bullets and obstacles the enemies throw at you in retaliation which you have to dodge.

Finally, the music was very well done. After playing a game a few times, I typically start to turn the music off, because of how repetitive it's getting. In the case of Undertale, not only can I not turn the music off even if I wanted to, I find myself trying to replay a few of the really good tracks in my head when I'm not playing it!

So the ultimate question remains: Is this game worth $10? Factoring out the cons I listed near the beginning, the story and hidden lore will leave you coming back time and again searching for answers to questions you came up with while playing. You will get more than your money's worth.

reviewText:
UNDERTALE! The RPG game where you don't have to destroy anyone.
Tags: Great Soundtrack, Story Rich, Choices Matter, Funny, RPG, Bullet Hell, Multiple Endings, Indie, Singleplayer, Pixel Graphics, Comedy, Replay Value, Cute, Psychological Horror, 2D, Memes, Dark, Dating Sim, Retro, Horror.

Pros: Every choice you make in this game matters.
The story is filled with memorable characters, each with his/her own special trait.
The soundtrack is absolutely amazing to listen to
If you play the game once, you will want play it again. There are a couple different ending I know of: a neutral ending, a pacifist ending, and a genocide ending.
Bullet hell dodging sequences placed in enemy confrontations are a fun and welcome challenge that adds another level of strategy to the game.
Save points found in many convenient places along the map, each with its own unique reason for filling you with determination. For example:*(Knowing that someday the mouse will finally eat the cheese…  fills you with great determination)
♥ Save		Return
Cons:Short gameplay. One playthrough can take from 10-12 hours in my experience. (there are other ending to experience, however, so there is the element of replayability)
A few of the jokes get repetitive and dry, but will still make you crack a smile.
No achievements, but some awesome cards and emotes to make up for it. Honestly, this game does not need achievements, but maybe a few would be nice. https://youtu.be/gdoKc3EL76Q
SummaryUndertale is a masterpiece of storytelling and humor filled with memorable characters and a catchy soundtrack. Everything you do matters. You can kill everyone in your sight, or spare them all. Or do a little of both. If you haven't gotten this game already, you are missing out.

My implemented rating system:Run away! 1-2/10
Handle with caution… 3-4/10
Buy on sale: 5-6/10
Every day purchase: 7-8/10
Must buy: 9-10/10

reviewText:
I have spent countless hours wandering a bombed out wasteland in Fallout, venturing to alien facilities in Halo, and warring with dragons in Skyrim. Each of those worlds are fondly remembered, but they are nothing compared to the feelings I have for the world I only recently visited for a dozen hours. The world of Undertale feels instantly familiar and comfortable, filled with characters that are friendly and relatable in a way that most game’s characters couldn’t dream of being. At the end of my journey, I felt that I had made real connections with these figures, I knew their ins and outs, and I felt joyous for helping them achieve their dreams. That is the magic of Undertale, a comedic JRPG that defies expectations at every turn and makes even the most jaded of players transcend into its fiction.

Read the rest of my 10/10 review over at TechRaptor.net . And then buy and play this game!
http://techraptor.net/content/undertale-review-no-bones

reviewText:
As a lover of RPG games, this one is by far the best! Undertale has a great and very interesting plot that draws people into the world it takes place in. Depending on the choices you make throughout the game and how much you keep a close eye on things, the story is almost always changing somehow, weather it's drastically or only small details. You could play Undertale a million times and you would always see some type of change or secret you didn't see before.

The characters are well created and you get attached to them as you play. I don't know how many times I started to cry or felt bad or sad about the choices I made whenever I reseted the game and started playing from the beginning again every time I finished it. It felt like I was seeing old friends again, even though they no longer remember me. Even now, after playing and finishing Undertale five times, I still laugh and smile at the actions of these characters when I see them make the same jokes as they did all the other times.

Another amazing aspect of the game is it's soundtrack. The music really sets the mood of the scene, weather you're simply at the shop buying supplies or fighting one of the bosses. You always feel the emotions that each song creates when it plays. It really makes you feel like you're the character in the game, not the one controling the character. There are even times I listen to some of the songs on the sountrack when I'm doing homework, and they always fill me with determination to finish it, no matter how late at night it is.

I don't know about anyone else, but personally, I would love to see Toby Fox create a sequal to Undertale. I know if he did, I would buy it in an instant!

...where to begin.

I beat the game after about 9-10 hours of straight playing and wow...wow, it is the most beautiful Game I have ever played.
I cried in deep sorrow
I cried in horrid anger
I cried with great joy...

Never before has a game gotten so many emotions from me.

10/10 the most beautiful game you will ever play.
10/10 you will cry your eyes out
10/10 Do Not Kill Anyone.

Goat Mom is the best character I have ever had the pleasure of being introduced to in a game, or any form of entertainment...and when things happened, I tried to call her every chance I got.

10/10 this is the best game you will -ever- play.

Thank you for makeing such a beautiful game. Thank you for making the most beautiful game...Thank you for making me cry so damn much.

It has the biggest soul I've ever seen in a game.

Thank you for making

reviewText:
Before I talk about this game, I'd like to say that receiving almost any advance knowledge of said game more or less destroys its magic. Its mystique, if you will. And this is a game that relies heavily on said mystique. You really wanna know what I think about it, but haven't actually played it yet, read until the first double spaced break. Capiche?

Perhaps this little thing isn't a Final Fantasy game. It certainly doesn't quite have the length of one, even if you account for multiple playthroughs. And the graphics? They do a good job, but they're not exactly triple-A. (The music, at least, is truly top-notch. It helps that the developer is a music composer by trade.)

Normally, I wouldn't even pay any mind to its Overwhelmingly Positive rating, with around 45,718 reviews as of my own review. Here's the thing, though: if a game isn't wowing so many people with its graphics, or its scope - and good music alone does not a good game make - there must be something to it. And that 'it' in Undertale's case is a whole lot of genuine heart, complimented by some actually good writing.

This is basically a JRPG for people who don't really like JRPGs, and I know this because I am one of those people. No matter where you stand on the JRPG-liking scale, I would advise you to at least try the demo[undertale.com]. It is, at the very least, something genuinely different, and it really does have heart.


As for the rest of the game? I dislike bullet hell even more, and the combat system comprising of mini bullet-hell games was nothing short of brilliant - at the very least better than the bog-standard 'select an attack, hold down the speed key in your emulator and watch stuff happen' system of other JRPGs.

Perhaps most importantly, Undertale gives you the choice of not killing any enemy you come across. Not unique, perhaps, but more elegantly implemented than any other game I've seen yet. Even an attempt at a pacifist run here counts for more than in some other games.

Tying into this, Undertale is the rare example of video game writing that isn't some value of bad or otherwise effortless/nondescript, a distinction that puts this game in the leagues of Alpha Centauri and Deus Ex for me. And screw every imageboard memer who hates it just because it's popular and not anime or a milsim. Undertale's writing isn't good because it manages to pull off speculative, philosophical hard sci-fi or just because it tells a rollicking tale of conspiracy and action with corny yet genuine voice acting. Undertale's writing...

...made me laugh, and laugh with it, and I'm not a person who laughs with a game very often. It made me think, not only of the enemies I killed, but of the ones I killed in other games. It started sincere and only became more sincere the further I progressed, although it might have helped that I was invested early on. On my second playthrough, it started to actually kind of get to me. The most important aspect here, however, is the gameplay and story segregation.

There is almost none. In a genre where developers generally don't even care about that sort of thing.

You truly live with your choices here. This game's encyclopedic recall of the decisions you make and the enemies you kill, and the tight interlacing of the aesthetic with the gameplay in general, really do make this game stand out for me...and I've played a lot of games. Even if this isn't the Best Game Ever, it's absolutely one of the best games to come out of 2015, or at least the best one with an androgynous player character which I think is pretty neat either way.

reviewText:
Undertale is a game that came out of nowhere and captivated the hearts of many, MANY players, basicly over night. The fanbase is growing on a daily basis on every possible social and art platform, many would argue it's probably just a phenomenon or a tumblr hipster thing, but I can assure you, there is a reason for all of this hype.

The developers of Undertale dared a risky deal with this game design. You could believe that another retro-style indie game would've turned down by the community in an instant, but there is something important and fresh Undertale has in comparision to other recent games, even the big titles.

Heart. Soul. And character.

Let's break it down in an old fashioned pros/cons list.

Pros:

True morality is something pretty rare in most games. You're the hero, killing the bad guys for the better cause, mowing through endless henchmen and evil dudes without a second thought. You're the reaper of evil!
But what if you could look behind the characters of those you've just slain...? Would you still feel good to kill a family father who was forced to do his evil deed? Undertale does exactly that.
Murder is not fun. The game tells you from the very beginning, heck, even in the trailer, nobody has to die in this game. When you're attacking and killing, it's your choice to do so. And if you kill a character, even the monsters in random encounters, they're gone for good. Other characters will react to your murderous intentions. And all of these bad things will eventually haunt you even in new playthroughs. However, if you choose to be patient and nice, to spare your enemies and convience them to your side, you'll have way more fun on your adventure and gain new friends along the way.

- Combat is pretty interesting in Undertale. Each encounter resembles a bullet hell shooter in some way, where you have to dodge hostile projectiles. Every enemy has multiple attack patterns which can be pretty surprising and hard at first, but they also resemble the mood of your enemy. Is the monster sleepy and slow, well, the attacks certainly will be easy to avoid.

- For me, the music in this game is absolutly top notch, godlike, gold tier, fantastic! There are a lot of different songs for different situations and characters of course, most of them are upbeat and fun to listen to, the perfect rythm for the battles! When something get's emotional, the music will fit right in. But when the game needs to be dark, it can also be spooky.

- The humor, of course, is something very subjective and can easily ruin the experience for you when you're not into it. For my part, I loved it. It had the right amount of cheesiness to still be entertaining, yet there were a lot of funny surprises in the dialogs.

- The characters and writing are probably the best parts about this game. Everything and everybody has character to it, the writing is clever and emotional - and that's probably where the most popularity comes from for this game. If you're a person with a high level of empathy, you'll find yourself invested in an emotional and great story which has a lot more to it than you would imagine on the first look. And stuff like this is pretty dang rare in modern games. Due to the believablity of the characters, you become attached to them, root for them and when you befriend them and they start to root for you too, it starts to feel good. You start to feel determined.

Cons:

- A lot of people are bashing the graphics of this game before even playing it. And you know what? They're right. The retro graphics might be charming, but pretty crude and inconsistent in Undertale. It's a wild mix of Atari style, 8 bit and 16 bit visuals. The environments you're wandering through don't have many details or are pretty in general (except the waterfall area maybe), enemy sprites are sometimes animated, sometimes they're not, this kind of inconsistency even appears with the boss monsters. The game might not be eyes-bleeding ugly, but it's certainly not pretty either.

- Okay, let's be honest guys, the most gameplay aspects of this game are weak. With exception of the combat which is pretty entertaining for the most part, you're just running around and solving... puzzles". But you can't call those things puzzles
date: they're minor obstacles that take a bit longer to overcome than simply running past it. The game in general is very simple and easy
recommended: calling it an actual RPG would be a pretty heavy exaggeration.\n\n- There is another thing that bugged me pretty hard in particular while playing the pacifist route. There is a certain battle in the game in which you have to fight
hoursPlayed:
even it was a no-go the entire game up to this part. The entire journey you learned that attacking can be avoided with kindness and sparing but then you're forced to attack to progress in the battle. That kind of inconsistency was not really necessary and just felt bad.


BUT these cons are minor nit-picks in comparison to the pros!!!

Even if the game doesn't look that good

reviewText:
In shortUndertale - buy it and you're about 99% guaranteed to be more than satisfied with your purchase.

Pros: Great artstyle, amazing music, sparkling humour and well thought-out plot with memorable characters.
Cons: By acquiring this game you're losing your soul. Plus some players get overly obsessed with the game and try always bringing it up, converting everyone they talk to into playing it, etc... But hey! Every healthy community has those weirdos!

Detailed, without spoilersOh boy, here we go.
To me it feels like everyone has heard about this game by now, but if you haven't - oh are you in luck, because this game truly is one of a kind gem that shines even brighter when played blind! Undertale is a singleplayer RPG that remembers your actions.
The artstyle is neat, deliberately simplistic and sometimes really cute. Reminds of good old early gaming era RPGs.
The game mechanics are rather simple and will be familiar to those oldschool RPG lovers. The main difference between this game and other RPGs is that you don't -have- to kill every monster you meet. Taking even this one simple notion into account, your entire playstyle may change drastically, leading you to different mid-game changes, and, of course, endings.
The music in Undertale combines 8bit and instrumental parts, is very well written, and greatly compliments the art and the story, making it into a whole brilliant work.
Overall being a simple game, Undertale refers to older RPG games and up-to-date media, has its own unique traits and manages to touch on complex matters, making not the pixels you control, but you, the player himself, an active and responsible for his doings figure.

Detailed, with spoilersAs someone who's determinately beaten the game three times and watched several playthroughs on top of that, I feel competent enough to write this review.
There are three general routes you can take in Undertale, and every one of them is worth going for. The neutral ending will make you WTF hard, the pacifist ending will make you really happy and possibly force you to shed a tear, and the genocide route will bring your self-esteem down to 0, then stomp on your heart and take your very soul for good measure.
So, I've got a question for you. What other computer games out there are able to do all this and more to you in a matter of several hours? The answer is - not too many of them, which makes Undertale such a treasure, my personal GOTY-2015 and a must-have for every modern player.
Alright, here's a better question. Do you read the review just to get more opinions on this amazing game after having beaten it yourself to fill in that gaping void in your heart? Yes? I knew it.

10/10, would have a bad time again.

reviewText:
There are hundreds of reviews for this game, and they'll all tell you the same thing: It's an amazing game.
Yes, it has a great atmosphere, excellent writing, world-building, and level design.
Yes, it has an amazing OST and characters you can really relate yourself to and become emotionally attatched to.

But that's not what did it for me with this game, instead of telling you why it's a good game, allow me to explain why I personally enjoyed my experience.

A good friend of mine, someone I hold dear to my heart, recommended this game to me after he had played through it, me being a hipster, I kept saying I didn't want to play it. But eventually, I did give it a chance, and I'm so glad I did. I played it for an hour or two and I couldn't really get into it. Sure, I was enjoying it, but it was nothing special.

So he starts watching me play the game, he backseats a bit, we chat, we comment on the world and characters, we're having a really good time. He's there with me for all the embarrassing moments, all the bad moments, and all the good. Together we spent the next 6 or 7 hours doing a True Pacifist run, and I'll tell ya', if he wasn't there for me in all those significant moments of the game, it would have not felt the same. I would've been bored, I wouldn't have cared, I would've just played through. Maybe I'm tasteless, but having him there with me the whole time made the game feel so much more special to me; because of it, I had a blast. We had a blast.

Before I wrote this.. I was doing a genocide run with him, he watched me attempt Sans 28 times.. he cheered me on and on and when I finally beat Sans.. I felt so good, not only because Sans was hard, but because he was there with me, rooting for me and telling me he loves me.

I'll always remember him telling me so often to stay Determined"

reviewText:
A lot of enjoyable games have come out this year - Such as MGSV, and even with Fallout 4 + XCOM 2 coming, I believe that Undertale easily takes spot as my GOTY.

From it's charming humor, down to it's gameplay, it never stays the same. There's always something fresh, yet unexpected around the corner. Toby Fox's attention to detail in this game is unbelievable. It's less of a game, and more of a adventure that can be enjoyed your way.

The soundtrack is inspired! The game was purchased for me, but I made sure to grab the soundtrack to both support Toby, and so I could listen to the beautiful music anywhere.

Undertale is charming in a way that only two other games can hold a candle to: MOTHER 3 and Earthbound

When I finished my first run of the game, I had interacted with everything, and enjoying every part of it. It had taken me about 17 hours from start to finish - And I'm doing another run of the game which makes the gameplay, story, and characters act completely different.

This $10 game had brought me more fun and entertainment than most $60 AAA games out there today.
Whoever is on the fence about buying this game - GO FOR IT. You'll easily get your money's worth, and then some.

As the lovable trailer told us - You don't have to destroy anyone.

reviewText:
Undertale is a wonderful fresh breath of air in the otherwise stale medium that is RPGs. In it, you play the role of a small child who falls down a pit into a world full of monsters. Your goal is to somehow find your way back to the surface world.

One of the unique things about this game is that you can beat the entire game without killing a single monster. To do this, you rely on a separate menu in combat (ACT) which gives you several actions you can perform to convince monsters not to fight you. Doing this for the entire game will net a special ending. Alternatively, you could get something completely different by slaughtering everything in your path.

Combat itself is turn-based and easy to learn. When you attack, you get a small timing-based mini game that determines if/how hard you hit. The other unique feature of this game takes place when it is the monster’s turn to attack. Rather than simply rolling the dice and determining how much HP you lose, you get a “bullet hell” minigame where you must maneuver your soul (a heart) within the confines of a box, avoiding all the pellets/body parts/energy beams shot at you. Because of this, it is possible to “receive” attacks from monsters and take absolutely no damage at all as long as you are good enough to dodge everything.

As far as your actions go, characters remember what you do to them and little things you do early on can have an interesting impact on later encounters. It really feels like your choices matter as opposed to most other RPGs where you are “on rails” all the way to the end. The game is also chock full of cutesy humor as well as serious or disturbing imagery and manages to blend them together without leaning too far in any direction.

Undertale shows a surprising amount of spit and polish for a retro-style game and shines in pretty much every category. The visual style and whimsical character design seems to borrow a lot from various games including Earthbound and Yume Nikki. I also noticed some other musical influence from the Ace Attorney series as well as a few other games. Again, all the references seem to just blend together perfectly without being too obvious.

If you like games that wander off the beaten path and shine in their own unique way, Undertale is probably right up your alley. Just remember to stay ‘determined’!

reviewText:
Undertale is an RPG game that takes many cliché elements in RPG games and creates it into this new type of game in which, just as the description mentions, you do not have to harm a single soul.

PROS:
+ Unique type of gameplay
+ Battles are unlike anything seen before
+ Surprising elements (planned crashes, (non-harmful) game file issues, etc.)
+ Many different characteristic entities, all with a very unique behavior
+ Intriguing artwork
+ Multiple routes" and endings
+ Great amount of soundtracks
+ Trading cards with valuable crafting rewards

CONS:
- It's not really clear in some battles what you're supposed to do
- The protagonist character is rather bland and randomly constructed. It doesn't feel satisfying to be the "normal guy" in what is best described as a world filled with a colorful mismash of vivid characters
- A lot of the game and its areas and transitions make little to no sense
- Not exactly story-driven

reviewText:
So.. Undertale.

The basic synopsis of this game without giving anything away is that you fall down a hole to where monsteres reside, and you have to escape.

But the game is so much more than that.

Undertale is an emotional joyride where you decide your fate, the fate of others and the world around you. At first, the game seems like a fun, silly new form of RPG which has nice characters, a fun story and gives you the choice with what to do with that, which is a great game alone, but then it becomes even better as you make your way to endgame. If you're looking for an emotional story over something more often seen in new releases, this game is definitely for you.

As said before, your choices effect the story. A lot. And before you go and relate this to something else such as Life is Strange"

reviewText:
The game came heavily recommended to the point where I believed it was overhyped. And to a certain extent, it is. HOWEVER, it far exceeded the expectations I've ever had for any indie title. While it lacks a shiny modern graphic design, it does not need it because it excels in every other aspect of its entity. The humorous dialogue stands equal to that of Earthbound's; the jokes were endless and, surprisingly, most of them were expertly delivered. New characters, unnamed and familiar, friend or foe, only added to the excitement and thrill of going onward. The music was completely addicting, the volume couldn't go high enough!  With a custom theme for each boss, it's the game that somehow keeps outdoing itself. The story and atmosphere was absorbing and could effectively set the tone of the game from whimsical and cheery to ominoius and spooky. The gameplay was fresh, new and truly something to be experienced in 'Pacifist Mode.'
I thought this game was another overhyped indie title, nearly writing it off as 'Flavor of the Month,' but it truly delivered much more than I ever expected from a small-time developer. I eagerly await another collaboration or projects from Mr. Toby Fox, Ms. Temmie Chang and the team behind Undertale

Sincerely,
A massive weeb and his 2 friends (also weebs) who helped him while they watched him be bad at video games

*Update* 11/27/15
Unless you are a massive sadist or masocist, a fan of bullet hells and/ or actual hell, I encourage you to h̶a̶v̶e̶ ̶a̶ ̶b̶a̶d̶ ̶t̶i̶m̶e play Genocide Mode but only after a Pacifist Playthrough.

reviewText:
Many people will tell you of this game's deep story, charming characters, interesting mechanical ideas, or its mysterious secrets. But that's not what this is about. Let me tell you what this game is to me.

To me, this game is being the best you can be, saving the lives of everyone, no matter how hard it becomes to not resort to self-defense. Going so far as to help a snowman by taking a part of him to see the rest of the world.

Once you've been to the far reaches of said world, you go for a victory lap. Bask in the glory of the world you saved.

Then, you meet the snowman again. You stare him in the face.

Without a word, you devour the piece of him you've held all this time in one bite, and just walk away.

No one will know his pain. No one will believe him.

No one.

reviewText:
Buy this game.

Buy this game.

Buy this game.

I just finished my first playthrough in a single sitting (took me roughly 8 hours) with some moderate exploration on the side.

As a testament to just how awesome and unique this game is, I can count on one hand how many games are able to keep my interest for more than a couple hours before I need to take a break. AND I PLAYED THIS GAME FOR EIGHT. HOURS. STRAIGHT.

Did you buy this game yet?

Don't let the simplistic graphics fool you into thinking this is some lousy indie game. Everything in this game oozes with charm, from the lovable and memorable characters to the rockin' soundtrack.

I don't want to spoil anything, but heed my advice: You OWE it to yourself to pick this game up.

If you're willing to get past the simple appearance, you will not be disappointed.

BUY IT. Be the hipster among your friends who knew about this game before it was cool.""

reviewText:
Undertale was one of my most anticipated releases of 2015. It didn't disappoint.

Undertale's characters are diverse and unique. Its writing is clever and kept me laughing the entire way through. The soundtrack, composed by Homestuck veteran musician Toby Fox, is littered with dangerously catchy earworms. The gameplay is a fun, frenetic hodgepodge of turn-based RPG, bullet hell, and just a hint of Warioware for good measure.

I had my fears about Undertale since it's a game made by someone who's never made games before, but those all went away after finishing up my first playthrough. Undertale is a one-man labor of love with stunning attention to detail from start to finish, and I would recommend it to anyone and everyone who enjoyed the heyday of turn-based RPGs.

reviewText:
This is probably the first RPG in years where I feel compassion towards seemingly random enemies. Most developers portray them as nothing more than fodder, but Undertale goes a step further by - if you play it right - having said enemies later show up in different areas you'd passed through earlier. They talk to you, say what's on their mind, maybe even flirt with you a little bit.

There is literally a tiny volcano who thinks her lava can heal people and tries SO hard to be helpful. The enemies have facial expressions and react to the things you say or do. The in-battle animations and their attacks all feel so personal. As someone I know said, it's like a combination of Cave Story, EarthBound, and The Stanley Parable with a heavy sprinkling of Touhou for good measure.

That said, the game isn't perfect. No game is, of course. The Genocide Route is understandly in stark contrast to the Pacifist or Neutral ways of playing. Instead of struggling to survive, the enemies fall like dominos. However, when they DO fight back.. it's not fun. At all. There are two fights I wound up having to get outside help with because I literally could not physically react in time. It was during those moments where I wondered just how much testing said fights were put through, or whether the developer had based it on their own skill - always a bad idea for one so intimately familiar with the game.

Otherwise, the game is a blast and I've already completed it on Genocide, Pre-Pacifist and True Pacifist. The writing is absolutely magnificent and you DO feel awful when you play to kill. The music is easy to lose yourself in, as well. There is so much to see and do because of the minutia between the two ways of playing and the multiple ways of ending a neutral game. This is one of those rare cases where you can truly say the devs think of everything"."

reviewText:
As a player coming in who's never played any of the Mother games, this was something new. I was swayed by the amount of hype and attention this piece got so quickly after release, I figured it was just a lot of nostalgia and over exaggeration.

But I finally played it and I have to say; while it might be over blown, it's not done so by a lot.

A game like this comes along once in a generation. One with enough soul that it demands you love it. (Even if you suck at it, like me) Few games ever have any kind of morality system. Even fewer question the morality of the very basis of their own mechanics. (Spec Ops comes to mind) But Undertale asks the questions; is it right to kill an enemy in a video game? Could you talk it out instead? If so, why not?

The amount of meta this game digs into might not be 'original' but it's certainly a refreshing change of pace. Not every choice you make is completely clear as to what it will do and the actual gameplay segments can feel a bit clunky, mainly due in large part to the slow amount of movement you're allowed during your dodge phases. The only real issue this game suffers from is that it's simply not enough. Too short and too lacking in all the amazing characterization it has, it's asking for an expansion or a sequel or something. One playthrough isn't enough to sate most people's taste for the amazing world laid out in Undertale, and playing through it has lead me to understand why. There's too much to drink in and not enough game to hold it. (Not enough hours in the day as they say)

Other than that though -- I have 0 complaints about this game. It's simply incredible. It will make you laugh, it will make you cry, you'll get mad in frustration and cheer in victory as you finally win against that boss you've been stuck on for 3 hours. The music is amazing, the overall feel pulls you into the world and makes you a part of it and it's all done with sprites and pixel art, and sometimes literally, through the meta games.

I really had to think it over since I didn't even give Far Cry 3 a full 10 due to it simply falling short in terms of gameplay stability. And I feel I should do the same for Undertale, but I don't think I will.

So for the first time ever in a *serious* review, I have to give Undertale a full 10/10 for its story and writing alone.

Hats off to you Toby.

reviewText: Undertale is by far one of the greatest and most unique games I have ever played. In fact, it is so good that I decided to write a review for it right away; I have not even completed it yet. First off, I have to say that the game has an absolutely amazing soundtrack. Some of the music is so catchy that I simply cannot get it out of my head. The story is very immersive and full of humorous elements. The great thing about Undertale is that you are free to do as you please. The game does give you a basic idea of what you should do, but you don't have to follow the rules! You are presented with many choices, and it is entirely up to you how you decide to handle them. I have had a great time so far, and I know it will only get better from here.

reviewText:
I am not the type of person who necessarily likes mainstream things-including games.. in fact, I really hate them...

or..
should I say..
MOST of them..

Okay, why?
Because. I fell in love with this game. The design and gameplay is absolutely unique and it really can bring out the innocence of things in life. It opens your eyes to either the true innocence of a child or pure evil of an unpure soul. There are multiple ways the game can play out and every action you choose to make can cause different gameplay results.
Overall, the puzzles are confusing at times but never too hard, the characters are simply lovable, the story is very well and cleverly pieced together, and there are multiple secrets and things to discover. I rate this game mighty fine because of its beautiful uniqueness. :)

reviewText: I haven't felt this way about a game's story in years. The story is so immersive and tugs at the heartstrings at every turn. The music amplifies those feelings and might even make you cry at times (No matter how much of a tough guy you think you are). The situations are real and relatable in a sense of having to do things your heart doesn't want you to do. Overall, Toby has created a wonderful game with a wonderful soundtrack and atmosphere.\n\nIf you are skeptical about getting the game, I was at first. I don't really have much interest in a game's story or RPGs in general, and giving this game a try was a bit of a risk, but I bit the bullet and was not disappointed!

reviewText:
She was the sweetest, most caring character I had ever encountered in a video game, and I feel utterly terrible for what I had to do to her. Was there another option? If I had just thought about it longer, would another solution have presented itself? It's too late now. I made my choice and I have to live with it.

I could look up online if there was another way to deal with the situation, but instead I'm going to keep this game true to life. In life, you sometimes make decisions that can haunt you for eternity. You agonize over the other possibible choices you could've made. This game is incredible for doing that to me.

I adore this game and I cannot wait to finish it so I can play it again. With so many choices presented to you, I imagine the replay value here is pretty high.

----

(Edit - I just finished the game and I cannot stress enough. RPG of the year material right here. In fact, no, this is the game of the year. One of the must plays. A true, legendary gem. DO NOT MISS OUT.)

This is not just your average flash-in-the-pan popular-for-a-month quirky indie game"

reviewText:
SPOILER-FREE REVIEW

Undertale is a beautifully crafted, unique game with a touching story to tell.
It contains RPG, puzzle solving and bullet hell shooter elements mainly, however, these are not the most interesting aspects about this game. It, rightfully, prides itself on being the first RPG where nobody needs to die, you can either kill or spare the enemies you encounter along your journey and it forges the storyline according to your actions.

The good:

+The memorable characters have all (Except for the main protagonist) very distinct personalities. Quirks, kinks and traits that make them enjoyable to either fight or/and befriend.
+It breaks the 4th wall constantly, and does so in a manner that the Deadpool game could only hope to be.
+There is good replay value to be had here, due to its multiple endings, new lines of dialogue and scenes that you’ll unlock if you decide to do a new run after completing it.
+The overall retro look of the game is delightful and so are the character designs and sublime soundtrack.

As for the bad:

-The game is extremely naive and idealistic and, more often than not, all the choices you make boil down to either be a good boy" or "be a psycho".
-Subsequent playthroughs can become a bit tedious.
-It's pretty short (About 5 to 7 hours
date:
depending on the kind of run you're aiming for)

Conclusion:

Undertale is charming

reviewText:
I am a huge fan of the RPGs of the SNES-era: Super Mario RPG, Terranigma, Final Fantasy, Secret Of Mana, Chrono Trigger, Earthbound, etc. The art, the story, the characters, the gameplay, the soundtrack. These games had it all and thus left a big impression on me and rank very high among my favorite games of all time.

Undertale managed to do the same for me. It stays true to the spirit of these games but at the same time it does something new: It messes around with your experiences, your expectations and parodies the core elements and clichés of the genre whereever it possibly can.

A little warning on that note: The humor is not for everyone. I'd describe it as random, meta and often rather blunt. I often couldn't really believe what just was happening on my screen. If you can't stand these kind of jokes you won't enjoy the game. Just read the game key features on the store page and have a look at the kickstarter video and you get the idea.

√ awesome pixel artstyle
√ great world design
√ hilarious and lovable character design
√ turn based fighting system with minigames and non-lethal option
√ your playstyle and actions have consequences and have the power to alter the game and further events heavily
√ small and fun puzzles to solve
√ appealing story with a lot of unexpected events and twists
√ masterpiece of a soundtrack *sample*
√ great sense of humor, doesn't take itself too serious
√ 3 possible endings with alternate versions based on your actions

× only one save slot
x rather short game with ~7 hours

Conclusion:

I recommend Undertale to everyone who is a fan of the good old-fashioned RPGs of the SNES-era but doesn't expect a 100% serious game and can take a lot of jokes.

reviewText:
No game has ever really made me feel this way. Say, comic book characters, movies, etc. None of those have even come close to what this game has made me feel and experience.

First of all, I might as well say here right now: This game made me so attatched to these characters, that I literally cannot play a genocide run. Or neutral. I refuse to outright hurt any of these monsters. You know you have a good game when it physically pains the player to betray a fictional character's friendship by murdering them for your own curiosity.

I'm not even kidding, this game pulled me out of an extremely bad rut in my life where I was just kind of bored of everything and didn't put much effort into anything I did anymore. Semi-depressed, I guess.

Anyway-- The way these characters, interactions and environments (and hell even the music) make you feel is on a whole new level of good storytelling. It will envelop you and make you feel as though you are the human, personally befriending all of these weird monsters.

I never thought a random RPG that popped up randomly after I saw some fanart of it could suddenly shoot up to being my favorite game of the year, possibly of all time.

It's an experience you absolutely have to take on for yourself. Please.

reviewText:
The power of friendship has never been so funny. Or as heartbreaking. And that isn't even getting into what happens when you throw that all out the window and go full-blown sociopath. Then you're really in for a bad time.

Undertale isn't the best game ever, but in a list of greats, it would certainly rank very near the top. Not only that, but it's the kind of story that makes use of it's medium as a video game to the fullest extent. It isn't a long quest, but it doesn't overstay it's welcome either, and multiple endings along with massive amounts of reactive dialog help with the replay value. I'm afraid to go into detail because of spoilers for this adventure where nearly everything you do (or don't do!) has a consequence. Best to go into it blind, with your only knowledge being these words and what the game itself tells you.

Just remember that, whatever your situation, in-game or otherwise, you can get through it; if you just show some determination!

reviewText:
It's hard not to love Undertale. It's exceptionally good at tugging on your heartstrings, and the amount of effort put into every detail of its development is equally stunning. I get the impression that whoever designed it was really enjoying themselves, and their good feelings are infectious.

It's also hard not to draw a parallel to Earthbound/Mother 2, an old classic from the Super Nintendo generation. Much like Earthbound, Undertale lets the mechanics take a backseat and focuses on creating a mysterious world for you to explore and charming characters to meet and influence in different ways. You are given the option of playing as a pacifist or a killer, but given the sympathetic portrayal of every monster that you encounter (and the frankly primitive combat system), only an unconditional sadist would select the latter.

Undertale is a game of mystery and wonder, never content with any particular circumstance and flipping every expectation you can think of on its head. Make no mistake, you are going to feel manipulated and played for a fool. There will be times where you are simply left scratching your head about the insanity of it all. But for an Undertale fan, that too is part of the charm. This is a game unlike any other, an otherworldly thing that defies explanation. It will be surely talked about for many years to come as its secrets are gradually peeled away like the layers of an onion. Should you will it, you can join in and help unravel the mysteries with the rest of us. I can tell that you have the DETERMINATION.

reviewText:
I have a problem finding a good way to recommend this game. It's so different from everything else we're used to, I don't even know how to explain properly what it is that makes it so brilliant without spoiling it. I strongly recommend it to every gamer, because it's really one of a kind and the experience is unforgettable.

Let me just say this game is an absolutely perfect mix of a very unusual concept for an RPG game, absurd humour, brilliant storytelling, amazingly charming characters, player's high involvement in the fate of the world and an unusual way of making the 4th wall completely inexistent, because things that would normally be a game mechanic are a part of the world in some way too. And the (good) ending is extremely satisfying and will just make you feel great.

I can't explain it any better... You just have to trust me. If you're still sceptical about this game and would rather play your precious AAA games instead, I'll just say this: you actually love Undertale, you just don't know it yet. ;)

reviewText:
Its been a -really- long time since I last played an RPG that has caused such an extreme emotional reaction for me.  This game has a way of working into your heart and pulling at yoru heartstrings, even when you don't want it to.

Sure you can go in and just kill everyone and everything. But thats only one half of the game, one way to play it. There is a whole other way to play. one of MERCY, and -true- love.

So yeah, you can play this like a regular RPG: Gain your ATK, DEF, LV, EXP...Or experience it with the mechanic that allows you to do so much, the act of MERCY.

No one, nothing has to die in this game, you can go thorugh it without ever killing a single enemy. And hell, you can even go on a date with a couple of the bosses, too. Its sweet.

Course though you could just got play something like Metal Gear, or CoD. Entirely up to you.

reviewText:
Remember when Cave Story was the best thing to ever come out of indie games? I now believe that the torch must be passed on to Undertale. Much like Cave Story innovated and expanded on the retro Metroidvania genre, Undertale does with old-school RPGs with a very noticable influence from the Mother/Earthbound series.

The similarities between Cave Story and Earthbound don't end there. Undertale is also full of many charming characters with charming dialogue that will constantly keep you smiling. The soundtrack only helps add to the charm with very catchy melodies that always suit the situations within the game.

Don't let the retro graphics fool you. This game is amazing in its own rights and is a must-own at its full price. The charm of the game and the promise of different endings and dialogue will keep you replaying just to make sure you've seen all that Undertale has to offer. I give Undertale my highest recommendation!

reviewText:
A game that's completely taken over my thoughts, conversations, dreams, and nightmares even after beating it, and one that's going to linger in my mind and change how I see and play everything else for years to come.

For those who form hate mobs over spoilers, I'll be dropping a few hints of the nature of the game in this review, but I'll avoid talking about anything plot-related. You owe it to yourself to find out what all the fuss is about, and it's probably best to dive in without any spoilers, or even clues on what to expect, so read ahead with caution.

Simply put, this is one of the most consistently funny, touching, surprising, shocking, charming, unpredictable, disturbing and overall memorable games made in years. It's ambitious but simple in design, taking basic, old-school mechanics and twisting them around a little to make it its own unique thing. That alone would make it worth a visit for nostalgic rpg fans, but where it goes so much further is in the way it bends and then utterly shatters its own rules, creating a colourful, branching story that's compelling enough on the surface and then outright mind-bending as you delve deeper into its layered meta-narrative. While I hesitate to even hint at anything that might spoil it, I'll at least say that this game has both made me laugh and terrified me more than anything else has in a long time.

While there's a lot to enjoy for anyone who likes games, the ideal target audience is an experienced gamer who's been playing since the NES/SNES era, given the partial reliance on nostalgia for some of its charm. It's a game that's very self-aware and fully indulges itself in pointing out its own use of gaming tropes and cliches, but it's a lot more clever than just  calling them silly and moving in. The deconstruction of games and the common gamer is a central theme to the overall plot and it has a lot to say about you, the player, and how you you play it. These moments range from clever little meta-jokes to sheer horror over your actions and creates an unsettling sense of overall paranoia whenever you do anything.

The breakdown of so many common aspects of RPGs and games in general work so well because they're not just jokes, but central plot devices and everything in-universe works on its own even with all the meta twists going on. It's not just a matter of pointing to a gaming cliche and going hey look guys isn't this dumb" but it's actually a very effectively analytical breakdown of games and why we play them. But before you dismiss it as a pretentious "art" game
date: it also happens to be a very well-written and funny game that hardly takes itself seriously in the slightest despite it all.\n\nThat a game can be so whimsical and funny on the surface and so clever and mind-bending beneath really just makes it a success on every single level. Much like many other landmark indie titles of the past
recommended: I can picture this one having a lot of influence on titles to come
hoursPlayed: but nothing could ever truly capture what this one accomplished again. It's a once-in-a-generation kind of game and you won't ever play anything like it again. While I hate to rush to such conclusions as calling it my favourite game ever so soon after completing it
voteText:
that was my immediate first instinct upon reaching the ending I was shooting for.

So play it. And remember:
I'll be watching"

reviewText:
Undertale gives back a lot if you sank hundreds of hours into 16-bit JRPGs -- especially FF4, 6, and Earthbound. But even if you haven't, it has so much to give. Undertale toys with your expectations, not just in plot, not just in game mechanics, not just in level design, but even all the way down to fundamental nuts and bolts of how games work. Undertale delights with clever subversions left and right, and a combat system that lets you fight your way through without ever hurting anyone.

It *sounds* gimmicky, but Undertale's pacifism isn't for chumps. Sure, you might get some easy encounters where you compliment a frog and go on your way, but lots of encounters function as a little puzzle -- you have to know about your opponent's wants, needs, fears, hopes, etc., and choose your actions along a multi-step process to earn their trust. And since you still have to live through the bullet-hell defensive portions, it's honestly a more engaging game to go peaceful anyway.

That said, you'll probably take the path of violence eventually. You have to, right? Just to see what happens. Just to assert that you *can*. Well.... Undertale will let you do that. You want to kill everything that lives? Go for it buddy. But don't be surprised to find that actions have consequences, and that those consequences might reach further than you think.

reviewText:
Oh boy. Where do I even start with this one? So much to talk about.

Undertale is an RPG game with bullet hell elements. You control a child who fell down from a hole in the mountain, far down into the Underground, where all monsters were exiled after they lost the war with humans. You journey through to the barrier that separates both worlds, meeting and fighting many interesting, weird, or downright wacky characters along your way. Ultimately it is up to you whether you will spare their lives... or kill them.

The game is obviously holding a simple 8-bit style for the most part, but it isn't afraid to drop it when needed. It's all pretty to look at despite its simplicity, but that's not what I would call the best part of the game.

Music. Almost every single piece composed for this game feels unique, done in its own style, blending perfectly into the current scenery or what's happening on the screen, giving an incredible effect. Just try to walk through the Waterfall without stopping for a moment to listen to the music. Or just downright doing nothing during a boss fight for the same reason.

The story is, for the lack of originality and better words, amazing. Depending on which path you take, you will feel a whole plethora of emotions as it progresses. You will laugh. You will cry. You will feel DETERMINED to keep on going.

Finally, the gameplay. You can explore the locations in your usual RPG fashion, and you enter a turn-based RPG-style battle when a random encounter happens. However, unlike in other games, during the monster's turn you will be thrown onto a field, controlling a red heart (called your SOUL), dodging enemy projectiles and attacks. This gives it some skill-based value and keeps it interesting - you can potentially avoid taking damage entirely if you're good enough. I will refrain from making remarks about its difficulty, as someone well-versed in bullet hell shmups, the game was rather easy for me personally. (I died maybe once or twice over the course of the whole game.)

But what the most important is, it's like there isn't exactly a fourth wall here. The gameplay rules are being altered to fit what is going on the screen at that moment. The game knows when you die and reload a save and will call you out on it. It's ready to mess with you at every occassion, making it sort of unpredictable. And so interesting.

My only complaint with the game is that it's a tad bit short. Your first playthrough will most likely be completed in less than 10 hours. I don't mind short games though, especially if it's something as great as this one.

I recommend this game... no, you HAVE to play it. There's no excuse. The game is everything that was great and even more about the old RPGs. This is an unforgettable adventure of your life.

reviewText:
I would go as far as to say that it's the spiritual successor to Earthbound.
A prime example that graphics don't make a game.
What makes a game is:

An amazing and funny script.
Characters that you can't help but to feel for.
A storyline that envelops you in a new misunderstood world, and jerks you up and down the emotional rollercoaster.

The longer you play it - the more this game will time and time again impress you with its originality and the amazing amount of heart and detail that's been poured into it.

It takes what you know and love from games like Earthbound - and tips its on its head.
And I couldn't be any more happy with it.

10/10.

EDIT:
I have now gifted this game to several friends.
This game CANNOT go unnoticed.
I want everyone to feel the warm fuzzy feeling that i have from this pinnacle of interactive ingenuity.
GAME OF THE YEAR. COME ON BABY.

reviewText:
Undertale is one of the most progressive and innovative RPGs in a long time.

While most modern RPGs will task you with murdering an  increasing number of nameless goons for the sake of raising some arbitrary stats, Undertale will make you care deeply for every enemy you will encounter.

It ruthlessly deconstructs the reasons why we used to play RPGs allowing the player to play through the entire  game without hurting another soul. It succeeds so completely in its thematic approach that it becomes a truly wonderful experience, seemingly emanating pure joy.


Undertale is a masterpiece full of whimsical humor, battle system innovations and deep moral decisions. The game proves to be a compact, perfectly paced RPG experience with hilarious, tense writing and endearing characters.

Never before has a game made me both laugh out loud and almost weep in the span of mere minutes.

Undertale will change you. It will fill you with ...determination
voteText: 9 of 11 people (82%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Undertale is not an outstanding game because it features one of the best video game soundtracks you've ever heard.
Not because it has a surprisingly fresh and robust battle system.
Not because of its humorous and well-written dialogue.
Not even because it manages to merge all of the above together seamlessly.

Undertale is an outstanding game because it inspires genuine emotions and connections with the characters of the world.
Because every decision affects the story in some form, with the player holding absolute authority over how it is told.

But most importantly, Undertale is great because it reminds you what it felt like the first time you picked up a video game and just had fun.

reviewText:
Oh my god.
This ♥♥♥♥ing game.
I don't usually make serious reviews, but this game has been an exception in so many things for me, I might as well.

Before I start, I'm going to save you a bunch of reading: Buy. This. Game.
It is amazing LITERALLY from start to finish. (This is the first time I sat through the entire game's credits.)

But anyways, on to the important stuff.

Pro's:
- Good story.
- The soundtrack is pure, digital gold.
- Unique, spot-on characters you will actually care about.
- Beautiful bullet-hell mechanics.
- Lots and lots of jokes♥♥♥♥♥♥ences.
- It never gets dull.
- Tons of replay value.
- Skeleton puns.
- Dogs.
- Temmies.
- Your choices matter (most of the time).
- Will make you love two of the most hated fonts in history.

Cons:
- Some of the dialogue can get a bit sappy.
- Some of the jokes overstay their welcome.
- The game is very in-your-face with its message.

Debatable:
- You will feel the feels. (Self explanatory)
- The fandom. (As with any fandom, it's filled with very unsavory individuals. I'm looking at you, parts of tumblr. But there's also a load of amazing people who create wonderful works.)

I'd give it an 8.5/10. Great game, but not without glaring flaws. Killing goatmom on accident haunted me through the entire playthrough. Developers, take notes.

I cursed his name, and got scared when the game crashed. I slowly loaded back the game, and noticed something was wrong. I got scared when I heard the eerie tune of Omega Flowey. I saw the outline, and ♥♥♥♥ my pants a second time. I have been defeated twice, both times crashing my game. I haven't tried again yet, but I decided to write a review. This review.
Thank you.
This game gets you involved, and scares you at times. It also has a lot of humorous moments.
I recommend Undertale.

reviewText:
If you care about video games as a serious form of art, you really should play this game to completion.  You will only understand what all the fuss is about when you see the best ending.

It's difficult to talk much about Undertale without spoiling things.  If this review seems vague, that is the reason.

There are many good things about Undertale.

It deals with some serious subject matter, and gives it the complex and detailed coverage it deserves, instead of resorting to simplistic, unworkable or even harmful, political tripe.  It does this without becoming depressing by mixing in lot of comedy, like the practice of performing comedies after tragedies in Shakespeare's day.

It does not have a plot in the conventional sense.  Every playthrough is likely to be at least a little different.  A vanishingly small number of other games (e.g. Dwarf Fortress[www.bay12games.com]) have achieved this with extremely deep simulation.  Undertale achieves this by making almost everything you do, even seemingly minor things, impact a large number of other things you will encounter later in the game.

The best ending is fully interactive, and if you do everything you can it will probably take you an hour or more.  I can't praise this highly enough!  Not only is it something I've never seen done before, but many other games have short, unrewarding endings, or even ones that punish the player for winning by having something bad happen to their or other loved characters.

I love the “Act” and “Mercy” parts of the combat system.

I really like the soundtrack.  It's quirky, but very listenable.  It's also long enough to leave playing for quite a while without becoming repetitive.

Even some things I do not like (like some aspects of the combat system) could be argued to be ‘part of the message’.

Undertale is not perfect, in my opinion.  However, it comes closer than most other games.

I am personally not a fan of the action aspect of the combat system.  The boss fights in the last half of the game would require someone to react with the speed and precision of a computer without certain items that they are unlikely to have.  This is too difficult to be fun.  At least the game does include a workaround (the necessary items) for those of us who cannot react that quickly and accurately.

Undertale misleads you into thinking you should avoid picking up or buying items because your inventory will be too limited with some bad advice in the beginning.  Further, it punishes you for using up certain consumables by making them unique or unavailable (because part of the world becomes inaccessible) later on.  One of almost every consumable is needed to complete a quest, or end a fight quickly, somewhere in the game.  The strangest thing is there seems to be no reason for this.

There also appears to be one bug in the game.  The solution to the piano puzzle sounds nothing like the hint.

Undertale lacks the settings PC gamers have come to expect.  There are no graphics or sound settings.  You can run the game in fullscreen mode or in a tiny window that cannot be resized.  It would be really nice to be able to resize and maximize/restore that window.  It would also be really nice to be able to set the music and sound effect volume.  There is no way to remap the keys, which default to the arrow keys (movement and selection) and Z (confirm), X (cancel), and C (menu).  Given that the game demands speed and precision, it would be really nice to be able to change those key bindings to something more comfortable.

I was gifted this game by a friend, and am very grateful.  This is one of the most enjoyable, and important, games I own.

I hope this game will fill others with determination to confront serious subject matter in their games, and provide such impressive replayability.

reviewText:
I haven't yet fully completed the Genocide Run, but I've played enough to make a decent review of the game. Now, I am totally glad I bought the game, but as all games, it has bad stuff. And as usual, I will start with the bad stuff of the game:

The biggest problem I've found so far, is one that has been slowing my playthrough since the start. And it's also something that I can't really understand at all: There's no way to change the controls.

Can I please ask WHY? The game uses the keys Z, X and C for interactions, and the arrow keys for movement. I literally can't think of a SINGLE GAME on my Steam account that uses those buttons. And I have nearly 200 games. In nearly all games, you would move using the classic wasd, but changing this is not only kind of dumb for a PC only game, but makes playing the game be really unconfortable. I've searched through the Internet for ways to change the controls, and I've found nothing, only if you plug a controller. I forced myself through the game, suffering these controls because I LOVED the story, but if you then decide to play it on a Genocide Run to see all of the stories in the game, you WILL end up tired of them, garanteed. Now, people say that playing with a controller is better... BUT I SHOULDN'T REQUIRE ONE TO PLAY THE GAME! Just think: You usually move in games with your left hand. This game forces you to move with your RIGHT hand, or cross your arms, which I tried and ends up being a pain. And for what I know, left-handed people have it even worse... And the creators haven't done anything about it.

The second problem I see with it, and last issue, is the gameplay. And this is related to the Genocide Run as well. The difficulty spikes are so pointy, they could take an eye out of your skull. Normal enemies are really simple, some bosses have a really GOOD balance of challenge and fun (like Papyrus, he seems to be the best example, as he changes the rules of the battle mid-way through... But it doesn't feel forced at all), and some hard battles like the two last ones on the Pacifist run were hard, challenging, original and still fun, but then you have the two on the Genocide Run. Yeah, there's only two real bosses on the Genocide Run, which is kind of dissapointing on it's own, but you will also have to face a difficulty spike way more crazy than the one before, as it's real boss appears nearly after an hour of killing enemies that really can't fight you at all, and it starts throwing attacks REALLY F#CKING FAST. I was able to beat it because it's movements were easy to master after a few tries... But then the other boss of the Genocide run has a ton of attacks that are randomized, and attacks even faster. To that point I decided to just take a break, and take my time to beat it, as sadly, both issues the game has so far go really good by hand, making enemies that require you to move really fast be more difficult than they already are.

There's a third problem with the game... But that one ain't the devs fault. It's the community of the game. Back when the game released, people would not SHUT THE F#CK UP about the game. What's the problem with that? This game is heavily story-driven, to the point that if you eat too many spoilers, you might as well just ignore buying it and go watch a playthrough on YouTube. And what did the community did? Just that. Spam stuff about the game everywhere. I know they were trying to give the game a good name, so more people go and play it; however that can back-fire really easy. If you haven't yet been spoiled a ton of crap of the game, you must live under a rock, or have no friends that have played it.

All of that being said, what do we have left? A really, really good game.

First of all, the story: It really gets you hooked for more. It's been really well written, and it shows that the creator actually knows what any gamer would do, as he though of nearly everything. And that's another thing...

The game really seems to be alive, to have a mind of it's own, to be self-aware of it. Everything seems to have a reaction, no matter how crazy it might be. It also helps that the forth-wall breaks a ton of times by some characters.

Talking about characters, the game has a ton of them, and let me tell you, you'll find it hard to hate them. Even the enemies have personalities, something you nearly ever see.

Combat is fun, if you stay away from Genocide runs. Feels rewarding to pull it off, and the boss fights are INSANELY EXCITING. It also has a item system which is okay, but suffers because of the controls at times. Save points are also forgiving, and there's usually at least one before those exiciting bosses.

The graphics are pretty. Now, if you hate old-school SNES graphics you might not like them... But I feel like everyone else will. The only thing that I feel awkward about is that the main character doesn't seem to have nearly the same detail as everything else.

The best part of the game, however, is the music. It's just perfect. Seriously. I'm not kidding. F#cking perfect. Well... Except in one part, when Toriel leaves you alone and you have to run for an entire area with a weird theme on the background. That's literally the only moment where I didn't like the soundtrack. And counting that it only takes 20 seconds of probably 8 hours for every run, it's not that bad.

Should you buy this game? Yes. Totally. However, I don't see nearly any sales for it. If you do wish to buy it, put it on your Wishlist, and wait. I mean, the only time I remember seeing it on a sale was on the Winter Sale, and it was only a 20% sale. If you can get it for bellow 5-6€, then it's a must buy. Otherwise wait, as I feel like 10€ might be too much.

And before I end, I must say: I am disgusted by the reviews of the game. I haven't seen nearly ANYONE comment the control issues on their reviews, instead some call it a 10/10, claiming that it's perfect. That's bullsh#t. If you can't make an honest review, please avoid doing it, as it creates problems like these. reviewText: To understand, I tend to be rather discerning with my tastes, and at the very top of my favorite games of all time are the first two original X-Com games, as well as Super Mario Bros. 3. Undertale has kicked even those classics I held so dear off their throne for first place as one of the most well-written, well-thought out and genuinely fun to play games, the trifecta of what makes a good RPG. The characters are interesting, the writing clever for something that deals with the delicate fourth wall, and the game itself a delight to play with quite a bit of variety for simple mechanics. (Relative to how they play, I'm sure they took quite a bit of doing in terms of programming)\n\nLots of comparisons to Earthbound/Mother and OFF have been made, I'm aware, those games indeed had some tear jerker moments and rather fascinating stories, details, and writing in them, and as much as I loved them, I'll be the first to say they also play like crap. While Mother 2 and 3 made me tear up a bit, OFF had me kinda scratching my head as I took it all in, Undertale got me emotionally invested to the point where I must concede a point to the villain and admit a pathetic aspect of me. Here, I cannot, as it'd spoil the fun, but I cannot think of a single title in the last decade that I'd recommend higher as of this review than Undertale.

Came out of nowhere as the best game I've played for years and years.
