reviewText:
I currently have two favourite games of all time, both of which have affected me on fairly deep emotional level.
The first of those two games is Dark Souls, a Japanese action RPG created by a god among videogame developers named Hidetaka Miyazaki.
I have played Dark Souls for a total of 929 hours, and I have enlisted at least 100 hours or more into all installments of the Souls game series, aside from the remake of Dark Souls 2 (because I'd already played the original a ton) which sits at 88 hours.

My second game of all time is Undertale, an indie game by an (until now) fairly unknown indie game developer named Toby Fox. It is supposedly reminiscent of the Mother and Earthbound series of games, but I have played no games from either series and have no nostaliga to be farmed off of them. It's also been more than a month since I last played the game, so any hype I've had should've subsided by now.
I have played Undertale for 11 hours total.How has Undertale managed to compete with a game I've played with such devotion over a long period of time?

Hell if I know, go play it yourself. You should like it unless you have a huge amount of dislike for storytelling, challenging but not difficult bullethells and pixel art (you can refer to the screenshots on the store page for examples).

I'm not gonna spoil anything about the game, so if you want a detailed review you'll have to look elsewhere. The game is a lot better when it's spoiler-free, however.

I dunno what else to say, really. 10/10, I guess. I'm gonna go listen to the game's soundtrack for the umphteenth time now.

reviewText:
Don't let the graphical style fool you, this game was a labor of love.

Things react to your actual actions as a player, not just dialogue prompts... the NPCs will react in different ways based on seemingly minor things you may or may not have done.  There's alternate dialogue everywhere, multiple endings, so many things to find... there's little secrets and hints, and it takes at least two playthroughs to put the important bits together.  Little hints and facts you may have picked up from just reading a bookshelf can come back and hit you hard when you learn more about what's going on, for example.

The battles are really interesting as well.  There's generally multiple ways to end a conflict, and the dodging mechanics when you're being attacked vary a lot throughout the game and major fights tend to introduce new twists.  The fights have a lot of work put into them, much more so than I imagined from seeing the simple Dragon Quest-style view.  Everything from the enemy reactions to the sprite changes and animations must have taken a lot of time for each monster, much more work than you usually see anymore.

The game's not very long, you can beat it" once in a day if you push... but I think it's well worth getting 'cause there's so much in it to explore when you replay it (to try to avoid spoilers).  And yes

reviewText:
Undertale is a really good game, and you should probably play it. That's it. To say any more about the game would probably ruin it for you.

It seems to me undertale is becoming one of those games people don't shut up about. Like Minecraft, or god forbid, FNaF. And it's kind of a bittersweet thing. With a huge fanbase comes huge expectations for a game. Everybody and their mother is singing the praises of this game, and while I love this game to death, and it deserves recognition, the popularity is in a way doing the game a disservice. Not to sound like some kind of hipster, of course, but with all the voices of the internet calling the game the second coming of Jesus Christ, it's easy to come into the game with inflated expectations. And when you come into a game expecting the best thing ever, you'll undoubtedly be let down every time.

My advice is to just play the game, and listen to no one. And avoid the fanbase like the damn plague. It's a good rule of thumb to do so with most things, but here it's especially important. To come into this game expecting something that will change gaming and make you have a religious experience and give you a free pot of golden hookers is going to result in you being very disappointed. Try and enjoy the game for what it is, and for the experience you have with it, not for what other people tell you.

reviewText:
You might not get a game that expands your concept of what “games” can be every year, or even every other year, but this is one of those years.

I’ve had the honor of both playtesting and playing the release versions of Undertale, and, although I have piles of unfinished games in my home and Steam library, I’ve already played through it completely twice, with plans already for a third run. For me, as an adult with little free time to dedicate to the RPG genre of games, I could easily worry about time consumption — if this game weren’t the perfect length for someone like me (about 6 hours, 10-ish for completionists). And Undertale makes the most of that sweet, sweet time, especially if what you love doing is talking to characters, solving puzzles, dancing with slimes, consoling ghosts, and much more.

See, Undertale is a game where “no one has to die” — one of the rare few games that takes the weight of your actions and treats them both realistically and appropriately. Your underground journey among a world of monsters can eschew violence entirely, even when it’s demanded of you. (And, as with reality, doing so is infinitely more rewarding.) Each monster is different. Each interaction is personal. Every problem can be solved, with time and effort.

This game was basically made for me. Stylistically reminiscent of cult classic EarthBound — funny, cute, dark, sometimes tragic — it’s easy to get into and easy to play, being relatively simple while shockingly deep. Its battle system will continue to surprise you, and the puzzles are fair even for people who aren’t puzzle fans (such as myself). Don’t take my word for it — play the demo! If you love the demo, you’ll definitely love the game — and it only improves from there. Its writing holds nothing back, with fun and intimate character dialogue, surprisingly sharp uses of the 4th wall, and a very distinct overall tone. Undertale will more than likely exceed your expectations.

I don’t want to say too much more because every moment with the game is precious, but:

- The game will make you cry baby snotty tears

- The game will make you laugh until your lungs and face ache

- It’s practically robbery at $10 ($18 for the OST bundle)

- The music is fantastic (especially the boss battles)

- You’ll want to play it 3-5 times all the way through

- You’ll especially love it if you’ve spent any significant amount of time on social media in the past several years

This game has made it obvious that you don’t need to turn to AAA first-party console-based titles to see the medium of games expand. At its core, it manages to maintain sincerity and heart through all its bizarre events. Please play this game with determination.

reviewText:
Anyone with a soul is almost guarenteed to love this game. Undertale plays to the strengths of the RPG format, while also removing some of the more tedious aspects of it. Battles are fun, engaging, and anything but straightforward. You can go into a battle geniuley not knowing if your going to let an enemy live or die, and the choice you make can have massive effects on the progression of the game, in ways that you may not even realize. Enemies are no longer simply enemies, but a moral dillemma for you, as the player, to overcome.

Every choice matters. That being said, the game is short in an initial playthrough (about 7 hours). However, there are so many scenarios and secrets that depend soley on your choices that there are things that you will never be able to completely experence in a single run. This game is massivly replayable in that sense. I imagine that even if I played Undertale ten times over, I'd still be finding new things I'd never seen before. The choice aspect of the game makes it a very personal experience, and as a result, the game becomes very easy to get invested into.

The excellent music, characters, and dialouge are so strong that they will stay with you long after you finish playing the game. Undertale also has to be one of the funniest games I have ever played in my life. This is the kind of game that makes you question your idea of what a video game is, how it can affect you, and what it can acheive with creative genius behind it. If in the right hands, games can shock you in ways you never could imagine. This game will shock you with its brilliance. For all these reasons and more, Undertale is an absolute must play.

reviewText:
I was a backer for the basic game tier and like when it came to Fran Bow a few weeks ago I wished I backed it for more. Undertale is a fantastic game, and alongside LISA it puts the vast majority of modern JRPGs to absolute shame.  Like LISA, the Earthbound influence is strong with Undertale, but it takes a far more heartwarming approach; though it easily can turn bleak as hell, but that’s all up to you. And that’s one of Undertale’s strengths, your choices and how you approach combat actually weigh heavily on what happens. The combat is also neat in how you have to avoid damage in sequences kind of akin to a SHMUP and the game constantly shakes these up and you get some really unique attacks to deal with. The writing is overall great, with charming characters and it when it pulls the heart strings it succeeds. It’s also genuinely funny. The atmosphere and soundtrack are also great. Finally I actually managed to get the best ending in my first playthrough and its one of the absolute finest endings I’ve seen to a game.

Overall I’m totally glad I backed Undertale because it’s an RPG classic in the making and a must play. Ten bucks is an absolute steal for this game. Buy it.

reviewText:
Undertale - The friendly RPG where nobody has to die
I never heard of this game before until it release on Steam around September 2015 and it seemed to be very popular for some reason. I thought what's the big deal about this game? It look just like an RPG game like EarthBound or Mother 3. So I went to the Undertale website[undertale.com] and try demo. The first minute on demo was really impressive and after I finished the demo I went back to Steam and buy full game and soundtrack bundle instantly, I didn't buy games on steam for full price for long time but I really want to support the developer.

The very first game that make me feel bad for trying to kill monsters
Undertale is a truly one of the most heartwarming and very charming story-driven games that I've ever played so far. I was playing normally by killing everything I encounter because that is just how an RPG games played right? but until I fought the first boss  Yes, it's Toriel everyone's beloved goat mom  and suddenly I just realized that I don't want to kill her but I accidentally kill her while trying to lower her hp but she will die if you attack when her hp is less than 1/4 of her full hp and that was the first emotional train that hit me straight into my face when I hear her last word. Well I have not feel so strong of an emotion toward game since the ending of Okami  Amaterasu and Issun farewell scene  anyway I reset that playthrough and start my new playthrough again and surprisingly, some of the characters know I regret my decision and decide to start new playthrough that mean every decisions you made in this game will be save in somewhere in game files and will affect the game unless you wipe your data on your computer.

The gameplay
First, it might look like normal RPG game but when you play you will find some humor of this game like you cannot actually sell your items to shopkeepers like in RPG because they don't want to spent money for items that they're never use but there still only one shop that still want to buy your items because they want them and they have a very deep history hOI! welcom to da TEM SHOP" or YES! You can literally date a skeleton! reviewText:
Undertale is gift sent from a greater being, it is hands down my favorite game of 2015 and Honestly probably my favorite of all time, this is one of the greatest experiences I've had in a very long time.  Toby put a lot of love and care into this game and it really shows, I have never been so invested in a story and it's characters in my entire life.  Undertale is definitely a game I'm going to continue coming back to every now and then just to revisit all the characters and places I love, which is all of them.

Every character and their dialogue are all so charming it's hard to dislike any of them, the art style while simple is appealing and fit the world perfectly.  Don't get me started on the sick jams the music is perfectly composed, every part of the soundtrack fits the moment flawlessly I could listen to the OST all day and have.

An RPG" where playstyle actually changes the way the story shapes up

reviewText:
Ok... so how do I start?

Well, this game is awesome... no, it is beautiful. You need to try this game, I reccomend that. Seriously, this is an awesome game. Really. Let me tell you why, without spoiling it for you. It has great characters, a great plot, many easter eggs, amazing lore, special interactions, good fight scenes, fantastic music, beautiful pixel art, good puzzles, good bosses to fight and will officially give you a feels ticket to the feels train on that is travelling on the feels traintracks to feels town on a feels mountain at the continent of feels in feels planet sitting within the feels universe.

It is a RPG game, a fantastic one too. A great story, make sure you play without spoilers. I will give you one advice though(It is not that spoiler-like but its very good advice. But if you don't want the advice or te slight hin just don't look at it then c: )[spoilers]Try not to kill anyone at all and spare everyone. Trust me, you will be rewarded greatly.[/spoiler]

The story is amazing, the music is excellent and its beautiful overall. You will fall in love with it's characters, you will care for all of them and love everyone, everyone is lovable, funny and memorable.There are easter eggs and hints through out the gameplay you will have to check a bunch of place. But the complexity and the easter eggs are very cople and interesting for you to see. Trust me, you will enjoy this game. It is pretty emotional and very exciting. Its a story game, and you should get it. This game had love and dedication poured into it, it will be the best game you will spend money on and you will note regret it. This game is awesome, get it.

TL;DR
This game is awesome, you will not regret buying it. Good story, music, emotional feels, characters, lore, easter eggs, puzzles, fights, boss fights and so much more.

reviewText: It may not have graphics, but games have proven time and time again that they don't need them to be good. Undertale is no exception. Its not just good, its smart. The story is entirely original, the gameplay is different with each enemy encounter, and the characters are lovable and exciting. There never was a dull moment in playing the game, even when traversing seemingly monotonous areas. Most of all, though. Its funny. The game never failed to leave me with a smile on my face. Even the endless amount of bad puns are done in such a way, it makes you smirk.\n\nAll in all, it's a must buy, even if you arent familiar with most RPGs. Undertale's combat system is so unique, you don't need prior experience in the genre to just jump in and play. So go ahead, start up the game and let the feel train take you on a wild ride through this wonderful little experience.

reviewText:
Top to bottom, an absolute gem.
Well done, Toby Fox.

It's incredibly hard to describe Undertale concisely without digging into its specifics, which ought to be experienced first-hand in the first place. It's hard to even categorize Undertale in a genre. The best description is often repeated though; Earthbound with shmup." But even that statement doesn't necessarily do it justice either; the game is so wonderfully crafted with each section of the game feeling meaningful. There isn't a single moment of the game that feels unnecessary
recommended: further exploration is set to your leisure.\n\nThe game is filled with moments that will break the standard video game expectations that we are used to
hoursPlayed: so go into this game with an open mind from the start. Undertale is not the longest of games

reviewText:
Even if you think 10 dollars is a bit too expensive for a 6 hour long game - but you will quickly find it is your choice for it to not be the case -
Even if you've been spoiled a part of the game when it blew up the Internet by surprise - I did too, but I still managed to discover things in my playthrough -
Even if you don't like sudden blows of popularity by some indie games that end up becoming passing trends, kind of like Slender of FNAF back in the day - however this game is well above those two, and that could be justified only by the lack of cheap jumpscares -
Even if you're tired of hearing your friends begging you to try it - saying it's the best game ever, or, maybe more realistically, the best game of 2015 -
Even if you can't stand all the memes this game has created - or if you think they will die as quickly as they were shaped -
Even if you think that a game messing up with the player or breaking the fourth wall is nothing new - though with this one, it's on another new level -
Even if you're fed up with indie games with 8-bit graphics - this one has some 16-bit sprites, that's already a plus if you're all about graphics -
Even if you heard songs from the OST a thousand times already - and you only heard the more popular ones, as the entire OST is a gem -
Even if you think that the idea of choices in a video game has no effect on you anymore - though here, it's really your choices that determine if you want to have a good time with this game... or not -
Even if you suppose that the concept of becoming friends with everyone is naive and pointless - that's still, paradoxically, the most fun you will have in the game -
Even if you prefer cats to dogs - and maybe this game will change your mind on that point -

You should, in my opinion, at least try Undertale, or its demo. It's a game that goes far beyond your expectations, and an experience that you will have a hard time to forget.

reviewText:
Admittedly, when I first saw this game, I didn't really know what to think about it. It didn't look like it was going to be bad, but I wasn't expecting it to be anything outstanding, either.

There was an awful lot of hype surrounding it, though. Lots of my friends were playing it and talking about it, and soon the internet was pretty much ablaze about this game. I'll admit, this somewhat lowered my expectations.

Then I played the demo... and then very shortly after, bought the game. No way did I think this game was going to play with my emotions the way it did, considering how much 75% of the internet overreacts nowadays.  It made me laugh, it made me rage, and it certainly made me feel for the characters in this game.

Go pick this up. You will not be disappointed. The game may be short, but it is well-made and it's very clear that a lot of thought went into the making of it.

reviewText:
It's almost impossible to even try and start to put how amazing this game is into words.

Gonna be honest here, at first, I was an ignorant pleb and had no idea what this game's deal was, so naturally, I just began to talk down on it as if it was a terrible game or something. One day I saw a family member playing it and I was fascinated for some reason.

So I immediately went to my room, bought the game, and sat down for a session.

What entailed next was quite possibly the best experience I've ever had with gaming in my entire life.

At first I wasn't into it, and I was honestly thinking about a refund, but as I kept pushing, I found myself even more captivated minute by minute.

For starters, just the concept of the game is amazing, and it's one of the most unique I've seen in a long time. The fact that you can literally play through an entire game without having to hurt a single soul and progress? Amazing. The fact that each enemy you fight has its own attack styles and problems for you to solve? Amazing.

The soundtrack is so good that I find myself at any given point in the day just humming any song that pops in my head from the game, and I mean any. Each song is so catchy and unique that there is no way that you would be able to forget any of them.

The CHARACTERS. This is where the game shines. Ranging from Goatmom to your best friend Flowey the Flower, you meet a cast of the most lovable and relatable characters I've seen in gaming, and I'm not lying; why do you think there's such a massive fanbase backing this game?

And finally the story. At first, you're just given basic exposition about why the monsters and humans are in a clash, and why you've fallen into Mt. Ebott, but as you progress through the game, you're thrown into a massive arc which involves more characters and feels than you'd think, all the while dealing small-scale with meeting new characters and learning what they're all about, which involves you in a more personal aspect of the game.

I know I didn't go into really any detail at all about what I brought up, but that's for good reason. Seriously, this is a game you have to experience on your own, and I'd rather not spoil someone's time by going into specifics about why the story is good or about why the characters are amazing. You simply just need to play it to see it in its full glory.

BUY THIS GAME.

reviewText:
An emotionally powerful experience unlike any other, Undertale is one of the best examples of video games as a capable storytelling medium, able to tell a tale in a unique way unlike any other art form.

If a comparison is necessary to understand this game, the best I can offer is that of a love child between indie classic Cave Story and the cult-classic Nintendo series, Mother - especially Mother 3. Trying to describe the game too heavily, though, does it a disservice. The best thing I can suggest is that this is an RPG where you can save or kill any enemy. Anything more will simply make the game worse.

If you pick it up, do the best you can to keep yourself unspoiled. Avoid looking up hints online whenever possible, as usually the game gives you suggestions if you keep trying.

Above all, stay determined! You have the power to keep going.

reviewText:
Undertale is a wonderful game that taught me many things:
> You can make friends in the strangest of places.
> Anyone can be a good person if they try hard enough.
> Not all problems can be solved with violence.
> If you deliberately hurt other then YOU'RE GONNA HAVE A BAD TIME.
and finally, the most important lesson:
> NEVER TRUST A FLOWER WITH A FACE!!!!

Overall Undertale is a brilliant shining star of a game that proves gameplay and graphics aren't what counts, but how deeply the story stays with someone and the fact that humans can produce A LOT of tears...

reviewText:
Having played this game fills me with determination.
Never before have I grown so attached to a Sansational skeleton and his Pastamancer brother. If you haven't yet, I highly recommend that you give Undertale a try.

My Undertale experience? I'd seen some videos and it looked kinda fun, but playing it myself? I wasn't planning on it, but when a friend gave me a copy I decided to give it a fair shot. I started off uncertain, not sure if this was the game for me, but I soon came to love every bit of it. From the characters to the combat system to the random elements thrown in, I loved it all. Tibia honest, I was really sad to see it end after doing a neutral and pacifist run (I could never do genocide). I wish to play more yet at the same time I don't want to ruin my perfect happy ending. So, for me, my Undertale journey is over, but I will never forget it. It was a pun-tastic experience that I will always cherish.

Goodbye Undertale. Farewell Sans, Papyrus and all my cool friends. I choose to let you live on in peace and freedom rather than trapping you Underground forever.
It's painful to say goodbye to something you don't want to let go.
But it's more painful to ask something to stay if you know they really want to go.

reviewText:
Undertale is a fantastic, thought provoking, hilarious, depressing, and overall insanely enjoyable game. The music is outstanding (but people need to chill with the whole 'undertale has the best music of all time' thing, it doesn't). It's something you will invest your emotions into, and it knows that. This game will break you. It certainly broke me, I almost felt what humans call 'feelings.' Weird, right? I played this game like *spoilers spoilers spoilers* and 2 hours later I felt like a giant piece of ♥♥♥♥. Choices matter. A lot. Everything you do has an impact on the final outcome of the game, and it makes it all the more worth it.

I'm going to give this game the highest rating out of any game I'd played that came out in 2015. I'd almost give this game the highest rating that I've ever given a game. It's fantastic enough to earn a 10/10, but I'm giving it a 9/10. Now that's not bad at all. I've only given one game a 10/10 rating EVER. 9/10 is ♥♥♥♥ing generous coming from someone like me who hates video games. It's my second favorite game to have come out in 2015, ironically sitting behind Killing Floor 2.

So why did I give it a 9/10 I don't hear you ask? Well, the internet has ♥♥♥♥ing RUINED this game. On the game front it has very few, if any flaws AT ALL. It's damned near perfect, However the fanbase and what the internet has made it out to be is just too ♥♥♥♥ing awful to ignore. The Undertale fanbase is so ♥♥♥♥ing awful, that I'd say it's significantly worse than FNAF and Minecraft. The best way I could describe the fanbase is Five Night's at Freddy's fanbase, only 1 year older, and much less mature. It makes sense, trust me. The fans are rabid as ♥♥♥♥, and it turned me off of the game almost entirely. I made a negative comment on an Undertale video that had nothing to do with the game, but a song in the game, and I got a DEATH THREAT because of it. (I'm not kidding, gyazo.com/feb1e8214b52b33115fa5a271eb41df7 <- screenshot). Memes aren't funny, especially stupid ♥♥♥♥ing video game memes. Also, something being random doesn't make it funny. It's ♥♥♥♥ing stupid when people say the humor is good for being random." And when the internet finally realizes that
date: the fanbase will be slightly less cancerous than Furious Pete's crotch.\n\nThat's really all I can say about the game without spoiling it. And believe me

reviewText: Undertale has a whole lot going on.  It leans heavily on being both charming and whimsical, while simultaneously being a commentary on video games and players.  And to its credit, Undertale lives this double life quite well.  In my opinion, it’s able to do this so well by spending an incredible amount of effort was put into the characters and creatures throughout Undertale and in making them likable, and then making any commentary or fourth wall breaks be rooted in who these characters are.\n\nIt’s sort of a cousin to both Earthbound and the Stanley Parable that’s roommates with Abed from Community and Bat-Mite from The Brave and the Bold.  It may not be right for everyone, but I found it just right for me.  And I hope you do too.

reviewText: I refuse to believe Undertale is  just  a game. For one thing, no other game made me feel the way this one does. I bought the game one day and played through a little bit of it, and it honestly reminded me of the game The Stanley Parable, in which you can pretty much do what you like with no regards for rules that are around in nearly every other game. Undertale gives you a lot of freedom in the choices you make. If you went through this completely blind (as in, you've never heard of it before and know nothing about it, which is likely impossible by now), you'd probably learn a lot about yourself based on the actions you take. The thing I love the most about this game is that there are  real  consequences for the things you do. It's not like other games where they have moral choices" which are blatantly obvious
date: and the results of your choice change maybe one or two things in the end.\n\nUndertale makes you really live with what you do. For example

reviewText:
Most would call it tranquil, I suppose, if not a tad foreboding. Darkened corridors, illuminated by the light of some strange genus of flower, are interspersed between calming, wondrous caverns flowing with glimmering waters. A strange, vaguely lightbulb-shaped creature asks me what a star is. “Can you touch it? Can you eat it?”,  it inquires. “Can you kill it?” There’s a pause. “Are you a star?” The monsters of the Underground haven’t seen the stars in generations, after all, so it’s unlikely this thing would know anything about them. Littering the walls of the jewel scrawled caves of Waterfall are many plaques, inscribed with the depressing history of monsterkind. They detail the sudden attack from the humans, the one-sided massacre of a war that ensued; the mystifying nature of the SOUL. Not long after, you bump into a monster. 'Wosh u leg' the birdbath-like creature exclaims; before swiftly and dutifully beginning to wash a pizza.

And that’s the general tone that Undertale sets from the get-go.

REVIEW
Undertale

GENRE
RPG?

Developed almost entirely by award-winning Earthbound mod creator and webcomic composer Toby Fox; Undertale is a (mostly) joyous romp through the otherwise depressing yet quirky land of monsters. The opening cutscene details the legend of Mt Ebott, a forsaken mountain whose travellers are said to never return from. The year is 201X, and a small child, presumably looking for shelter from the rain, wanders into an opening at the peak. Whilst exploring the inside of the cavern, they stumble on some vines, sending them tumbling far, far down into Ebott. As luck would have it, they land on a well maintained bed of golden flowers. It just so happens that this child is you, you blundering ninny! [Why would you ever climb a mountain like that? Really!] Thus, your tale begins; your, uh, Undertale! [I tried, okay?]

Moving on from my half-hearted attempts at humor, let’s talk about Undertale’s pull; its unique combat system and genuine, heartwarming humor. Sure, it has the usual RPG ensemble of combat mechanics; fight, items, flee, etc., but what truly sets Undertale apart from other games of its genre is the ACT menu. As you’ve probably seen from the trailer, the game’s description, or the blurb that sits alongside the game’s picture; the tagline of Undertale is: ‘The friendly RPG where nobody has to die!’ True to its word, Undertale is a game where not a single creature has to die; I repeat,  not a single creature has to die. [That is, unless you want to have a BAD TIME.] This is where the ACT menu plays a part. Each enemy presents their own puzzle for you to solve during combat, and as the game puts it itself: “If you ACT a certain way or FIGHT until you almost defeat them (Monsters)... they might not want to battle you anymore.”

This also ties into the game’s humor quite well, as, aside from the many fantastic puns and brick jokes, the ‘hostile’ encounters with the residents of the Underground are usually chock full of it. In the aforementioned Waterfall, there exists a monster named Aaron; a deliberately creepy literal seahorse who is muscular beyond reason. All of his dialogue ends in winky faces, even when he’s as scared out of his mind as he is ripped. On the topic of Aaron’s veterinary need for his sick pythons, the ACT menu allows you to foolishly challenge this apparent god of muscles to a flexing competition. While I say foolishly, it’s the pacifist’s way of beating this beefcake. Flex thrice and the equine epitome of energy will flex so hard that he flexes himself out of the room. Yes, I’m being serious, and that’s just one of the many interactions with the monsters of Undertale.

“But what about the defensive side of the combat?”, you’d ask. “I was just about to start on that, you impatient little nerd.”, I’d respond. Much like you’d see in a game of Touhou [Or so I’ve been told, I’ve never played Touhou.], enemy’s attacks are presented as bullethell-esque challenge. You move your SOUL around a small boxed in region while your foe throws a variety of little, white ‘friendliness pellets’ which you must avoid; unless of course you like dying. Each monster provides its own unique pattern to dodge and adding more monsters to the equation only helps to further enhance the difficulty, as the monsters will combine their attacks into a completely new one. Heck, to take it another step further, the titular boss monster encounters can sometimes change the way you control your SOUL entirely. Sometimes you’ll be affected by gravity, forcing you to jump over dangerous obstacles; other times you’ll confined to a set of three pathways which you must swap in between to evade danger. Most importantly though, remember; blue stop signs.
So that’s the end of combat, and segues sure are hard; aren’t they? Speaking of segues, I just made a half-♥♥♥♥♥ one into the soundtrack section of this review. Neat, right? The soundtrack of Undertale is phenomenal, and I can without a doubt say that Toby’s reputation as a composer utterly precedes him. From the subtle uneasiness of ‘Your Best Friend’ to the bombastic whimsy of ‘Nyeh Heh Heh!’, the many fantastic songs of Undertale could only be described as unique. Personally, my favorite song from the OST is ‘Dummy!’ a hyperactive remix of the uniquely Undertale ‘Ghost Fight’. [Yes, I described it as uniquely Undertale; it fits the style of the game to a T.] Each song fits its situation perfectly, and, if you’re unfortunate enough, you might just uncover a certain someone’s calling card.

Aside from the audible presentation of Undertale; the visual presentation, while not too terribly complicated, is utterly intriguing. When you encounter a monster, the world becomes monochrome, aside from your SOUL; still a warming shade of red. Color is scarcely used in combat; reserved for truly singular spectacles or small, oft unnoticed details. A dark shade of crimson can barely be seen in a particular monster’s eyes, though you reaaally have to be looking to notice it. Outside of combat, the world is vibrant, colorful, expressive. The lovingly-crafted pixel art paints a picture of an expansive underground community, lively and fun; although sometimes dark and ominous if need be.

AVAST YE, POSSIBLE SPOILERS BELOWAnd that’s the truly astonishing thing about Undertale, it knows what it wants to be; it knows how to be itself. Over the course of my journey I was thrown through a whiplash of emotions and events, each delivered with the utmost sincerity and expertise. Many a hearty laugh came from the surprises Undertale had cooked up for those expecting something they'd played before. You're expected it to play like you would any other RPG you've played, and the game decides to play you instead; to take your preconceptions and mess with their very being. I find that if you let the game take your hand, let it guide you down this archaic, joyful, tragic, melancholic, path of madness; you'll come out better for it. Not many games can make you truly feel that child-like whimsy of playing your first game, of learning to love your hobby all over again; even fewer can make you truly attached to the characters of its world. I'll admit, I got a bit misty-eyed when my journey had reached its end, when I looked back at all the good times I had with these lines of code I’d come to know as friends. Undertale is a game that sets itself apart from the rest, a game that knows how to be how to be uniquely Undertale. One moment, I’m traversing a luminescent grotto; solemnly listening to the hopes and dreams of the species my kind has imprisoned for centuries.

The next, I'm getting lessons on hygiene from a washing machine and its bird.

reviewText:
If you're late to the Undertale party like I was, you may only know of this game for some awkward moments, witty one-liners, or even a few memes. Rest assured, they're all here, but there is much more below the surface.

What truly set Undertale apart for me was the overwhelming amount of love and care poured into it. Don't let the graphic style fool you; this game more than makes up for it with its memorable and relatable characters, incredibly catchy soundtrack, consistently unique battles, and an attention to detail that would make any fan of the Mother series proud.

On top of all this, the most engaging aspect of Undertale is the fact that there are always multiple solutions to any problem or opponent you face. The decision is yours to make as a player, and you only have yourself to praise/blame for the results of your actions. This game's unique take on the traditional/expected RPG was wonderfully refreshing.

My only piece of advice if you are considering this game for purchase is to avoid spoilers at all costs. Undertale is a game that is best experienced for yourself!

reviewText:
Undertale is what all modern RPGs should aim to be like, this game has set the new bar.

It replaces the usual grindy turn based style of RPG combat into an interactive bullet hell minigame that lets your level scale at a natural pace. It's a good RPG for this fact alone. Besides this, there's engaging and unique ways to spare every enemy you come across which contributes towards several different endings as well as affecting the entire world around you as you progress. Truly the only game in the last year to understand the morality principle in video games and make it feel satisfying.

Undertale features a magnificent story with compelling characters that continues to unravel over multiple playthroughs and changes depending on what you've already accomplsihed. Great humor akin to Earthbound and because the game is short and the world is small every corner of the game is rammed with detail.

Indie Game of the Year!

reviewText:
I received Undertale as part of a Secret Santa gift swap, but it's been as cheap as $7.99 at the time of this writing.  It took me around 6.7 hours to get one ending and around 10.7 hours to get another.  I played pacifist from beginning to end since I figured, why not?  The game's description outright says you don't have to destroy anyone, so I thought I'd see how that would go.  And I enjoyed my experience.

The backstory involves a war between humans and monsters that the monsters lost, resulting in a magical barrier to keep them trapped underground that humans can freely cross.  You are a human child who climbs a forbidden mountain and winds up tumbling into the world below, thus starting the plot.  I won't say anything more.  I know with most games, you're encouraged to go in blindly so that your reactions to what all happens is most genuine, but I'd honestly encourage you to try and avoid spoilers before playing.  And that's rather difficult given the game's popularity, so good luck.

I honestly did laugh a few times during the game.  It's seriously weird at times, silly, goofy too.  Some of the characters have...colorful personalities, and there are some great situations I find myself in too.  But that's how the game went when I was peaceful.  There are largely three routes with playing the game, between being completely peaceful, being completely violent, or some mix of the two, and the game will react to your actions, so that's something to consider when you start.

Undertale is probably one of the more unique games I've ever played.  It fancies itself as an RPG, and while it does have random encounters and stats and equipment and healing items and so on, I'd honestly say it plays a bit more like a puzzle game.  That comes in more if you decide to be a pacifist, since you have to figure out how to get the monster to become Spareable through various context-sensitive actions.  It's somewhat reminiscient of Shin Megami Tensei's demon contacting feature, though you're always given the same options for each specific monster type, and the 'solution' to the fight is the same for each copy you encounter.  Unlike in SMT, you won't invariably anger monsters by trying the same dialog options that worked before or whatever.  Of course, you can just cut the knot instead and kill the monster if you want.

The combat system also incorporates a unique dodge mechanic.  Unlike regular RPGs where dodging is based on stats or equipment, you physically get out of the way of attacks.  That in itself isn't novel, but how many RPGs have elements of bullet hells?  You control a tiny red heart during the monsters' turn and you're given a field you can move within to dodge their attacks.  It sounds and is simplistic at first, but of course the game adds new elements to keep you on your toes.  Most of the boss fights introduce a gimmick and you have to quickly learn how to work with it and still avoid getting hit.

The encounter rate I thought was on the low side.  Fights in this game use invisible random encounters so you can't just avoid monsters or lure them away from where you need to go, but the fights are nowhere near as frequent as some of the RPGs from ages past.  This can be good or bad depending on how you're approaching the game, but I kinda liked not tripping over a mook every three feet.

On the difficulty side, I thought it was about middle-of-the-road.  I had to look up solutions to beat two of the bosses, mostly because I ignored what the game needed me to know.  Whoops.  For the puzzles, they were a little harder than what I'm used to in other games, but I didn't have to look up help for them.  The game does throw quite a few at you, but it never got to the point where I was annoyed at facing yet another one.

On the visual side, Undertale works a neo-retro style with pixel graphics reminscient of SNES games.  During battle, monsters show up in two-bit black and white, stark contrast to them appearing fully-colored in the field.  Characters have their portrait in dialog boxes and their expression will change to reflect their moods since the character sprites are generally not detailed enough to show these.  Some characters also use completely different fonts when talking, so that was an interesting feature.

For audio...well, a lot of people say it has a great soundtrack and I agree.  Music uses cues from chiptunes though it's not all beeps and bloops.  Some of the songs are another song either sped up or slowed down, sometimes with different instruments.  You usually wouldn't notice this.  Sound effects were there, though each speaking character had their own sound effect to go with their text appearing, giving them a type of 'voice' so that was a cool touch.

If you have an open mind and are willing to try something different, I think you'd like Undertale.  Someone going in expecting a typical RPG might be annoyed at the character personalities when they the player plays nicely, but that's why there's always the option to just be a typical RPG protagonist, right?  You'd like it a lot better if you're already familiar with RPGs already since you otherwise wouldn't know the concepts that the game addresses and uses and turns on their heads.  So not a great game to break into the genre with.  And despite its cutesy appearance, I wouldn't recommend it for young kids.  It might look sweet and innocent on the outside, especially given the gentle nudge for not hurting anyone, but...

Also, there's a demo on the official website.  It's not 1:1, but it'll give you an idea of what to expect, how the battles work, and so on.  If you're interested, it might be worth a try, though I never tried it out because...I didn't know it existed.  Whoops.

Anyway, I really did enjoy my time with Undertale, though I don't think I'll be taking it for a spin again anytime soon.  I have a perfectly valid reason for that.

reviewText:
Okay, i finished the game as the true-good guy and as the bad guy.
Time to write a review.

Is this game overrated? Yes, it's overrated af.
Don't get me wrong, it's still a good game, but only if you dive into this world.
And start care about reviews with more than 10 H. of gameplay.

Good.

- Soundtrack !
- Art/ graphic
- Humor
- Mostly created by one person
- Price
- Fight system
- Boss fights
- NPC´s

Neutral.
Why i make a neutral section? Because ~70% of the games story, secrets, friendships etc. are hidden really good.
It's like the the game is made for discover and RPG nerds, i had to use the wiki alot to get everything and i'm still confused about the story. So the neutral section is GOOD but only if you dive deep into the game and i think that's not a thing for everyone. When you just rush through the game, you will be 100% disappointed.

- Story
- Friends, enemys and bosses
- Different paths
- Secrets
- Eastereggs

Bad.

- Less RPG than i expected
- The gain of knowledge in the game, to complete everything
voteText: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I was really sceptical of all the love this game was getting, I'm not the biggest fan of the Mother series, for instance.

But.

I tried it and it proved to be disarmingly charming.
And then really funny.
And then really, really engaging.
And wonderfully magical.
And thoroughly moving.

And then it gets close to the end, and it transforms into something even greater.

And then it ends, and you load your save again, and it pauses, raises its head, and soars.

It transcends into something else, something beyond, and it's so powerful and amazing and wonderful and complete, you will just sit there like an idiot for ten minutes after the final screen has rolled up.

And you will rush to steam to give it a glowing review cause it's just so special you want the world to know.

So here I am.

Please play it.

It's.. special.
voteText: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Much to say, but to keep it simple (and spoiler free):

Blew my mind, and a true gem among Indie games. You can't go wrong picking up this title; This has literally been my favorite game of 2015 so far.
- A bullet-hell game that brings a well-written story without the need of high-quality graphics.
- Choices affect the game (and the game knows when you try to change it).
- Multiple endings can make for as many playthroughs as you want. Perhaps even extra runs to explore every little detail you can find.

An enjoyable RPG that lasts about 4~8 hours for a first time playthrough. Saying too much gives away parts of the story.

10/10. Recommending to anyone with an interest in RPGs or Earthbound-like wackiness.

reviewText:
Knowing that you might read this review and play this wonderful, incredible, and unique experience fills me with determination.

I've never played anything like this game. It's smart, funny, and heartwarming (unless you choose to take a terrible path). If you like old school turn-based RPGs and humorous dialogue in the vein of Earthbound, please, do yourself a favor and give it a try. It's really hard to explain what's so great about it, honestly. The characters, music, and dialogue easily rank amongst my favorites in any video games ever. It's top tier and quality work across all those categories. You can tell love was poured into every ounce of this game. I can't reccommend it enough. Play this game. Make choices. Make friends. Or enemies (you heartless scum).

p.s. ANIME'S REAL, RIGHT?!?!

10/10.

reviewText: This game is a piece of art that everyone in their lives needs to play at least once. Do the true pacifist run first, not the genocide run. Determination is the main thought of this game and it plays to that so well. The combat system is cool and different, it's like a toned down bullet hell. Undertale is probably one of the more unique games I've ever played.  It fancies itself as an RPG, and while it does have random encounters and stats and equipment and healing items and so on, I'd honestly say it plays a bit more like a puzzle game.  That comes in more if you decide to be a pacifist, since you have to figure out how to get the monster to become Spareable through various context-sensitive actions.  It's somewhat reminiscient of Shin Megami Tensei's demon contacting feature, though you're always given the same options for each specific monster type, and the 'solution' to the fight is the same for each copy you encounter.  Unlike in SMT, you won't invariably anger monsters by trying the same dialog options that worked before or whatever.  Of course, you can just cut the knot instead and kill the monster if you want.

The combat system also incorporates a unique dodge mechanic.  Unlike regular RPGs where dodging is based on stats or equipment, you physically get out of the way of attacks.  That in itself isn't novel, but how many RPGs have elements of bullet hells?  You control a tiny red heart during the monsters' turn and you're given a field you can move within to dodge their attacks.  It sounds and is simplistic at first, but of course the game adds new elements to keep you on your toes.  Most of the boss fights introduce a gimmick and you have to quickly learn how to work with it and still avoid getting hit.

The encounter rate I thought was on the low side.  Fights in this game use invisible random encounters so you can't just avoid monsters or lure them away from where you need to go, but the fights are nowhere near as frequent as some of the RPGs from ages past.  This can be good or bad depending on how you're approaching the game, but I kinda liked not tripping over a mook every three feet.

On the difficulty side, I thought it was about middle-of-the-road.  I had to look up solutions to beat two of the bosses, mostly because I ignored what the game needed me to know.  Whoops.  For the puzzles, they were a little harder than what I'm used to in other games, but I didn't have to look up help for them.  The game does throw quite a few at you, but it never got to the point where I was annoyed at facing yet another one.

On the visual side, Undertale works a neo-retro style with pixel graphics reminscient of SNES games.  During battle, monsters show up in two-bit black and white, stark contrast to them appearing fully-colored in the field.  Characters have their portrait in dialog boxes and their expression will change to reflect their moods since the character sprites are generally not detailed enough to show these.  Some characters also use completely different fonts when talking, so that was an interesting feature.

For audio...well, a lot of people say it has a great soundtrack and I agree.  Music uses cues from chiptunes though it's not all beeps and bloops.  Some of the songs are another song either sped up or slowed down, sometimes with different instruments.  You usually wouldn't notice this.  Sound effects were there, though each speaking character had their own sound effect to go with their text appearing, giving them a type of 'voice' so that was a cool touch.

If you have an open mind and are willing to try something different, I think you'd like Undertale.  Someone going in expecting a typical RPG might be annoyed at the character personalities when they the player plays nicely, but that's why there's always the option to just be a typical RPG protagonist, right?  You'd like it a lot better if you're already familiar with RPGs already since you otherwise wouldn't know the concepts that the game addresses and uses and turns on their heads.  So not a great game to break into the genre with.  And despite its cutesy appearance, I wouldn't recommend it for young kids.  It might look sweet and innocent on the outside, especially given the gentle nudge for not hurting anyone, but...

Also, there's a demo on the official website.  It's not 1:1, but it'll give you an idea of what to expect, how the battles work, and so on.  If you're interested, it might be worth a try, though I never tried it out because...I didn't know it existed.  Whoops.

Anyway, I really did enjoy my time with Undertale, though I don't think I'll be taking it for a spin again anytime soon.  I have a perfectly valid reason for that.

reviewText:
Undertale, the game where the only thing wrong with it is the fanbaseYou can only hate this game for two reasons: one, if you don't like pixel games; or two, if you've stumbled upon the fandom.

Much like in every successful indie game ever, the fanbase is filled with these kinds of people:
The rabid ones, unable to control their rage when the game is criticized and feeling the constant need to defend it
The vocal ones, unable to shut the hell up in every game discussion, pushing their love for Undertale, even if the game has no place in the discussion
The autistic ones, spouting references all over the internet, roleplaying in public, talking with asterisks and dedicating their entire virtual lives to the game
The weird ones, drawing pornography of the characters and writing erotic fanfiction about them
And last but not least: the moderate ones, the minority, enjoying the game for what it is, drawing lovely fan art and keeping to themselves without bothering anyone elseSo... long story short, if the fanbase is keeping you from enjoying this game, I suggest you to look past it and play it. Undertale isn't the second coming of Jesus (as most reviews paint it) but it's a good game. Here is my review.

✓ Great soundtrack (seriously, I literally bought it for the soundtrack)
✓ Good story
✓ Reference humor (some people say it's over the top; apparently they never played Borderlands 2)

✗ Capped at 30fps (before you say anything: NES games ran at 60fps)
✗ You can't take screenshots
✗ Lacks basic elements like a main menu/options

I don't wanna spoil anything about the story, but the game rewards you with feels if you take the 'goodie' route (no fights/aggressivity). You can choose to be a genocidal maniac as well, but I've heard the ending is not as good if you do so.

Overall grade: 8/10

reviewText:
For ten euro, there's so much to pick up from this game. Undertale isn't your traditional pick up, play and put back in your shelf game. Partly because it's only avaliable digitaly, but mainly because It's a game that sticks to you. And impacts you.
The world of Undertale is alive. It's breathing. And by alive, I don't mean the game world is huge, or looks impressing graphically. Quite the opposite actually. The game world in itself isn't impressing in scale, and the game looks like a game straight from the SNES era. What truly makes the world of Undertale feel so alive is it's characters and world-building.
Every character is so lovable, charming and distinct to the point where you almost view them as real persons. And the writing in the game is so fantastic, it's hard to stop playing or thinking about Undertale once you're hooked. The characters actually remember your actions and reacts to them, just like a real person would do. The characters are some of the most lovable in a video-game, and it explains the endless stream of fan-fiction and fan-art for the characters of Undertale. Undertale is the kind of game where you loose yourself in the experience, loose track of time and absolutely love it. Or hate it. Depending on YOUR actions.
And that brings me to my next point.
Undertale is a game where you make choices. Real, heavy choices. And the choices you make actually matter. Not just within the next ten minutes of gameplay, but for the whole experience. As I said, the characters remember everything you do. The game has no less than three diffrent endings, each one playing out significantly diffrent compared to the others. To understand the full plot, and the full greatness of Undertale you have to get all of them. The replay-value is fantastic.
The consequence of such a living world, meaningfull choices and so lovable characters makes for a game incredibly easy to immerse yourself into. And Undertale abuses this to the max.
Did I meantion that the writing in this game is incredible? It really is. I meant it.
The story has so many twists and turns and breaks the norm in so many ways, to the point that you never know what's gonna happen next. This game has some of the absolute most hearth-wrenching and hearth-warming moments in video-game history, and often you don't even see them coming. I wont spoil anything, but this game will make you laugh through your tears.
As you may have heard, I've mentioned the word experience many times throughout this review. And that's because that's just what Undertale is. This game will make you love yourself. Or absolutely hate yourself. The game toys with your feelings, and it's fantastic.
But what about the gameplay?
Well, Undertale surely doesn't dissapoint.
The combat system is fast-paced and robust, with each fight being like a puzzle on it's own depending on how you choose to handle the situation. The way you fight also change drasticly depending on which enemy or boss you're fighting, which makes every fight memorable.
And oh, did I meantion this game has a killer soundtrack? The game's tracks fit their scenes perfectly, and are a huge part of the game. The games track contributes to the experience immensly, and makes the emotional moments of Undertale hit even harder. Which is a rare thing these days. The boss tracks are also some of the most epic, awesome, hearth-pumping tracks I've ever heard.

Just listen to some of these tracks. Seriously.

Heartily recommended, buy it!

reviewText:
This is a game about a poor innocent human Childe, trapped in some kind of heretical hellhole. He is forced to enact Exterminatus upon the daemonic monsters and heretics of Undertale in the name of the Emperor, all on his own. However, the Emperor protects and the Childe prevails.

As far as JRPGs go, this is certainly one of the more challenging ones. The first two bosses are deceptively easy, but they get noticeably tougher later on, after you face a fishwoman spawned by Cthulhu himself. In the games climax, you face a Skeletal Monster who tapped into the very depths of The Warp for some insanely overpowered moves. But with Faith in the Emperor and a bit of tinkering with Cheat Engine tee hee :^) even a Child can prevail, proving once again the superiority of Humanity over monstrous abominations.

7/10, it was ok.

reviewText:
Quite literally the most beautiful game i've ever had the pleasure of playing through. This game takes you through a unique, heart warming, and utterly heartbreaking story the likes of which I haven't seen done as well in any other video game. The JRPG nature of the game should not come as a concern to those who are not fans of the genre (I personally hate them) as Undertale meerly takes the frame work of the genre while adding its own twists to the mix (It breaks up the turn taking aspect with a sort of SHMUP like mini-game during the transitions).

Even if the main combat-based gameplay can become a little frusterating at times, down to it's core this game is about it's atmosphere and story, both of which will suck you right in as you find yourself utterly engrossed in this game's (under)tale.

I can't say enough good things about this game. Any game that makes me  cry like a little ♥♥♥♥♥  is a instant favourite and this is one quickly became one of my favourite games of all time.

Try it then buy it. It will live long as it does already; as an absolute classic and masterpiece.

reviewText:
Two words of advice for potential players before going forward with the review:
- EVERY battle can be ended without killing the enemy. Sometimes you need to select the right actions; sometimes you need to run and reposition yourself outside of battle; sometimes you just need to wait X number of turns.
- DO NOT SPOIL YOURSELF! There are few guides right now (the game is less than a week old), but reading discussions or wikis or guides will ruin a lot of the fun. Play through once or twice, then look online.

On to the review; minor spoilers ahead!

TL;DR:
Pros:

-Humor
-Music
-Characters
-Some creative puzzles
-Non-violence mechanics
-Bullet hell" dodge mechanic

Cons:

-Morality system may lock you out of some endings even on future playthroughs
-Choosing a pacifist run means you miss much of the RPG aspect
-Graphic style is simplistic (I liked it

column38: a huge amount of expression and emotion is conveyed.\n\nThe only negativity I have has to do with the RPG aspects. Dishonored had the same problem - if you're doing a no-kill run
column39: you won't be diving into the RPG aspects as much and thus avoid much of that part of the game. I'll be honest; this felt like more of a puzzle game with a dodge mechanic than an RPG when played this way. Your weapon will hardly matter (mostly only for added effects
column40: like additional invincibility time after being hit
column42: you won't look at your stats
column43: and there's no grinding because your money will only be spent on low-level healing items since your max HP never increases. I feel that
column45: you're forced to avoid some of the core parts of the game for some of the lore parts
column46: if that makes sense. In some ways it's worse because at least in Dishonored you could always start another run and go just for killing. In Undertale
column47: doing so may very well screw over your future runs.\n\nIn conclusion... buy the game. Yes
column48: the reviews right now are overwhelmingly positive because mostly only fans and followers know about it. But I anticipate that they'll remain highly positive even months from now. The game is just SO good. And while it's somewhat short (maybe 6-8 hours for a run through)
column49: I have no doubt that I'll replay it at least twice more."

reviewText:
Undertale succeeds in something that surprisingly few tripple A titles manages to get right - characters, story, and meaningful choices. When you make choices, you feel in control, and getting a good resolution to the story feels like an accomplishment, and not marely a sleepwalk. The gameplay is great in its simplicity, and there is no surprise that Toby Fox is able to deliver a great soundtrack as well. Don't be fooled by the simplistic graphics in the screenshots - it's a stylistic choice, not an indication of terrible graphics. With one of the best endings to a game I've seen in a LONG time, Toby Fox delivers on his kickstarter promises. This is not just an extension of the demo, this is he real deal. Strong game of the year contender for me - and considering what else is being released this year, that is not small praise.

Undertale: 9.5/10
- Excellently written 3-dimensional characters
- Deep, impactful story, where you feel in control
- One of the best endings to a game that I've ever seen

reviewText:
So I've been around for the Demo, and this was actually the first game I have ever backed on KickStarter, and let me tell you something:

At no point does this game ever disappoint.

How do I know that? Here's a list:

1. Dating Skeletons? Check. Dating a Lizard nerd? Check. Making friends with a fishwoman? Check!
2. Bullet hell that's actually fun instead of frustrating! No need to be a Touhou Weirdo to enjoy this game!
3. A very encouraging atmosphere, where even the lowliest of garbage can take selfies and feel good about oneself.
4. A bigger, more well-written plot twist than from the likes of Sir Shyamalan!
5. DOGS!!!!
6. SERIOUSLY THERE IS A DOG YOU PET HIM AND IT'S ALL D'AWWWWW
7. STUPENDOUS soundtrack, I'm glad I backed the KS tier to get that. Easily worth the 25$ I shelled out.
8. So many endings! I mean I've only seen one, but the way this moral choice thing is done I'm sure they've got one for every part of the Lawful-Neutral-Chaotic" Spectrum.
9. Everyone is cute and smoochable.
10. Yes even the bad guy maybe this review's getting weird?
11. Puzzles! Everyone loves those.

The list goes on and on. In conclusion

recommended: you are severely missing out and

reviewText:
Alright, I'll give this one a go. Before I dive too far into it, I feel I should be clear: I love this game. It's been weeks since I've finished it and I still catch myself listening to the soundtrack or looking up fan art. An 'undertale remix' search on Youtube is one of the first 'u' urls in my browser (which should be distressing but somehow isn't).

Because I love it though, I want to try to lay out clearly what it is and what it's not. I didn't follow Undertale until the pre-launch trailer went up and it got my attention; I didn't play it until a friend started it up and gave me all the details I needed to know I had to play it. So I want anyone who considers this game to come at it ignoring the hype surrounding it, if that's at all possible.

Pros:

- The soundtrack is pretty rad. I think we can objectively agree on this, right? I guess if a kinda SNES/chiptuney aesthetic turns you off, it might not be for you - Toby, in my experience, obviously goes all in for that stylistically. It's more than that but I'm really not qualified to do music critique.

- I'd be inclined to say the same goes for the visuals. I've seen potshots that it's more of this sort of you made it in an old-school way because you can't do any better
date:
and while that can hold true if you're burned out by this sort of thing, I think Toby comes by the style pretty honestly. It's artistically sort of like if someone took Earthbound's artistic sensibilities and used it to flesh out a dream-y kind of Yume Nikki aesthetic full of neat setpieces. If that and a general kind of old school look don't work for you, there's not much else I can say.

- Gameplay is more involved and fun than the RPG Maker games I know I had in mind when I was thinking about buying this. There's a standard sort of turn-based menu selection element at play, but the shmup-y gameplay that occurs when you're trying not to get hit is done well. You'll notice it less depending on how you play the game but with boss battles, the game whips out some neat tricks to change how fights operate. I'd be lying if I said it's a profound, fantastic, super great system, but for what it is, it's done well and I believe should keep most people more invested than just clicking a button and smacking things (although you can certainly do that as well).

- The game advertises itself as a game where you don't have to kill anybody, and it takes that idea as far as it can go. Sometimes it even takes it farther than you'd think it could. I don't want to comment extensively on it and risk ruining it, but Undertale plays the implications behind level grinding incredibly straight. The moments where you're figuring out whether and how to spare an enemy are the most praiseworthy parts of how the game is put together. There is at least one encounter I drove myself nuts over because of my absolute unwillingness to fight back and for a game to do that to me is one of the better things I can say.

- This is a vague one, but: Undertale is not afraid to make narrative use of its medium. It's best you find out exactly how for yourself, but I would go so far as to say the particular ways in which Undertale tells its story are THE draw and what distinguishes it from the games it's influenced by.


These all constitute things I have a hard time imagining someone looking to get this game would dislike. What follows aren't exactly cons but they are things I would think about:

- This absolutely feels like a one man kind of show. I don't recall who else was credited, but my understanding is that Toby did more or less anything that isn't Temmie. I personally love this - I've become kind of a crank about how soulless it is for me when I can't feel any distinctive personal touch in a game - but if you don't like Toby's writing voice, you're honestly probably going to have a bad time. I think the game is incredibly funny and I'm clearly not alone in that respect. But Toby is the kind of person that will take a gag and run with it, and isn't afraid of just throwing in random stuff that's meant to be amusing because of how out there it is. If bone puns, dating sim interludes, and having an obscene amount of hot dogs stacked on your head strikes you as stupid, well, don't hold your breath for that kind of humor to ever stop.

- I'm going to go out on a limb here and guess that Toby likes JRPGs. That sounds like a no duh thing, but hear me out. If you've played a JRPG or watched anime at any point and have felt that the reliance on hope and friendship you often get with them is cheesy and/or emotionally manipulative, I don't think Undertale will change your mind. There are clever touches that it sucks I can't mention here really, but when it unloads the power of love on you, you have to have an affection or openmindedness for that sort of thing to appreciate it. If you don't, it's probably just going to leave you cold.

- From a conventional content standpoint, Undertale took me somewhere around eight or nine hours to beat and I may have taken more time than is normal. You could get more out of it depending on what kind of playthrough you do, or whether you play it again to go after a whatever other things you want to (there's a surprising amount of sort of cosmetic variability depending on how you handle sparing or killing monsters), but I had no desire to play any more after the ending I got and I mean that in a very positive sense, believe it or not.

- And staying on content, most of that time is focused on walking around, occasional random battles, easy puzzles, and interacting with a ton of NPCs. I think it's a fair asking price for what I got out of it, but if you're hoping for a low price find with lots of sidequests, replay value, challenges that will hold you up for a long time, you're going to be out of luck. There are somewhere between one to three places I would expect most people to struggle, and you really have to overacheive to run into two of them. This game is largely a brisk narrative straight shot that goes from Point A to Point B that most people should clear quickly. I like not having my time wasted with filler so shortness isn't a flaw for me if what's there is good. I think it is but maybe that won't sell you if your idea of bang for your buck is getting a lot of time out of the games you purchase.


Con:

- Nitpicky, but I want to throw this in here. The game's transition from midpoint to finale is abrupt. I had the definite sense, which I was able to ignore in the spirit of what the game was trying to do, that I was being rushed through the end towards the final set of encounters. Before the endgame, I would say Undertale is paced incredibly well. As you hit the endgame, it starts to feel like some kind of cosmic deadline was closing in. What IS there is good, but I was sort of sad to feel like I was being rushed to the conclusion of something I could have spent more time in. Read a certain way, that's almost kind of a compliment though, isn't it?


It's all kind of pedantic and I regret how poor my cutting room floor instincts are, but I think this covers it. Undertale is a game I think as many people should experience as possible. I strongly recommend it. It's made me think a lot more about what you can do in a video game than I ever have before. It also happens to be more playful and fun than a stuffy sentence like that would suggest, hahaha. I could talk a lot more about what I personally really liked but I think it wouldn't be useful to someone looking to figure out if this is the game for them or not. Whenever it happens to get discounted, if you're someone who happens to be on the fence about it, just get it. At an even lower price than $10, I have a hard time seeing how you could get absolutely nothing out of it.

Oh, and, be good, won't you?

reviewText:
I tried.

I'd been getting kind of weary of 'retro-style-pixel' games. I've become impatient with text heavy games too. I've clocked a dozen Zeldas, had enough of reading text in games, but...
I read the reviews. All positive. I held off. I read many articles hailing this game as amazing. I still thought 'it's not for me'. I saw it listed in many 'Game of the Year' articles. I caved in.
What the hell. Has to be good. Right?

Um.
I can appreciate the effort, the creativity, the humour. It's just not for me.
Maybe I'm getting old. Maybe I should have just listened to my original instinct.
Everyone else seems to like this game. You probably will too.
Then again...

reviewText:
One of the best games I have played this year. *NO SPOILERS*

Its an RPG with a massive difference which I wont go into as its better to go into this one completely blind. The fighting system is like micro-game from warioware focusing on little bullet hell games with a timing based attack system. There is also the ability to play completely passively which can be done throughout the game to every single enemy and boss.

The world of undertale is beautifully kooky and fascinatingly off the wall whilst keeping a sense of slight unease throughout.

The music rocks by the way. I almost bulked at the price of the soundtrack until I got some ways in and flooded steam with all my money and couldn't wait to slap it on all my devices.

This game is genius and shouldn't be missed out on.

reviewText:
My not very well written brief reviewAt a first glance, this game appears to be another generic RPG. Get past the first 10 seconds and you'll find this game has another, more humorous coat. Get past that and you find this game's dark side. These elements blend to deliver an interesting story with some strong messages.

Undertale has a wonderfully unique combat system, one mostly based around NOT actually fighting anything.

TL:DRThis game made me laugh a lot, cry twice, and I had a lot of fun doing it.
Play it if you  want. I'd highly recommend it.
