reviewText:
First of all, I am not a fan of RPGs myself but I do have my own exceptions. Undertale just entered in this list in the past night, as I am writting this review.

In this game, you play in the skin of a human girl that has fell into the depths of a mountain, where there is a world with monsters sealed away from the surface for many years due to a war where humans ended victorious. In order to the monsters be able to return back to the surface, they need a last human soul out of 7... and that's you. What are you going to do? Will you fight back and destroy them?... Or will you spare them with hopes they won't harm you and understand that humans aren't necessairly murderers? Well, you will be pleased to know that you can actually decide which destiny you want in this game: you can optate to kill every monster you find, you can kill ones and give mercy to others and you can give mercy to everyone. And every little action you do in the game has got consequences in the story. This is the only RPG I know where you can win without killing opponents and that was one of the main reasons I got interested in trying out this game. I went for a Pacifist Route as I really did not want to finish the life of the creatures and let survivors thinking that every human is equal and I can guarantee that your actions are rewarded in surprising ways! You also end up getting attached to the most important characters of the game as each has got a different personality and are really memorable!

Now, I will talk about the game by parts and tell what I think about each:

Story - The essence of Undertale's story is simple as I explained above but it is impressive the level of depth it has got as I can really tell that these indie developers have put a lot of thought in it not just by having experienced the game but also by informing myself on the internet about the other kind of consequences it can bring depending of other types of actions you do. There are really many different versions of the story. There's drama but there is also a lot of humour, dark humour and references to japanese culture and I promise that this game will steal you smiles and laughters!

Graphics - Other thing that pleases me in Undertale is the retro aesthetic it has got but this is just a matter of personal taste. They are pleasant and detailed. It interestingly changes to a more minimalist graphism once you enter in a battle. There's a detail that I won't develop a lot as it involves spoilers but there is a point where I really believe you will feel disturbed by the type of visual a certain monster adquires for being distinctively out of place".

Gameplay - In third person it works like a normal RPG: you wander around to explore the environments and you interact with characters to obtain informations. Ocasionally
date: you will be dragged to battle with a random monster. Fortunately
recommended: the encounters are not annoying as they do not appear a lot of times. In battle
hoursPlayed: you have four options: to fight (a graph appears and a vertical bar passes through it. The more centered the bar is by the moment you press your key
voteText: more damage you inflict)
helpfulPercent: to act (this functionality is really interesting as the secondary options that appear really depend of the monster you find
votesHelpful: and even in here the creators used a lot of humour!)
votesTotal: to use items (like in normal RPGs
votesFunny: items can be used to heal HP or to increase stats) and to give mercy (monsters will be spared from harm but it won't work unless you performed necessary actions in the Act command although this rule only applies to the majority of the monsters). The way battles work has got an original mechanism as I never saw something similar before: your soul is represented with a red heart and inside a limited area you can move it to dodge yourself from enemy attacks that vary a lot. There are occasions where you have your soul limited to specific movements too or that you are exposed to special enemy attacks that force you to either freeze yourself or to move yourself to ensure you don't get harmed. You really need to have dexterity in your fingers as some enemies attacks (especially bosses) can be really difficult to dodge. A note I would like to make is that in case you want to spare every monster
commentsCount:
is the fact that every monster you find has got a different way to be "defeated" and they are not only creative but will also surprise you and make you laugh a lot!

Controls - I don't have got a single complaint in these: they are simple and very sharp. If you are enoughly familiar with playing with a keyboard you won't have any issues.

Sound and music - Just like the graphics
column16:
these are retro-like. The sounds are varied and simple. While there is not a lot of different musical tracks in the game I found them pleasant.

Difficulty level - The level of difficulty is progressive and is challenging but not to the point of frustration.

Longevity and replay value - I finished the game in approximately 10 hours but the time of conclusion might vary depending of the player skills and the destiny you choose. It is relatively short
column17: but the fact that your actions change the whole story course gives you extra reasons to consider returning to the game and play it again.\n\nI am really happy that a game like this appeared in an industry overflooded with games with the same selling formulas and same conception formulas. It brought a completely new way to play an RPG and hooks you to the end. I do think the industry needs more games like this as with the technology evolution many game makers seem to forget what's most important in the conception of a videogame: its essence
column18: its soul.\n\nUndertale is a hidden indie gem that deserves recognization. I really can't find any complaint for it as I never found any annoyances in it nor even glitches. And this game can be yours for only 9
column20: a real bargain. Please buy it
column21: it is worth every cent. And spread the word: Determination."

reviewText:
The GoodThe story! Dear god, the story. What starts out as a pretty standard retro themed little-kid-in-a-scary-world RPG quickly turns into genuine care for well designed characters, some of which are downright hilarious and all of which are memorable. The complete lack of a fourth wall is played to perfection in each of the three available endings, and there are a number of twists and turns to surprise even the most jaded gamer. (Indeed, that's the whole point!)

The music is nothing short of phenomenal, and there will absolutely be tunes you catch yourself humming (or trying to get out of your head) weeks later.

Undertale has a very unique battle system - rather than the usual final-fantasy-esque bit where you swing a sword at someone from 10 feet away and they take damage, you actually dodge various bullets in a touhou/danmaku-esque game of skill. This means that if you're good enough, you can take no damage whatsoever. This means that careful play is rewarded, and there is no grinding required to make meaningful progression.

The BadUndertale is short - an amateur speedrunner can complete the game from start to finish in two hours, and a normal human in 3-4 hours. This may or may not be a bad thing, though, since you must play through the game at least three times to experience everything it has to offer.

It's hard to read anything about the game online without running into spoilers. Given how much story and care is packed into its short time frame, any spoilers you find will be *disastrous* to your enjoyment.

The UglyRealizing that the creator of this masterpiece, Toby Fox, is so burned out on the hype and subsequent positive reaction that there will probably never be a sequel or a usage of these characters ever again.

OverallRPG of the year 2015. You owe it to yourself to pick this game up, and then after you've beaten it, to go pick up the soundtrack. Damn near flawless, and the most memorable game in a long time. Highly, highly recommended!
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
In the past, if I said game had a great story, I meant that the story would be great even if it were removed from the context of player interaction, mechanics, level design, and the rest of the things that separate video games from other sorts of media.

That definition didn't really work with Undertale.

Its story is so closely tied to it being a game that I can't really isolate it and examine it out-of-context. I constantly found myself examining (and to be honest, horrified by) what could've happened if I had made different decisions throughout the game. Juxtapose that with the game's cheerful humor and you get... well, Undertale.

Do yourself a favor and play it, its a decision you won't regret.

reviewText:
Ah, Undertale. Where do I begin?

It truly is amazing. The story, the characters, the gameplay, the adventure...

The story will never leave you. It's so memorable, you can never forget it. It's so deep, tragic, happy...
There are different routes you can take, and each one will scar you in a good or bad way. Once you finish you first route, there's no going back. Sure, you can reset, but what you did will never leave you. It's stuck with you. Forever.

The characters are so charming. Each one is different and unique, you'll love all of them. You create an in-game bond with them, and you'll start to actually care for them.

The gameplay is quite odd, but still very fun. To win a fight, you must dodge enemy attacks in a small box. After a few seconds, the box will dissapear, and you can do one of two things:
Deal damage to kill them, or use the Act" button until you can eventually spare them
Depending on which button you press
hoursPlayed:
have you heard that music? Amazing.

No game has impacted me so drastically as Undertale.

9.5/10

It's a mastapeece




"

The way battles work has got an original mechanism as I never saw something similar before: your soul is represented with a red heart and inside a limited area you can move it to dodge yourself from enemy attacks that vary a lot. There are occasions where you have your soul limited to specific movements too or that you are exposed to special enemy attacks that force you to either freeze yourself or to move yourself to ensure you don't get harmed. You really need to have dexterity in your fingers as some enemies attacks (especially bosses) can be really difficult to dodge. A note I would like to make is that in case you want to spare every monster
commentsCount:
is the fact that every monster you find has got a different way to be "defeated" and they are not only creative but will also surprise you and make you laugh a lot!

Controls - I don't have got a single complaint in these: they are simple and very sharp. If you are enoughly familiar with playing with a keyboard you won't have any issues.

Sound and music - Just like the graphics
column16:
these are retro-like. The sounds are varied and simple. While there is not a lot of different musical tracks in the game I found them pleasant.

Difficulty level - The level of difficulty is progressive and is challenging but not to the point of frustration.

Longevity and replay value - I finished the game in approximately 10 hours but the time of conclusion might vary depending of the player skills and the destiny you choose. It is relatively short
column17: but the fact that your actions change the whole story course gives you extra reasons to consider returning to the game and play it again.\n\nI am really happy that a game like this appeared in an industry overflooded with games with the same selling formulas and same conception formulas. It brought a completely new way to play an RPG and hooks you to the end. I do think the industry needs more games like this as with the technology evolution many game makers seem to forget what's most important in the conception of a videogame: its essence
column18: its soul.\n\nUndertale is a hidden indie gem that deserves recognization. I really can't find any complaint for it as I never found any annoyances in it nor even glitches. And this game can be yours for only 9

reviewText:
My not very well written brief reviewAt a first glance, this game appears to be another generic RPG. Get past the first 10 seconds and you'll find this game has another, more humorous coat. Get past that and you find this game's dark side. These elements blend to deliver an interesting story with some strong messages.

Undertale has a wonderfully unique combat system, one mostly based around NOT actually fighting anything.

TL:DRThis game made me laugh a lot, cry twice, and I had a lot of fun doing it.
Play it if you  want. I'd highly recommend it.

reviewText:
OverviewSetting
Undertale is a low-res RPG set in an undefinable setting. It borrows a lot of elements from several different archegenres, that I won't list here. The game takes place underground and across several different locations in this cavern.

Combat
This game uses turn based-combat with the command blocks similar to other RPGs that also employ this system, such as Attact and Item menues. While in combat, you utilize an attack bar"
date: where you must time your hits to the center of the bar for maximum damage during your turn. During the enemy's turn
recommended: you have the oppertunity to avoid their attacks
hoursPlayed: via verticle-shooter style
voteText:
where you must actually avoid attacks to prevent damage.

Graphics
Undertale uses Pixel-based graphics

such as Bit-trip runner and Cavestory.

Sound

but those were few and far between.

Story
Undertale is about a boy who fell down a hole into a cavern. Inside this cavern dwell monsters of many different shapes and forms
column21: but not all are inheriently hostile. Your journey through this cavern takes you through a few noteworthy areas
column22: and introduces you to a colorful cast of very well designed characters. While the characters themselves don't have a terrible amount of backstory
column23:
their personalities are very well conveyed and make this experience a very entertaining one.

Other notes/mechanics
Undertale is a unique game for a few reasons. First of all
column24: you don't have to kill a single creature. Not a single enemy. Second of all

but do require some thought and exploration to solve.

AND YOU CAN USE A CONTROLLER.

My thoughtsSo... This game is wonderful. It's beautifully thought out and executed in an extremely great manner that could lead to several hours of playtime. There's a huge world of lore and tidbits that could have you reading for hours at a time. The bosses of the game are unique in their attacks and personalities too

Final
I absolutely encourage anyone who enjoys games that take them on adventures to places forigen

and in your own mind. It's truly an experience worthy to be had.

reviewText:
There is so much to fathom or take into account involving Undertale; is it taking a little too much from its predecessors, or has it hit the perfect spot of being its own unique experience?

Well i definitely think the latter is what won me over, being a person who has played and experienced the other games that Undertale has cloned slightly (Earthbound, Mother etc.). The game distinguishes itself overall by its own unique quirky humour and moments, something that is kind of missing in today's gaming industry. Something that gives the game its own distinguishable style. Games like Portal are examples of this as they use an engine of visual style of other games (Half-Life, Source) yet somehow easily distinguish themselves from the others due to their incredible small stories and little slice of atmosphere put into it through the labour of love from the developers.

I am kind of rambling on, but my point still stands; Undertale is a game which from a couple of glances could fool anyone into thinking its just some kind of clone Japanese-esque RPG, but what it brings to the table that really makes a far better game than the others is the sheer atmosphere and level of emotion the game invokes on the player. The characters designed and the unique idea of the game state" style of interaction
date: where the game acts completely self aware really make the game for me. The style of the fighting involved is something that really hasn't been done before quite as well as this game. The polish and unreal attention to detail in everything in the game makes it pretty damn hard to find any plothole that sticks in your mind (looking at you Bioshock Infinite).\n\nThis game genuinely gave me hope for something great to come out of the Indie market. While a lot of developers these days are quick to throw "early access" and half finished products with little to no effort or labour involved in them
recommended: this game really shows that the indie market can outweight triple budget games by putting in some real passion to the works.\n\nOverall I would give this game a 9/10 easily just from how well Toby Fox has made it

reviewText:
Ah, Undertale. Where do I begin?

It truly is amazing. The story, the characters, the gameplay, the adventure...

The story will never leave you. It's so memorable, you can never forget it. It's so deep, tragic, happy...
There are different routes you can take, and each one will scar you in a good or bad way. Once you finish you first route, there's no going back. Sure, you can reset, but what you did will never leave you. It's stuck with you. Forever.

The characters are so charming. Each one is different and unique, you'll love all of them. You create an in-game bond with them, and you'll start to actually care for them.

The gameplay is quite odd, but still very fun. To win a fight, you must dodge enemy attacks in a small box. After a few seconds, the box will dissapear, and you can do one of two things:
Deal damage to kill them, or use the Act" button until you can eventually spare them
Depending on which button you press
hoursPlayed:
have you heard that music? Amazing.

No game has impacted me so drastically as Undertale.

9.5/10

It's a mastapeece

reviewText:
Watching a lets play or something would ruin it, it's massively about the experience but if you haven't had it spoiled it is easily the best game of the year, or many years. If you aren't sure, just play the demo.

The ending(s) are amazing and the storyline / narrative is amazing even if you don't like the RPG genre or narrative driven games. It is so well written that one of the hardest part of doing a genocide run (a run where you kill everything) is that it feels horrible since so many of the characters are so well presented and have such unique personalities, even in the random ecounter battles against common enemies it feels horrible killing them (most of the time, no one likes Jerry).

The soundtrack the second best I have ever heard, only thing that beats it is the Hotline Miami 2 soundtrack. Then again, I don't think it's possible to make a soundtrack that would better suit a game like this.

Also it is terrifying, at one point i was as far away from my monitor as my headset cable would go, with my headset around my neck. Maybe I'm just bad at scary things.

TL:DR play demo or just buy it please.

reviewText:
I had no money at first. I waited long and long just to gather the amount in hope to play this.

Meanwhile friends were playing it and the whole internet was talking about it. I thought I wouldn't have the chance to play this game/

One day , I finally had the money. The excitment couldn't hold me. I started playing it.

At first I was very confused and scared. Then as the game continued I found recomfort and safety.
Although I knew it wouldn't last. I started to feel guilt and fear. My hands were shaking as I was battling when I didn't wanted to hurt anyone.

I got sad shortly after , knowing that I had to leave the only place that would offer me recomfort and safety , that I would maybe never see the only person that helped me.

I had to carry on meeting other characters , some funny , some epic. I was filled with determination to move forward. I started to feel anger and frustration as I couldn't advance. But I stayed calm and tried again and again.

After a while I got melancolic. It still pained me , not being able to see the only being that protected you. But this feeling disapeared as I made more friends along my path.

After defeating the final boss... I couldn't hold my tears , I was crying of Joy. Even after the credits I still had tears and a little smile on my face , I was feeling in such a long time : happy...

But something was stopping me from closing the game. Because I knew if I closed it. Then all this wonderful experience would come to an end.

But even after closing it I could still hear this little music box in my head , with all the good memories this game gave me.


It will be an experience I will never forget. An experience that showed me so much and reminded me of so much. For ever.... I will store it into my heart and share it.
Thank you , to all the devs that made this wonderful game.

reviewText:
Ahh boy, Undertale.

Undertale is an alright game.
There, I said it, it's alright.

It's not revolutionary, it's not incredible, it's not really deep. it's alright

Here's whats going on with undertale.

The music is fantastic, easily the best part of the game.
It's -kind of- funny.
The characters are interesting, but I feel like a lot of the game relies too heavily on the players imagination. I'm okay with this, but for a lot of players this might be a big miss.
It mixes classic rpg but if you're looking for a traditional RPG experience, this isn't exactly that. There's like 8 weapons and 9 armor sets you can find, with minimal differences sort of this ones slightly stronger" and some have a mild effect as well.

It's a very short game and not so much a game as it is a story. The menu is clunky
date: there's no config options. The only revolutionary part of it is bridging the gap between games and books really.\n\nThat being said

reviewText:
You'll Feel It In Your Bones, This Game Is Your Destemmie - An Official Waffle King Review
~Find more here.[www.nonm.co.uk]

Howdy!

I bet you love happiness and love, huh? You like warm, fuzzy feelings? Puppies and cute things? You don't like to feel sad, do you?


You need to play this game then.


Play this game, and it'll make you happy. And the happier you are, the more love you'll feel.


You can trust your ol' pal Waffle King on this one.


Undertale is a game like very few others. It's an RPG with a unique twist. The entire game can be played without killing a single monster. All of them can be dealt with in a peaceful and civil manner. Or alternately you can kill all of them, but why would you want to do that? ♥♥♥♥.


And I really must say, every possible expectation I had was gratuitously exceeded.


I did not know a game like this could happen. I did not think it possible.


This is Mother 4. The real Mother 4. Unless Nintendo makes another one, I guess. But even then, there's no telling if it'd be a product of genuine heartfelt emotion like this is. Mother 4: Zip Lash" would not have the same impact Undertale has
date:
you know?


Undertale is imbued with a magic that I've only ever seen come out of Nintendo's Treehouse. The writing is on par with a Mario & Luigi or a Paper Mario. No
recommended: I'd go a step further. This is a better Mario & Luigi or Paper Mario than Nintendo's most recent installments in those two series. If you were to combine Sticker Star and Dream Team
hoursPlayed:
you'd get maybe half the charm and wit that Undertale packs.


The gameplay itself isn't just a vehicle for the story
voteText: either. It's a hybrid turn-based action RPG exactly like any of the Super Mario ones that Nintendo puts out. Press buttons to make your attacks hit harder
helpfulPercent: or dodge incoming enemy attacks to avoid damage. Undertale's dodging system in particular is something interesting
votesHelpful: resembling a bullet-hell shooter. You'll move your character's icon around the screen
votesTotal: avoiding the flurry of incoming attacks. Choosing the peaceful route will net you plenty of dodge time
votesFunny:
seeing as most enemies aren't too keen on making peace regardless.


The intense bullet-hell battles climax with the game's magnificent boss fights. Each one adds a devious twist to the rules you thought you knew
commentsCount: suddenly messing with the game's mechanics in unique and impressive ways. And all complimented by a phenomenal soundtrack. I really could not pinpoint a favorite track or musical piece in the game because they're all so kickass
column16:
but that's not what's most impressive.


The quirky cast of characters that make up the various boss fights each have their own perfectly fitting boss theme that seems to fully encompass their personality and their boss fight. The adrenaline rush of a badass boss theme complimented by hell raining down on you from all angles
column17: and then twisted around with a unique boss mechanic that completely changes the way you have to think about playing
column18: makes for an  extremely satisfying experience. And the game consistently tops itself. Whenever you think that there's no way they could top a particular part of the game
column19:
it destroys your expectations accordingly.


It's the type of game that you finish and just sit there
column20: basking in the glow of your monitor
column21: contemplating where you could possibly go from there. Chances are whatever you play next won't make you feel the same way. Not even a sense of attachment to the game
column22: or to the characters. But a sense of satisfaction that goes beyond simple entertainment. The feeling of a game that's communicating with you in a heartfelt and genuine manner. There's a soul to the game
column23: a life that was born organically. It wasn't planned out at a business meeting
column24: it wasn't a checklist on a sell-sheet. It wasn't even the by-product of a couple of crazy kids and their wild ideas to strike it rich in the indie computer game industry. It feels inspired
column25:
and it feels like it came from someone's heart. It's video games as an interactive art form.


There are highs
column26: and there are lows to Undertale's overall mood. You'll swing from outrageous
column27: stupid
column28: and ridiculous moments right to a punch up your scrotum and into your ribcage to yank out your heart. There's twists and turns. And there's dogs
column29:
lots of dogs. And skeletons. And a motherly goat that you can flirt with. All important things that are totally relevant to the plot.


I could give Undertale all the stars or 10/10's in the world. I could give it two thumbs up
column30:
because I only have two thumbs. But my final word on it is just a genuine plea that it be played and enjoyed by as many people as possible.


It's as real and genuine as a freshly baked pie from a loved one. And what kind of sick ♥♥♥♥ hates pie?


Not playing this game is like refusing to pet a really fluffy dog. You just gotta

you know? You just gotta. Do it.

reviewText:
This game is amazing.

I appreciate the various retro art styles, you can see an Apple II type style in-battle, and a sort of SNES/NES-esque style in the over world.

The characters, while not being overly thought out or dissected, are easily acquainted with and you can hardly help but seem to like every one of them for their quirky, humorous natures.

Battles, while being randomly chosen after a set number of steps which is a primitive way of doing encounters, are still fun despite this face. The music you have while fighting is upbeat when appropriate and sometimes dramatic and suspenseful. Which only adds to the dodging sort of mini game you play while enemies take their turns in battle.

The story is really good, if you can get into it and appreciate it. Which in certain circumstances could be a good OR a bad thing. You're a human who has fallen down into the perilous Mt. Ebott, you don't know why you are here not, but it seems like it was meant to be. You're definetly not the first human to fall down, but you'll be damned before you don't become the first to escape alive, no matter if you are a violent psychopath or kind and caring type.

If you love RPG's with an engaging story, crazy and addictive music, enjoyable bullet dodging scenarios, and a healthy combination of smiles and tears, Undertale is for you.

reviewText:
Undertale is the story told in 3-5 hours; perfect for the price range and an afternoon or night of gameplay. You'll find yourself sucked in to the expertly crafted world. Your expectations will constantly be turned on their head, and there are more than a few laugh out loud moments. Characters are well written, expressive, and grow if you let them.

The game centers on the Fight or Spare mechanic. Fight and you lose everyone who could be your friend, spare and you'll discover a robust story and character development - impressive for the amount of time in which this is done.

Sparing works similar to demon conversations in the Shin Megami Tensei games. You have to figure out which dialog options are best for the fight to move on without combat.

Dodging attacks becomes a game in and of itself; youll be locked in a window as a heart, and have to bound around and dodge countless forms of attacks, many of which are absolutely inspired in how well designed they are, and how fun they are to encounter.

The soundtrack (and sound effects for that matter) has clever nods to a variety of classic games such as EarthBound, Final Fantasy, Secret of Mana, Chrono Trigger and so on. Not to be overlooked! You'll be whistling the music for days afterward.

I can't recommend this game enough!

reviewText:
True Pacifist here.

Loved the game.  The writing went above and beyond expectation, the musical variety and intensity was excellent.  Gameplay was...well, it's an RPG, but the ACT system is quite creative, and the player has to piece things together to achieve their goals.  That being said, the best part about this game is the ending, especially for pacifists.  The last -- what, eight hours?  Masterfully crafted, and absolutely something you should play through for yourself.  Toby did good work.

Most of the game: 8/10, enjoyable and unique but not my favorite game ever

Papyrus: 10/10, bones untrousled

Mettaton: 10/10, fabulous fight

Everything past Mettaton: 12/10 hold on to your hopes and dreams

Surpasses AAA titles in thought-provocation and emotional draw, made mostly by 1 dude, it's ten dollars.  Worth the money.

reviewText: I don't usually do this sort of thing, but after playing Undertale, I feel compelled to write a review, just so the developer can get the money that it deserves. I am still under an hour into the game, but the amount of intricate details placed into the game brought me to tears. Every NPC, even the random encounter enemies, feel alive; they have personality, desires, feelings and fears. It really feels like they have their own lives, lives that are completely separate from the protagonist adventures. For the first time in a long time, I honestly have the feeling... that I don't want to kill them. I don't want them to die. I want for them to live their lives and be happy. I want to protect all of them no matter the cost. Fallout is amazing for its storyline, and not necessarily by their choices (though they do play a small part in the game), but Undertale nailed the mercy/kill route to a tee. It gave me an incentive to keep them alive not by rewards, or stat point; they make me want to keep them alive because it made me genuinely care about them, their lives, and their love. I now understood why Jim Sterling gave this game a 10/10. It's a labor of love, a true testament of how much effort a man can put into a game, and make it shine like the sun and the moon. I can only wish that more people know of this game, that more people can but this game, just so the dev can make the money they deserves. Undertale definitely gets an A" in my book
date: and I sincerely look forward to the Dev's next game... however long it may take."

reviewText:
Real Review Time with Zens! [Possible Spilers]

Undertale is a rare game to come along. It explores the concept of player choice, save games, 100% completionism, and morality systems in an unexpected way. It is charming, but dark. In a way Earthbound had it. There are dark moments, but remains primarily charming. There is a way to make it far less charming and that will be immediately obvious how as you play the game. The game's heart is very large and it can be very judgemental as well, but in a good way I think.

Also, you will probably find some 4-8 new favorite new characters in here. Characters are well written and interesting. The jokes are well written and funny (Except those intentionally terrible ones. Momedian. You have been warned.) A beautiful game.

While some people liken it to Mother 3, Mother 3 is a train of emotional torment. Undertale has the heart and spirit Mother 1 and 2 in it. The charm never lets up if you take the proper path and you keep getting reasons to fight (in a way. You should avoid that button unless you wanna have a bad time). But the elements of other games such as Spec Ops (Yes), Jets and Guns (just a little), Schmups, Stanley Parable, and other games help ensure this is not just some Mother game. It is its own tale, of its own right.

Dodging attacks becomes a game in and of itself; youll be locked in a window as a heart, and have to bound around and dodge countless forms of attacks, many of which are absolutely inspired in how well designed they are, and how fun they are to encounter.

The soundtrack (and sound effects for that matter) has clever nods to a variety of classic games such as EarthBound, Final Fantasy, Secret of Mana, Chrono Trigger and so on. Not to be overlooked! You'll be whistling the music for days afterward.

I can't recommend this game enough!

reviewText: A League of its Own\nI was skeptical back in October 2015 when I began hearing things about a game called Undertale".  Friends had told me to give it a try

reviewText:
Personally, I love this game a ton because of how much it gives and gives. You think you're done but there's just so much more to find out.
The feels this game gives is a lot, too. If you're someone who isn't a toughguy about getting attached to characters in a story, then this game does extremely well at making 2d characters likeable.
Additionally, the soundtrack and story itself are extremely well done.
Definitely a great game and is probably one of the top games on my personal list of 'best games 4ever'

I wouldn't say it's the definite best game forever because I feel like this game could also completely flip around for some people. It's not for everybody. While I love it, some people may hate it.

Undertale.

reviewText:
started game, got attacked by a jerkass of a flower, got saved by a surrogate mother, got led through some puzzles, got a phone, called her a lot, made my way through puzzles by myself, futzed around for a bit, cheered up a ghost, had to eventually ask to go home even though I sort of didn't want to but really ought to have anyway, had to fight someone I didn't want to, killed them when I intended to spare them, frantically reloaded save...

....FOUND OUT TO MY HORROR/AWE THAT THE GAME KNEW I HAD DONE THAT AND REACTED ACCORDINGLY...


INFINITY/10 Going to fully restart from scratch to play again

Having now completed the game, and gotten the True Pacifist ending, I'm in awe. I... I COULD go and play a Genocide run now but... I can't bring myself to. I'm just not that kind of person... I mean you can, but you're gonna have a Bad Time.

So many incredible characters, great detailed backstory, wonderful interactions, wonderful humour and HEARTWRENCHING FEELS... This is right up there on my best games ever mental list.

watch the trailer seriously, if that doesn't make you want the game, you have no soul.

(also bonus points for awesome punwork)

reviewText: As an animator the first thing that really drew me to this game was some of the things a friend had shown me happening during some of the boss fights. It was very creative and I wanted to see what else they had done in the normally static pixel rpgs. I had heard of it, played the demo a while ago, and been recommended it multiple times but this got me to finally buy it. Since then I have bought it for 2 more people and have found my thoughts drifting to it often. The best way to describe the game is inspiring. The soundtrack is absolutely phenomenal, the writing is superb, the animation is charming and impressive. But what it becomes as a package is to me the best indie game to date with many moving parts that great an experience that might be labled to outsiders as art in video game form. I've personally believed video games are art for quite some time, but many do not share this opinion. If you meet these people, have them buy this 10 dollar game gem and they are likely to reconsider.

reviewText:
Not since I played To the Moon have I played a game that touched me on so many different levels. Light hearted and fun with a great use of darkness and some great twists along the way, Undertale turns the idea of RPGs on its head and makes us feel for the monsters we fight and grind through.

I found myself at times completely blown away by the unique uses of common RPG mechanics (which you've got to see for yourself, you'll know when you see them). Truly a refreshing experience in both combat, story, and overall gameplay.

As such I highly recommend Undertale (and it's amazing soundtrack as well)! It's certainly one of my 2015 games of the year.

reviewText:
This game, I'm not even sure where to start.
I picked it up on a whim because it looked cute and charming and sat down to play.
I've...well.. I found it very difficult to stop. This game is...utterly charming..adorable. It really gave me...so many..emotions. Like no other game has in a very long time.
It isn't your traditional RPG that is for certain. But it is a treasure. Something special. And I love it.

So many times it managed to grab me right by the heart and just lock me in, hold my attention, the whole world vanished save me and the game. And...some fifteen hours later.. I'm..I'm genuinely sad that it is over. I want so much for there to be more...for it to be longer. For, anything, everything. The entire experience was a delight and to the developer, I want to say, thank you so much. You are an artist, a true creator. And this is an amazing piece of work that I will hold in my memory for a very long time. Forever, if I am lucky.

That might sound sappy to you, the reader. But this is really the sweetest game I have played. I know there is another way to play but I cannot even fathom that now. It...just doesn't seem like something I can do.. I've grown so attached and fond of these characters. And I don't think I could do it, even if I tried.

What is Undertale? You might think, it is just some kiddy rpg. But..you would be mistaken. The gameplay...is surprisingly original when it comes to the battle" system and was definetely not what I was expecting. It was enjoyable to learn
date: difficult to master. And the various bosses added their own spice that kept me guessing and
hoursPlayed: fuming but I always came back for more.\n\nIt takes a lot of cues from Yumi Nikki

reviewText:
There is little to say about this game that doesn't spoil it.

In its core, it's an RPG. Accenting it is bullet hell based combat systems. The gameplay twist, if you will.

So far, everyone who I know who's played the game has had a strong emotional reaction to it. Most enjoy it, one felt a strong disgust, but it was interesting to see his reaction regardless. It's difficult to avoid hype without seeming like you're mindlessly following the bandwagon. But this game's worth it for the story alone.

Long story short: Earthbound meets Stanley Parable meets To The Moon.

reviewText: On the surface (no pun intended), Undertale is an rpg with a quirky twist. You don't have to kill anyone. Undertale is more than that though. It's an rpg that makes you question what you know about games, what you know about typical video game characters and tropes, what you know about yourself. Sometimes it tries a bit too hard to get this message across, but for the most part this is a game full of love. This is some of the most brilliant writing in a game ever, and it has great, interesting characters, all who feel real and have their place in the world. If you care about small details in video games, Undertale is for you. It is bursting at the seams with charm and wit. The soundtrack is also beautiful and understated. Undertale does so many things right. It does have flaws, but they're easily forgiven. Mostly it requires a bit of patience and attention for detail to truly understand what the story means, and the hundreds, possibly even thousands of in-jokes, references and secrets that the game has to offer. I felt a lot of things playing Undertale. I felt happy, I felt sad, I felt confused, I felt frustrated, but most of all I wanted to know what happened next.  I guess you could say that I was filled with determination.

reviewText:
Undertale is simply one of the best RPGs I have played in a very long time, and it will likely touch you and effect your emotions in ways that no RPG ever has before.

The game has two very distinct ways to play. You can kill, or you can spare. As advertised, no one has to die in this game. It is possible to spare every single enemy, even the bosses. The story alters greatly depending on how you play, and it is nigh impossible to discuss aspects of it without spoiling something, but, I can tell you it has an amazing storyline, with plenty of twists and turns. Also, while you are free to choose how you play, a pacifist (no killing) run is highly recommended. This is a game where choices truly matter.

You do not control a party in this game, rather, you control a single character. Physical combat is done through a timed-hit system, where you do more damage to monsters if you press the button on time. If going the pacifist route, then each battle is something like a negotiation. You are able to select special actions in order to interract with monsters in a non-lethal way, in order to come to a truce. Either way you cut it, the combat system in this game is truly unique, for its dodging system alone. Near the bottom of the screen is a box with a heart. When monsters attack, you get to move this heart around in order to dodge their attacks and avoid taking damage. Think a schmup title where you move in all 4 directions to avoid bullets, it is very similar to that. Boss fights almost always bring a unique effect to this as well, changing up the rules a bit on how dodging works with them, so each one feels unique and original in how they operate.

The game is also quite nice visually. Its art style is clearly inspired by the Mother series, and there are many creative and bizarre monsters that you will encounter on your journey. Each area of the game feels unique, and areas do not feel bland or repetitive in design. Monster sprites in-battle are animated, and also have a monochrome color scheme.

The soundtrack is also very nice, and is filled with all sorts of tunes. The soundtrack overall fits the game very, very well, and no piece of music really feels out of place. Music variety is also very good, and manages to capture a very wide range of emotions, something the game is good at overall.

The characters are another of the game's strong points. No two characters in this game feel the same. They all have their own unique personalities, and are all written amazingly well. Even basic NPCs in towns are all unique from one another; not one sprite is used twice, with the exception of the NPCs in a certain town, though that's a somewhat..special case, we'll say.

Overall, Undertale is a fantastic game. Don't make the mistake of looking at the screenshots and thinking it's just some silly quirky RPG; it is so, so much more. It is an unforgettable journey, filled to the brim with personality, and characters you will grow to love. It is difficult to find any major flaws at all in this game. If I can think of one minor complaint, it's that the random battles can feel somewhat repetitive after a while, especially if you're going Pacifist, but this is minor, especially considering most random battles are quite short once you figure out how to win them, and they are usually not super-frequent.

Buy it. Buy it now.

reviewText:
Undertale is a masterpiece and by all means the best game I have ever played.

If you like any of the following video games: Earthbound, Mother 3, Cave Story, the Shin Megami Tensei series, Ace Attorney, and bullet-hell shmups, you'll definitely find something to love about Undertale. However, this WORK OF ART doesn't only build upon the pre-established conventions of the games listed prior, it innovates upon them in bold and inventive ways that I could never even conceive until I came across Undertale.

Now, I could write pages and pages about the lovable cast of characters and how both hilarious and downright terrifying the world that Toby Fox created can be, but I see no reason to do that, as I'm sure that there are countless reviews  which are probably better than anything I could ever write that explain all of those things clearly.

Undertale gets a well deserved 10/10.

Now do yourself a favor and buy this game or I'll come over to your house and make you some spaghetti.
It'll be good, I promise; but nowhere near as good as this game.

This is potentialy my Game of the Year for 2015, it's ironic really how all these $60 - $120 (Collector's edition) games come out and try to impress us, and here comes this sweet little game that just takes Steam by storm, no DLC, no Microtransactions, no pretentious indie stuff, just a sweet game that's really nice to play.

Update: Man this game it just keeping getting better as you go on, i'd love to sit here and tell you the details and features but it's honestly one of those game you have to try to understand why it's so loved, telling you more than what you can see from the simple trailer would only rob you of the enjoyment.

But i wll tell you this, so many subtle things are in this game that you'll be left wondering if you had made another choice would something had turned out the other way? And to both your pleasure, and possibly disdain the anwer is usually yes.

But the game supports multiple playthroughs and remembers your choices though all of them, so go ahead and play with zero regrets.

reviewText:
This game really is something else. I don't know what I could possibly say without spoiling anything, but it's rare that a game comes along, and makes me feel, and connect so strongly with each, and every one of the characters included within the narrative. (Toriel is best GOAT mom.) The art-style I can understand as being subjective, aka not everyone's thing, but it personally clicked with me, and I feel like it perfectly compliments the game. (See LISA: The Painful RPG as another example.)  The OST is a glorious mixture of chip-tune, and more modern-esque themes. Well to put it in a much better way, the OST is one of those very rare soundtracks where every single track on the list is just magnifique. Despite being an RPG, the length for this is just the right length with the average playthrough being around 8-10 hours. The combat as well is fantasic, and very unique in how it is implemented, and you'll always need to stay alert during attacks.

I guess the bit of criticism I have would be that some boss battles are a bit unclear as what you need to do to get past them in a non-lethal manner, but as I looked back at my playthrough I realized I wasn't paying enough attention to some of the hints that were being dropped.

All in all I'm still thinking about all of the characters that I've encountered, and I just want to keep going back, and interact with them even more. As a last thing I should add, while there are many games that use the Mother series as a measuring stick in how much they aspire to achieve a similar set of emotions that emerged from said series, Undertale is one of the few games that I feel that truly accomplished what it set out to do, and is one of the finest games to have been inspired by EarthBound.

What I'm trying to say here is if you're looking for something fresh, and have fond memories for Earthbound, if this game has been in your sights lately, and you need a final push then consider this review that push, and do yourself the favor you've been meaning to do. Support this game, Support Toby Fox, Support the Indie Dev industry. All of us here would truly love to see more like this from such a creatively free industry in the future.

EDIT: Beat the game for the second time at the end of 2015. Still 10/10 GOTY / GOAT worthy.

reviewText: The game looks pretty basic, but there is depth and variety to this game that will put AAA titles to shame. At its heart a puzzle-RPG hybrid game, it quickly both reinforces and subverts those ideas. The story is lovely and the characters are touching, in their own strange ways. The fact that you have the choice to not hurt a single soul in this game is well implimented and remarked upon.\n\nHonestly, my GOTY for 2015. I can't see many other games nearing the hights this game touches.

reviewText:
This game is easily, hands down, the best game I've ever played. Now, if you want to know everyone else's reasons for loving this game, go ahead and scroll down. I challenge you to find a -single- bad review for this game. Why? Because this has everything you could ask for.

The story of this game is remarkably compelling- it merits replay after replay.. Not in spite of the fact that you know the story, but BECAUSE you know the story! It's like a book. The more you re-read, the more you understand, the more secrets you unlock, the more you enjoy it and feel for the characters.

And that's what you do in this game- you feel for the characters. They're not static like in most other RPGs you find- Somehow, they seem more relatable, more alive, more -human- than most humans in other games. Where most games, you have one well-developed character, in this game, you have.... Well, I'm not going to spoil it.

I would go on and on and on, and I easily could... But I will have MERCY and SPARE you the massive review. Suffice it to say this:

While most game dev -teams- struggle to make a compelling game, somehow Tobyfox managed to make a game that eclipses all of them, practically by himself. So put that in your spaghetti. If you need some salt for it, just lean over the plate. The tears this game's storyline will give you will be salt enough.


Ten out of Ten stars. I would give it more, but that's mathematically impossible. Oh well, giving it the highest score of any review I've ever made, and am likely to ever make, is fair enough....

This is like if Hayao Miyazaki and the Earthbound devs collaborated and made a video game together.

Normally this is the part where I go in depth about the game, but really it's one of those things where you should know as little about it as possible before going into it for the best possible experience.

reviewText:
This is, quite possibly, the best game of the year. Hell, maybe of the past FIVE years. It's a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ masterpiece, and I loved every moment of it.

STORY: 10/10

Anything I could say here would spoil everything. All I can say is this: It's amazingly well written, the comedy is hilarious, and the FOURTH WALL BREAKING IS ALMOST NIGHTMARISH FLOWEY YOU SACK OF SHI--

SOUNDTRACK: 9/10

It's TobyFox. What did you expect? Most, if not all, of the songs are incredible. Just go to his Bandcamp and give it a listen. It's beautiful, it sounds amazing, and some of them are even ♥♥♥♥ING TERRIFYING FLOWEY YOU PIECE OF SHI--

GAMEPLAY: 9/10

It blends RPG, bullet hell, and even platformer and shoot-em-up together perfectly. At some points I found myself gritting my teeth over how ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t some of the attacks felt, but the bosses only used them once or twice OR A MILLION TIMES FLOWEY YOU SACK OF SHI--

OVERALL: 9.5/10

It's a beautiful game. The characters feel genuine, the humor is amazing, and the story is so sad and yet so heartwarming that it might even make a grown man cry. Okay maybe not but still. BUY IT. BUY. IT. NOW. GIVE TOBY YOUR MONEY. HE DESERVES IT.

And don't pull a genocide run. Please don't.

reviewText:
(There are some spoilers around here, so I'll put the spoilers in black )

Oh my god, that game is just pure amazing.. I knew this game just by browsing around on Steam and it looked nice for me, so I decided to buy it but I couldn't buy the soundtracks sadly. I actually fully played the game without knowing the spoilers, so, I was discovering the story step by step. But I didn't know that there were 3 kind of modes, and, obviously, I started with the Neutral mode because I killed some ennemies (there are some ennemies which I didn't dare to kill them cuz they looked too cute for me).  The ending of the neutral mode really scared me. Oh my god.. When I mercied Asgore once I defeated him, Flowey appeared in a very creepy form and it kinda traumatised me lol, and plus my game got 'crashed' several times when I had to fight Flowey in his creepy form.

And now, I fully resetted the mode and I'm going to do the Pacifist mode. And for the Genocide mode, nope, I think I would cry so much..

I can tell the game has a lot of feelings, trust me. It's sometimes funny, interesting and even sad ! I even almost cried sometimes. And good thing is that you don't have to kill the ennemies, it's up to your choice !
I strongly recommend you that game if you like RPGs and games with lots of feelings ! :)

reviewText: This game is great but clearly not a GOTY, since it can't compete with AAA titles. Yet Undertale is an experience that one will remember for quite some time. I got both natural" and "true" endings of the game as well as read all the lore about "bad" ending. Made up some of my theories and connections that were implied and thats what makes this game great- it implies a lot of stuff yet lets you come to your own conclusions giving you parts of information.\n\nI think that ideas shown in the game were already used in some other game or movie
date: but no matter if I am wrong or right non the less it's still interesting to play through the game.\n\nGameplay itself is rather easy
recommended: sometimes these speech bubbles get annoying (when they are pretty much filling the space)
hoursPlayed: music is nice
voteText: characters are recognizable
helpfulPercent: almost all your actions have impact on the world in one way or another which is extra nice. Price tag is rather big for a pixel isometric game by itself if you ask me
votesHelpful:
but with the fact that beating this game once will take you about 5 hours or so and with the fact that game encourages you to beat it at least two times (or more if you want to read all the possible lore yourself) price of 10 usd does not sound that much.

And a side note that has little to no relation to game review itself.
Overall I played this game after a huge overexposure to it on Tumblr and other social media websites. I saw dozens of lame jokes and I thought that maybe if I play the game these joke would become funny. And while in fact some of them turned out to be rather silly
votesTotal: huge deal of fanmade content stayed boring. Just wanted to say that if you feeling annoyed with all the things that fans are doing online and you haven't played the game yet
votesFunny: you might as well do it if you have spare money and time."

reviewText:
Today I finished Undertale. And I may very well never play this game again. And if I do, I don't expect it to be for a long time. Of course, it is not because it was an awful game, or because it was unfulfilling, or because I have far too many games in my library that I haven't touched (I do). The opposite. This game was an amazing, wild, beautiful roller coaster of emotion and pleasure. It's been years since I wandered across a game that could have me laughing with all my heart before I felt like someone had shoved their fist into my chest cavity and squeezed that same heart. It left me smiling and on the verge of tears in just minutes of eachother.

I loved every moment of it.

This game, from its minimal, but endearing art style, to its touching, clever music, to its diverse and beautiful characters. All of it had so much time, so much energy and so much, dare I say it, SOUL put into it. To me, every moment felt genuine. This is the kind of love and effort someone should put into their game. While we have Steam being flooded with half-built, unfinished money-grabs for twenty or even thirty dollars, this wanders unexpectedly into our lap. It's a diamond on par with Cave Story, or the Banner Saga, or Bastion.

I told a friend I would have payed the price of the game to have everything before the titlecard and all the music. And now that I've beaten it, I can't say I would take that back. If I had to pick a list of games for my children to play (or at least my nieces and nephews), this would be on there.

I'm not saying it was a perfect game. I'm not saying that it's even the BEST game put out this year. But this game grabs my number one spot for being so clever and so touching. I hope to god we can see more of this kind of thing making its way into the world, games that are more a product of time and love than they are money and ground-breaking technology.

reviewText:
This game is is just great. Mew Mew Kissey Cutie 2 is trash though. This game has so much character. Most games are just KILL. KILL. FINAL BOSS. GAME OVER. Now I'm not saying those types of games are bad, but those kind of games are (I spent 2 minutes trying to think of a word btw) simple. And the annoying thing is some people judge this game based on it's graphics. Guys. IT'S SUPPOSED TO HAVE GRAPHICS LIKE POKEMON OR ZELDA or something like that. I mean sure the gameplay isn't exactly god's gift to gamers but still. Also the game has a point on
the whole save point thing. when people do a pacifist run, some people are just curious. They are just curious enough to do a genocide run. And they just kill everyone. You feel bad. You want to go back and do the pacifist run all over again to make everyone happy. But to do that, you have to sell your SOUL to Chara. And it changes the end of the pacifist run. So this game has so many important life lessons. It has homosexual couples, Anxiety, Depression, etc. So In Conclusion, I really recommend this game. Buy it for a friend, and buy it for yourself. Sorry if this review was a little all over the place but this is the first review I've ever typed lol.

reviewText:
Undertale...
I've never written such a serious review before.
I've never played a game which affected me so emotionally and deeply.
I've never played a game in which it could draw me in and be so emotionally riveting, and immensly powerful.
I've never played a game where I could bond over characters without voices.
As a game where you are cast into the underground and fight/spare your way to the surface, I have never thought that this would be one of my favorite games of all time.
Giving a critical review for Undertale would be irrelevant, as this game is critically perfect.
It is outstanding how much care went into the characters, settings, and almost every tiny detail.
So in a critical standpoint, I would give this game a 10/10, hands down.
This game amazes me, that it can be so simple, yet so complex and moving.
Even the soundtrack manages to be simply amazing.
Overall, if you haven't got the game already, please get it. It simply is immensly moving and amazing.

reviewText:
Summary and Suggestion
This is, without a doubt, the best gaming experience I have had in years if not my entire life. But before you read my review or watch my videos, I heavily encourage you to play this game as blind as possible if you can and are willing. Don't look details up, don't watch playthroughs, and experience the game for yourself. Mr. Toby Fox has done an incredible job making this game an experience rather than something to beat, and you will continue to be surprised by everything from major changes to small details from playthrough to playthough.

...still reading? Okay, here goes a review as spoiler-free as I can make it.

Gameplay
Undertale is a game that presents itself as a classic turn-based random-encounter RPG, but it adds two unique gameplay elements. First, your defenses take the form of a bullet hell. Secondly, the game almost always offers non-violent solutions even within battle through the Act" and "Mercy" options. By interacting with monsters based on their personalities and desires
date: you alter the shape of the battle. Speaking strictly gameplay-wise
recommended: this system is deep and contains all levels of challenge...if you figure out how to find them.\n\nThe game emphasizes exploration and curiousity. It begs you to try all the things and have multiple playthroughs. It asks you to act based on your feelings and shapes your experience around the type of player you are. Even doing the same type of playthrough a second time can create a different experience. The game learns and talks with you in both explicit and subtle ways
hoursPlayed: and you are expected to piece the full story together through your different encounters and possible paths. And it is worth it. No matter how deep you want to dig
voteText:
the game has enough to offer.

Design and Story
The characters' designs are diverse and engaging
helpfulPercent: and the music and sound design emphasize each of their personalities and moods extremely well. They have varying degrees of self-awareness and often will give you hints to the game's deeper lore if you listen carefully. The story is touching and it actively seeks players who are empathetic. But the game is not for children by any means. As innocent and simple as the game may first appear
votesHelpful: it will very quickly scare and complicate the story. And it does a good job of letting you know that early on
votesTotal:
to prepare you.

Cons
To be honest
votesFunny: many of this game's cons ultimately come down to player preference. There are a few
commentsCount: as there always are. The game's visual design is often inconsistent due to the multitude of different artistic styles
column16: although this did not interfere with my enjoyment of the game so much as add to the feeling of the world's diversity. Your character is meant to be as interpretable as possible in its design to allow you to fill in the blanks
column17: but those who want to be provided a character may be disappointed with a lumpy-looking protagonist.\n\nThe game is sometimes obtuse and will not tell you when you have crossed a point of no return or altered your future game experience. This can frustrate some players as there is only one save slot. There is an extremely good REASON to only have one save slot
column18: though
column19: but that may not excuse the inconvenience for some. So
column20: if you're looking for a game to play once
column21: have the whole story
column22: and be done with
column23:
this may not be for you.

Conclusion
Beyond that
column24: I have no complaints. I do not regret spending hours on this game or buying it for my friends. I would not be opposed to spending hours more if I would not feel guilty for doing so... I heavily recommend this game to anyone who enjoys a good story
column25: music
column26: retro RPGs
column27: a deep experience
column28: or a game that actively changes based on your actions. I'd try to recommend this game to people who hate those things too
column29:
but that might be asking too much.

Playthrough
I am currently uploading and fixing a recording of my playthrough of the game to my YouTube channel. If you want to see the game in progress before purchasing
column30: then you can check out the link below.\n\nMaven Plays Undertale"

reviewText: This is one of the most expertly crafted RPGs I've ever played. The characters are deep and its hard not to like any of them because they all have admirable qualities. The music is jaw-dropping and most of the tracks give me goosebumps when I hear the track start. The gameplay is astounding, and htat's putting it midly. Though it may seem simple at first, the combat quickly ramps up in difficulty to allow you to test your skills. And finally, the story behind this game is very well thought out and every choice you make has an outcome somewhere down the line. Good or bad, you'll be reminded of the choices you've made and forcing you to think before doing.\n\nThis is a very well-made game and it'd be a crime not to play it.
